Author: huu
Review Content: Overwatch 2...I'll be the first one to say - I haven't played much Overwatch 2. This is more-so a recap of my time with Overwatch 1, why I stopped playing it, and why I never came back, even with the release of Overwatch 2.Let's wind the clock back to 2017. I was getting very bored of Team Fortress 2 by that point. The "Meet Your Match" update, which likely released to try to compete with Overwatch, had killed the way I was used to playing the game for about 4 years at that point, ruining the experience by making it feel more "competitive" rather than a fun, casual, silly game to mess around in. By that point, I was craving something new.Most of my friends had gone to Overwatch, so I started to want to play the game. Sometime in March 2017, Blizzard hosted a free weekend for Overwatch, which is when I made my account and tried the game. Surprisingly - I enjoyed it. So much so that I started to want to play it, but problem is - I was an 18 year old without a job struggling to finish school. So I couldn't afford it. One of my friends at the time caught wind of this and gifted me a copy of Overwatch (thank you, by the way, Hitzip). I really appreciated this, and started playing, and at that time - firmly left TF2 behind.When I got into the game proper in May 2017, I was having a blast. I enjoyed the fact that, despite being more competitive than what I was used to with TF2, a lot of the skills I had from that game transferred over. I wasn't the best, but I was having a fun time. Being a Medic main in TF2 meant that I found my home with Mercy. Yes, I was a Mercy main, before the Mercy rework at that. There were a lot of things I genuinely enjoyed about Overwatch when it came out. The Sombra ARG, the Doomfist arc of piecing him together and even wondering if Doomfist will ever be a playable character. I was around for all of it, and following along both with YouTubers & Reddit, solving these cryptic mysteries, piecing it all together - it all reminded me of, well, Team Fortress 2. And its old updates, like Love & War and the bread stuff that came with it.When I first got into Overwatch back in 2017, it felt like I was part of a growing, accepting community. Jeff Kaplan's videos addressing the state of the game & ways they're taking to improve things was also a breath of fresh air compared to what I was used to with Valve, who would often just sit silent and do nothing, even to this very day. Legit, it was very exciting to play & be a part of the community by then.However, I bounced out of Overwatch in early 2018, last playing sometime in 2019 before giving up on Overwatch as a whole. And mainly because they started doing mass-reworks of, what felt like, every single character. First came the Mercy rework, which sucked for me as a Mercy main, but I could understand the logic behind it. She was stupidly easy to play and was ludicrously effective with her ultimate being a CTRL+Z keybind put into gameplay. But then came Symmetra, Torbjorn, the nerfs to Roadhog & Junkrat...it all became too much. I felt like I had to re-learn and re-adapt to what felt like every old character being tossed out and replaced with new ones everey 2 or so weeks. It became exhausting to keep up, so I tapped out.Over the years, I saw Overwatch going in decline. Player numbers dropping. Allegations against Activision-Blizzard. Overwatch League dying - this one particularly stung, as I knew a friend of mine who was actually part of OWL and he basically lost a career out of it - and Overwatch being left in a vegetative state. All for Overwatch 2.Come announcement of Overwatch 2. I'm sure you know by know. Overwatch 2 was originally meant to be a single player campaign game, where Overwatch 1 would be, well, Overwatch's PvP. Content from OW2 would get ported back to OW1, and the two games would co-exist.The idea was:- OW1 for PvP- OW2 for PvE campaign stuffThis never happened. Instead, Overwatch 1 was effectively killed off and replaced by Overwatch 2. PvP, now instead of 6v6 is 5v5, much like CS:GO & Valorant. Loot boxes have been removed, which, at first glance - awesome! Loot boxes are a tumor in modern gaming, regardless of what company is doing it - be it Blizzard, EA, Valve - I viewed it as a positive that Blizzard was removing the loot box system, and thought they'd replace it with something better, like what Valve did for Dota 2.Nope. Battle Pass. Two versions of it. Basic one, which gives you ♥♥♥♥-all, and a Premium one, which even has stuff like outright brand new characters. Ones that players who do not pay for it - DO NOT GET TO PLAY AS. One of the core selling points of the original Overwatch is that you buy it, and all future content - maps, events, characters - are FREE. Overwatch 2 ditches this by going free-to-play and opting for a Battle Pass system.There are other things that drove me away from Overwatch in 2018 as well - role queues in particular just made it feel unwelcoming to play. But what drives me away from revisiting Overwatch with OW2 is the monetization model, the convoluted leveling system which feels like they're trying to reinvent the wheel for no reason, and many issues from Overwatch 1 not being addressed.Ironically enough, I've fallen back in love with Team Fortress 2 since then. And that's probably the game I'm going to continue playing, even 11 years later. I don't see myself having the same attention span for Overwatch 2.What a shame, really.

Author: CornGolden
Review Content: It still feels so weird seeing this game on here.Personally I don't hate Overwatch. I've been a TF2 fanboy since 2010. When OW1 was released I celebrated its innovations in the realm of team based shooters, and what ideas it could give a game like TF2 in the future. Wasn't a fan of its lootboxes, and relatively sweaty community, but from what I saw the game looked fun and its community was strong and loyal to it like TF2s (I will admit tho OW beats TF2 in its porn by a landslide). Unfortunately, its unnecessary sequel, OW2, Is a game I can't give much praise to.This game:- Features a battlepass that locks new heroes behind a massive grindfest. If you want them immediately you gotta cough up around $10 for them.- An item shop with outrageously overpriced items. A lot of which are around $15-$20. As much as I personally love D.Va (my fav pornstar) I aint shoveling out $10-$15 to play as  her in a cop outfit, or a school uniform.- Different types of in-game currencies. There's your premium currency "Overwatch Coins" that require real money to get (not obtainable via battlepass btw), and your lesser currency "Legacy Credits" obtained either from the battlepass or from leftover credits carried over from the old Overwatch. Premium gets you fancy looking skins while lesser gets you reskins of the base skins for each hero.- On the topic of Overwatch Coins not being obtainable via the battlepass why can't OW2 grant you premium currency through it??? Other games with battlepasses (Fortnite, Apex, Warzone) grant you around 1500 of whatever their premium currency is as you progress through their BPs. Hell if you save those, their even enough to get you the next BP without having to spend more money for currency for another BP- Makes you miss lootboxes as a microtransaction mechanic. A sentence I never thought I'd ever say along with "Overwatch is now on Steam."-A PvE (THE WHOLE REASON WHY OW2 EXISTS IN THE FIRST PLACE) that was cancelled in May, then resurrected as this $15 paywall per story mission campaign?!?!?- On top of all this, OW2 is a game "developed" by Blizzard. The same company that is currently trying to implement another unnecessary BP in Diablo IV, and had one of the most predatory microtransaction systems with Diablo Immoral last year. On the upside, I can now play this game without needing to use the god awful battle.net launcher (thanks Microsoft! Once Warzone Caldera shuts down I can uninstall that ♥♥♥♥♥♥ software at last!). Plus I can run it on my steam deck now without having to do a bunch of tedious steps to get the game to not crash like before (recommend Proton Experimental for this or your controls wont work after you die once)Do I recommend you play this? Sure. It's fun, but VERY flawedDo I recommend you spend any money on this? ♥♥♥♥ no. Don't encourage Blizzard to do ♥♥♥♥ like this in the future. Save your money, and spend it on a better game that deserves your money like Baldurs Gate 3 or Elden RingIs OW2 porn better than the game? Yes! Yes! Yes! Yes! Y E S!!!At least the porn doesn't ask you to empty your wallet left and right.Overwatch 2 and Blizzard: they ♥♥♥♥ you harder than all the generic 3D dudes that porked down Tracer, D.Va, Widowmaker, and Mercy COMBINED!

Author: Nagato Komado
Review Content: I used to love Overwatch, and in a way, I still do. However, Blizzard decided to turn Overwatch 2 into yet another soulless free-to-play game with a battle pass, microtransactions at exorbitant prices, and, of course, the removal of free lootboxes. This forces people to grind their way through the battle pass levels to earn some of those legacy coins. Not to mention the removal of key features from OW1, only to be re-added (some of them) later in OW2.And worst of all, they removed the PVE game mode. Like, what the heck? Cancel the only reason this sequel had the "2" in its name? They knew they'd never finish the PVE mode when it was released in October last year, yet they hid this from the public for half a year. Some people actually bought their skins, believing it would help further the development of the PVE mode. Instead, we get this wasted potential of a story mission, WHICH COSTS 15$. THEY'RE NOT EVEN GIVING IT FOR FREE. We could've had a full game with multiple story missions, skill trees, hero levels, and much more.Overwatch 1 died for absolutely nothing. Blizzard only killed it so they could rebrand it "as something new," but in reality, it's just the same game with a lot more microtransactions.

Author: Underdrill
Review Content: Like many of you reading these reviews, I was once a huge fan of Overwatch. I had the Origins Edition preorder and was there at midnight on release day, loading into Hanamura and signing away my gaming life for the next year at minimum. From the incredibly fun cast of characters, to the great map design, to the instantly iconic music and sound design, to the consistently rewarding (albeit somewhat controversial) progression system, it quickly became one of my favourite multiplayer games ever made. If it was released on Steam in 2016, it would easily be in the top 5 most played games on my account. I eventually moved on as I grew tired of the competitive grind, but became super excited to return with the announcement of the sequel offering substantial PvE content.And then the sequel finally dropped last year…and they dropped the ball with it. Jeff Kaplan clearly jumped ship for a reason.The promised story campaign, endlessly replayable PvE missions, and talent trees for each character, were all pretty much cancelled in their entirety, with the community informed far too late in the process. The single main reason for this game having a 2 slapped onto it in the first place will no longer come to fruition, so what’s the reason for it being called Overwatch 2? Outside of the new 5v5 standard, and the typical live-service hero, map and mode additions, the core of Overwatch is essentially the same as what was originally released all those years ago. I guess there is some PvE content in this invasion update, but the main part of it is locked behind a £13 paywall, and there’ll probably be more £13 segments of this campaign locked behind future paywalls. With so many incredible titles out there still to play, I cannot foresee myself dropping the cash to experience what is essentially a fraction of a campaign that games less than this cost of entry would provide in full and then some. Why would I spend money on this when I could buy incredible experiences like Skyrim, Doom Eternal, Papers Please, Disco Elysium and Mafia for far less?Outside of sports releases, Call of Duty and Ubisoft games, sequels to beloved titles usually come with substantial additions and advancements building on the foundation of that original entry. It is an insult to the legitimate sequels out there that this is still being referred to as a second entry in a franchise. The only substantial change I can see relates to how the game handles progression and monetization, and this is a straight-up downgrade from how it was handled in Overwatch 1. It has become yet another F2P live service where the most exciting content comes in a time-limited Battle Pass, where all items are unlocked in a linear fashion and require a substantial time investment to make the most of your purchase. This exhausting, creatively bankrupt trend is disintegrating the interest that many people have in modern AAA shooters, as it turns every game that has one from being a fun past time into essentially a secondary job. Blizzard even had the audacity to lock the latest heroes past the halfway point of the free battle pass track (changed to Unlock 1 if you pay up), meaning everyone will not have access to the full hero roster at all times, a truly fatal error in a game where a good portion of the strategy is based around hero synergy and effective counter-picks. All of this pains me to write, as the game still remains incredibly fun to play all these years later. The foundation of Overwatch is brilliant, even if not much has changed. But I just cannot excuse how shamefully Blizzard has handled this “sequel” to one of the most revered multiplayer shooters of the 2010s. I know it’s popular to refer to Overwatch as one of the many in the line of dead live service titles, but I don’t think it deserves that placement yet. Games have come back from far worse states than what Overwatch 2 is currently in. I hope Blizzard is having a serious chat behind the scenes, looking at the fan backlash received over the past few months, in particular with this Steam release, to see what needs to be done to make things right. They can only rely on the support of fans with a high sunk-cost fallacy and new players oblivious to the game’s previous greatness for so long.I’ll return to Overwatch to try out some of the seasonal modes I’ve missed, but outside of that, Blizzard won’t be getting a dime out of me, and not much time out of me until they at least make the PvE a competent experience, as was promised when Overwatch 2 was first announced. I hope that my perception towards this game will become more positive over time, but Blizzard has a lot of work to do to make that happen.

Author: JTodd
Review Content: Edited my review to put this quick summary at the top:Overwatch 2 is not a game without faults. I think a player should evaluate what's important to them and decide themselves if they like the game and wish to spend time with it, like anything else they do in their life. In my opinion, the actual gameplay in Overwatch 2 today is the most fun the franchise has been in a very long time. The game is free, and all Heroes and maps are playable without spending any money. If you are picking up the game today, know that the game is best experienced with friends.----Prefacing this by saying I, personally, never really cared about the PvE campaign. I was probably going to play it at some point, but what I mostly play the game for is the PvP, which I find very fun, so PvE not being rolled out the way it was promised has no impact on my opinion of the game we have today. It's very important to note that, for a very large number of people, the promises made were a make or break situation. I acknowledge that this is a legitimate reason to dislike the game. There is still a PvE campaign-ish thing in the game as of Season 6, it just simply is not what people expected. Final side note on this, the PvE was always planned and advertised as a paid experience, I am not sure how people ended up thinking it was going to be free.The handling of the professional Overwatch scene was very poor and also impacts a lot of people's opinion of the game. Overwatch can be a difficult game to watch, so combining that with bad management is unfortunate (but also has no bearing on the actual gameplay). I wish Blizzard had let the grassroots competitive scene grow naturally, instead of creating the mess of OWL.---I am a peak Masters player in standard competitive, so I have an OK idea of the game state, but I'm not a particularly amazing player, especially since I just play ranked occasionally now and squat in Gold and Platinum depending on role(washed up).-Overwatch is a fun and colorful hero shooter in an interesting futuristic universe with goofy likeable characters that allows for a lot of skill expression for people with different play styles and skill sets. Team fights are dynamic, chaotic, fun, and frequent - nearly constant. The average time-to-kill in this game is quite long compared to traditional shooters, which is my personal preference. Every role has significant impact on the outcome of the game, however, not every Hero has the capability to win the game on their own.I particularly like the amount of characters with high mobility options in the game, which is a deterrent for some people due to the increased emphasis on mechanical skill, I just find it fun! There are Heroes that don't require good aim and there are Heroes that don't require fast reflexes and keypresses. Most important, currently every Hero in the game is a viable option - despite what your teammates may say (But team play is still more important than Hero viability). There are mains for every hero in Top 500 in every region, which somewhat, imperfectly, proves my point.The transition to becoming a F2P Live Service game was a good move overall, in my opinion. The additional cash flow should incentivize more frequent updates and balance changes, and so far has done exactly that.The price point for skins is in line with other F2P games, which means they are quite expensive. The seasonal battlepasses have improved and are now about average, or slightly below, compared to other games in terms of content. There is a ton of filler that no one wants, but the large milestone premium rewards are pretty cool, which seems standard. For comparing, Fortnite still stands above most of the industry.A complaint I have with the new economy is that the seasonal battlepasses so far have not had currency in them to pay for future battlepasses, which is a practice many games with passes have. Placing Heroes in the battlepass, also, was a move I, and many others, did not like. Note, they are on the free pass, rather than the paid pass, and all of the Heroes are available through free missions after their debut season has passed.There are weekly quests for battlepass experience that also have a premium currency reward for their completion, but the amount you earn is so minuscule it might as well not be there. What is most important about the change to a F2P environment, is that every map and every Hero is available to a brand new player without spending any money whatsoever.To extend on this thought though, I think that with how this game is played, all Heroes should be immediately unlocked for all players after their onboarding because of the importance of Hero-swapping. A player starting the game today is at a legitimate disadvantage because of their limited Hero pool, until they finish unlocking them all. If the game were even more MOBA-like and did not have Hero swapping (like Paladins) then this system could be slightly more acceptable. As it stands, in my opinion, this is the biggest reason to not pick up the game if you don't plan to play long term. It is not P2W, but it certainly is not a direction I like, despite it not affecting me personally.The online community for this game, both inside of the game and out of it, is like every other online game - extremely toxic. There are bubbles of pleasant and nice people, but you usually have to seek them out. I met my closest IRL friends in a random match of this game, so I know there are nice people who play the game. My recommendation, unfortunately, unless you are high rank and playing Competitive, is to not join voice chat and disable text chat if you have a sensitive disposition. On the plus side, I report people constantly, and constantly receive notifications that the people I reported have been actioned on. Press the button liberally.-Other things about the game:The Workshop is a powerful tool that has a dedicated community of players and creators keeping it fun and interesting. There are tons of fan-created modes and tons of people playing.The Arcade is quite fun and silly (depending on rotation), but is unfortunately not incredibly popular. Sometimes, a particularly fun mode rolls through and has extremely fast queues. Mystery Heroes and Deathmatch are other alternative ways to play the game, which I find relaxing, especially compared to Competitive. Ever since Blizzard nerfed Tanks in non-role-lock queues, these modes have been much more enjoyable.The Achievement system in this game is a particular soft spot for me. I am a completionist and love achievement hunting. This game is actually quite good for people like me. A downside, is many achievements are only available during specific seasonal events, so you may have to wait a long time for them if you are starting today. Tangentially related, there are Co-op event modes with scoring and leaderboards that are really fun to optimize with friends.Competitive is the central (but not most popular) mode in the game. In my opinion, there is not enough incentive to try to climb the ranked ladder, unless you are aiming to go pro. I own many golden guns, and what I gain out of Competitive is just more golden guns. Needs improvement. The temporary Competitive modes that Blizzard comes up with (like Mystery Heroes and Lúcioball) are always super fun to me, but have very long queues due to being unpopular.Last thing I can think of is Co-op Vs AI matches. I have no experience here, but, like in LoL, apparently the mode is quite popular. Could be a nice alternative if playing against people is stressful.--Conclusion: There is definitely good and bad that you need to weigh yourself. For me, I really like this game, I find it very fun, so I will continue to play. My opinion, whether you're new or experienced, is the best way to enjoy this game, coming from a former competitive-only player, is grab a beer, get a group of friends together, queue Quick Play/Arcade/Workshop, and just goof around.

Author: [unassigned]
Review Content: Let's get this out of the way first: I negatively reviewed Overwatch 2 and I also negatively reviewed TF2. I have no dog in that fight, I think TF2 is a cesspit of racists, hackers, and bots, and though I once enjoyed my time on it, I got tired of games lasting hours and then getting decimated by something like a c@ bot.But people also have every right to hate Overwatch 2, especially if they (like me) used to play Overwatch 1. Most games when they get a sequel continue to exist even after that sequel is released. Not so with Overwatch 2. It completely overwrote Overwatch, so none of us who paid for the game get to play it any more, instead we got Overwatch 2. Allow me to explain a few reasons why this screwed us over:Team SizesDespite looking really no different, and functioning basically the same (minus a few character changes), the fact that they dropped teams from 6 to 5 massively changed how it played in practice. One tank meant a single player underperforming as a tank crippled the entire team. Before, the other tank could pick up the slack, but not now. Especially now they have so many "DPS" tanks, there's too many occasions where you or your opponent desperately need a shield to even the odds but the lone tank won't comply.Not to mention is made fights much quicker. The tank can't defend everyone, so if the enemy wipes the healers with a flank while the tank's struggling to cover the front, it's pretty much over for that fight. Before, you could have a dedicated tank for your heals or damaage and another to hold the frontline, so fights took longer and required more skill and strategy to separate the team.SkinsNow, I'm not part of the zoomer generation that thinks it's acceptable to pay for skins (and I don't begrudge you thinking that, it's all about what you're used to and if that's what you're used to then it's not your fault, I just don't have the same view). I grew up playing games where skins were something you modded yourself and were as varied as you liked, with entire communities dedicated to making interesting designs. The idea of having to pay for them, or even buying from other players (while a company takes a percentage of it as well) is insane to me. So I NEVER buy skins.Blizzard didn't like that from people like me. In Overwatch, you used to be able to earn skins in-game just through playing, and they were viable enough that I'd collected maybe 60 or 70% of them before Overwatch closed. But in Overwatch 2, that's dead and gone. There was a running joke among players that after a few months, it would finally be getting to the point where those of us who were grinding every day and every week would finally have enough in-game currency to buy ONE skin. That massive nerf to earning skins meant Blizzard was intentionally forcing people to pay real money (£10+) for a clothing change.It's pure greed from Blizzard, and probably the main reason they stole Overwatch from us, to try to funnel everyone into the new game for more attempts as selling pixels to us. And it works, I regularly see people saying they're saving up to buy the new skin. I've seen my own younger family members buying things like virtual currency for Roblox and other such nonsense, so it's just the way things are now, but when it impacts what we've already paid for then there's an issue.CharactersInitially, the changes they made to characters wasn't particularly useful. Orisa losing a shield to become a more DPS-oriented tank still bugs me, and Doomfist going from DPS to DPS-oriented tank was also a massive mistake. But they were just symptoms of later issues.The new characters they've made have mostly followed this sort of pattern, where they might be a tank or a healer, but ultimately they've been designed to be doing more damage again. Which leads to the inevitable result of players neglecting their primary role to focus entirely on the damage aspect which Blizzard gave them, pushing the entire game further into these rapid, chaotic, ADHD battles all the time.And why do they have to keep pushing the overly progressive nonsense? Why does what a character apparently does in the privacy of their bedroom matter in an FPS that's primarily aimed at kids? There's no need to go "oh btw this one's not straight!!1!", as if it matters at all in that context. The more you draw attention to it as being weird in your eyes, the more it makes people feel uncomfortable.MapsWe lost a few maps that some disliked because of the game mode (assault maps), but I personally enjoyed. Hanamura, for example, was one of my favourite maps. I liked Horizon Lunar Colony. I get that others didn't, but to remove them from the list entirely was irritating. Why they couldn't do a TF2 style "select which maps you want to queue for" system, I have no idea.The new ones were even worse. Any of the "push the robot" maps are awful, taking way too long for an obvious outcome solely because the spawn proximity to the end is what's stopping the game ending in many cases. The back and forth of it is also extremely boring, having to fight your way slowly all the way up only to have to do it again and again because you're taking it in turns to wipe each other.But then it got so much worse. These new Flashpoint maps are insanely bad. You now have to capture not 1, not 2, but 3 points to win. I've seen matches where the teams are so even that you both end up double 99% on every damn point, and it took 5 whole points before the game ended, meaning you're fighting the equivalent of 10 dominant games for a single win, 2.5 times the length of a usual king of the hill match.Story modeI never had any hope for this. I didn't play Overwatch for it, and I knew they'd be bad even if they did turn up. You can get better content from Custom games, as is common for most multiplayer games. It was never going to be something as in-depth as maybe a Call of Duty story mode, for example.But it really has been an insult to those who have been waiting for it. We already had a taste of what was to come with those special event maps and game-modes, usually at Halloween with the Junkenstein stuff, it's always just players fighting NPCs like pretty much any other usual multiplayer map against people. In fact, the current new one is just a copy of the previous King's Row Uprising game mode from Overwatch. That's all that got given to people who (perhaps naively) thought they'd get something of worth.Blizzard is selling these multiple times as season passes, for a game that a lot of us had already bought once before. They're asking for regularly payments at the level of a brand new game for effectively cosmetic trash and recycled or bland content. To me, it feels like disrespect to their players.Ultimately, I used this thread to vent, but also to make an important point for a lot of the flamers drawn out in defence of this game: don't let your ego get tied up in something that's not connected to you. When people hate a game, they can hate it without knowing you even exist. It's not a personal attack against you specifically. In fact, you can let people hate a game and the company that makes it without it having anything to do with you. Focus instead on what you enjoy about the game instead of trying to tear other people down for their opinions. I'm glad you can enjoy Overwatch 2, but do bear in mind that there's a lot of people who unfortunately can't do that, so instead of reacting with hostility to them, maybe empathise with how they might be feeling.

Author: Lil San
Review Content: cake recipeif you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding cake recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients150ml sunflower oil, plus extra for the tin175g self-raising flour2 tbsp cocoa powder1 tsp bicarbonate of soda150g caster sugar2 tbsp golden syrup2 large eggs, lightly beaten150ml semi-skimmed milkFor the icing100g unsalted butter225g icing sugar40g cocoa powder2½ tbsp milk (a little more if needed)MethodSTEP 1Heat the oven to 180C/160C fan/gas 4. Oil and line the base of two 18cm sandwich tins. Sieve the flour, cocoa powder and bicarbonate of soda into a bowl. Add the caster sugar and mix well.STEP 2Make a well in the centre and add the golden syrup, eggs, sunflower oil and milk. Beat well with an electric whisk until smooth.STEP 3Pour the mixture into the two tins and bake for 25-30 mins until risen and firm to the touch. Remove from oven, leave to cool for 10 mins before turning out onto a cooling rack.STEP 4To make the icing, beat the unsalted butter in a bowl until soft. Gradually sieve and beat in the icing sugar and cocoa powder, then add enough of the milk to make the icing fluffy and spreadable.STEP 5Sandwich the two cakes together with the butter icing and cover the sides and the top of the cake with more icing.

Author: Mahogany
Review Content: I used to like Overwatch, a lot. I bought it on launch week, and played hundreds of hoursIt's no longer recognizable. With updates over the years, the development team has systemically destroyed everything I like about the game. Every character I liked playing, reworked totally. Goofy stuff like stacking heroes, gone. Even in casual modes. Further shrinking of the already small team sizes to 5v5. The developers seem to take the game more seriously than it has any right to be. Even the lootboxes, already my largest complaint about the first game, replaced by an even more predatory monetization model. I wish I could go back and play Overwatch 1. But you can't anymore. Overwatch 2 has replaced Overwatch 1 - the existence of Overwatch 2 is a net negative, and it would have been better if it never happened. This game has no reason to exist, and I'll never get to play the game I loved ever again.This is to say nothing about the horrific abuse taking place at Activision Blizzard. Burn the company to the ground.

Author: Ｙ Ｅ Ｅ Ｔ
Review Content: If your main selling point of Overwatch 2 was a PvE mode with a lot of progression, but you end up canceling it just to add a lesser version of said PvE mode, that is locked behind a paywall, you deserve all the negative reviews you can get, even if that means that Blizzard is not likely to put their other games, like World of Warcraft, the Starcraft franchise and Heathrstone, on Steam which would be a shame.But, I'm glad that I don't have to launch battlenet when I play Overwatch 2 via Steam - EA & Ubisoft could learn something from that!Speaking of Ubisoft learning from another company, Blizzard managed to add Steam achievements to their game - something that Ubisoft is too stupid to manage after slowly putting their games back on Steam.Porn carried Overwatch 1 when the content dried up and porn is going to carry Overwatch 2 as well because the artists care more about the game than the actual devs (except for the art-team, they rock). Overwatch 2 looks better than Overwatch 1, so there is that too I guess.I've played Overwatch 1 and some Overwatch 2 over on bnet - it's probably still a somewhat decent game but the almost predatory microtransactions are worse than the lootboxes in Overwatch 1; yes it's free 2 play, yes the devs need to earn money to keep the game going but please be more creative than a battlepass (that used to not give you back any premium currency for the first two seasons!), locking new heroes behind a paywall and underwhelming PvE missions that leave a sour taste in your mouth when you think about what it could have been.But hey, Bobby needs a new yacht so more microtransactions are expected to pop up soon!

Author: Starliqht
Review Content: AHAHAHAHA I HAVE WAITED FOR THIS EXACT MOMENT. I WAITED ALMOST MY ENTIRE OW LIFE FOR THIS GAME FOR THIS TO BE ON STEAM AND NOW THAT IT IS, I CAN FINALLY LET THE WORLD KNOW HOW I FEEL ABOUT THIS GAME. IT SUX SUX SUX AND IT MAKES MY BRAIN GO AHHHHHHHHHLet me explain, I played this game around 2017 when the game was "good". I recently came from Minecraft when I felt that the game that I loved wasn't the game that I initially fell in love with (Déjà vu) and I immdiately fell in love. Great game at the time, fun times and memories yada yada yada you get the picture. Genji main who stuck in low ranks, wanting to be the very best after seeing a certain Genji youtuber (you know the one) slices and ults the entire team. Thankfully that dream died a long time ago along with a box of other broken dreams but still, having fun playing a training mode for Exp and fun (I paid my $60) & eventually meeting some good friends. I instead found a new goal of wanting to work at my profile and wanting the max border possible but you don't want to hear about it. What made me change my mind? The sheer obvious balance changes that the community couldn't agree on. New chars (Doomfist was the first added hero they added when I played) while I don't personally hate them, all genuinely have a problem. Moira is a great example. My friend who optimizes Moira (shoutout to T.C.) explained to me one day why Moira is a throw pick technically around higher ranks because she doesn't have any utility other than damage or heal while Ana has sleep, nade, and boost Mercy, has rez, etc but at lower ranks, can easily dominate because people don't know how to counter her. It amazes me how rushed and unrefined most of these heroes are, but they just care about the OWL... as yes the OWL... The Overwatch League is a league where Blizzard tried so hard to make a success. A league filled with people who don't have an idea how to run a proper league. I will say, when the OWL was on Twitch, everything was so simple. Moving to YouTube and having to watch with your bnet or watching now with a YouTube account specifically linked to your bnet and you can't have a business Google account and have to have a specific Google account makes it complicated to watch and earn points, I would rather buy a skin that I like (if I wanted too, not that I have any skins that I like that I don't own). I never really had any desire to watch people better than me compete for something because...Well, I stopped caring. There are plenty of videos of sweaty men in one room focusing on hard work, showing teamwork, and being rewarded when they finish I have seen in my days *ahem* The part that I don't enjoy is the fact that Blizzard seemed to have forgotten the 98% of the player base with content, and of course balancing... Anyone can tell you that GOATS was the most annoying team to face, and if you didn't mirror it, you'd get rolled over. The devs who had no clue how to balance this just kept buffing DPS and nerfing the Tanks affected but it was still there. No matter how hard Blizzard tried to nerf (in once in a blue moon), the meta was still there and the only option was for them to add Role Q.Role queue was in my opinion one of, if not the least most controversial update. Some people liked it because you HAD to play with Tanks and healers, no more than 6 DPS (sad), and some people hated it because dps queue times. I hate it with a burning passion because of how streamlined the game is. Let me rephrase, the way they implemented it is the way I hated it. I could have possibly gotten used to it, but they just added it as a last-ditch effort to make the game watchable for the OWL. They could have reworked some DPS into tanks and support, and balanced some heroes that obviously could have benefited from it, but no. So much for creativity! It also made Comp too more annoying if someone who cares about getting the maximum comp points in a game has to play a role they aren't comfortable and you're at a disadvantage. Another thing is splitting the ranks into individual roles, at least the way they implemented it was horrible also because you can have someone Top 500 in their main role, and Bronze in the other 2 roles as a joke (nice one). After so many seasons of the same thing, there is no purpose to playing comp or keeping grinding once you've done it all. I mean sure you can aim for the leaderboard, & have a cool spray and icon, but... after that, what's the point? There is no reward or motivation for someone to keep playing comp other than lackluster rewards and some comp points, but nothing meaningful. Despite all of this, what kept me going and playing during these dark and troubled times was leveling my border and aiming for that max diamond border because, to me, that felt like an accomplishment. Finally aiming for something you've been working hard. I didn't care about Sr or glory/fame from smarter people, I cared about leveling my border so that people in the game can go, "WOW this person played a lot, they're so dedicated" or "I hate facing you, you're the final boss of OW" and after even hitting my goal I wasn't done yet. During that time when there was NO CONTENT after 2020 and NOTHING TO DO, I started to hate the stale of it, waking up every day playing a dull game that but despite all of this, I was still under the impression that when OW2 would come out, the borders would continue and that I leveled 600..no 1,200 levels(totaling my time to 6k hours today) after 3001 thinking that there would be some cool border. Even though that early on, they announced borders would be gone that I would still be awarded for my work. I had every obtainable loot boxed skin with an extra 300k ow credits saved up thinking that I would use these for OW2. I was filled with hope and determination that Ow 2 would bring my love back for this game. Yeah, that was a lie and it was all for nothing :) Ow 2 was prob the worst thing that Blizzard has ever done with this game and I even miss the GOAT era days, heck I miss the no-content days bc that was more fun than the horrible shell of a game that exists today. My skin collection will never be complete now because I am 2 poor to afford these horrible excuses for a skin price, and since FOMO is a tactic, will prob never appear again (unless in the shop in 2099). My border which I worked so hard for, was reduced to only being seen in your career profile with no way to progress it, replaced by some horrible Battle pass grinding which itself is also stupid & frustrating to grind. I used to look forward to recycled events and look forward to doing my chores of "winning 9 games for an epic skin", but now, I don't even care. Everything that I've cared for is gone for the sake of "convenience". The little things like I can't type when loading or bugs that should not have been a thing day 1 (on fire being not there until recently) should not have been a thing. But the shop magically always works! This new hero progression is not the same thing as Borders it's in my opinion a lot worst because the "reason" Borders were gone was "players of high level were being bullied for playing too much and being in x rank" or something like that when I think hero progression is going to do the same thing, if not worst, especially with an off-meta character, and of course how could I forget the broken promise of PVE :) Unfortunately, every time I load up this game, the song of Viva la Vida and a wave of depression would hit me making me question my purpose in life and make me suffer a midlife crisis. Every time I genuinely play the game, I suffer the 6 stages of grief while in queue and in the hero selection screen.TLDR: Sop Story don't try this game. I wouldn't recommend this game to my worst enemy, although they probably still love this game like the mindless drone they are lel.

Author: Zeptimus
Review Content: Wow, the audacity of Blizzard to bring this game to steam.They really must be getting desperate for mone- ermh, I mean, players.For those that are completely unaware, the short summary of what has happened, excluding all the other Blizzard scandals and flops, is that the original Overwatch was put on life support after they announced that OW2 was coming, with the main focus being PvE for the sequel. Fast forward, they finally released OW2, except there was no promised PvE and it was just Overwatch 1 with cut features, a balance update, a paid battle pass and pretty much removing the ability to earn skins by playing.  They basically took away the product that people had paid for previously and filled it with a cash shop. They did also show a roadmap that hinted that the PvE will be coming after a few seasons. Okay that's not the worst, right? Give players the updated PvP early to build hype for PvE that's coming soon. Well, they didn't hold up to their release date promises and delayed the PvE further with no confirmed released date. The community was left in the dark and let down yet again. Now in recent months they came forward and said that they're giving up on the original promises of vastly replayable PvE mode with a progression and customization system and will instead release story missions spread out, bit by bit. Missions that most likely are glorified versions of PvE event missions from the original Overwatch, which are no longer available due to the release of OW2. They even dared to say that they're doing all of this to focus on what "players really want", which apparently is ongoing support for PvP.So they want you to pay money for butchered PvE that will probably take a bit over an hour to finish.  I don't think I'll go on more about all the other little details that have happened during the lifespan of OW2, but let's just say that the balancing team is still incompetent and the game now has a predatory monetization system.The recent Diablo 4 release was also terrible, clearly all of their talent has left the company long ago. I've also heard that WoW and Hearthstone are having increasing monetization features.So in summary, Activision Blizzard is probably the scummiest gaming company and it doesn't deserve your money or leeway from criticism. Overwatch being a victim of their greed and now just a shadow of it's former self.Bobby Kotick is probably going to cry into his dollar bills about how he is the victim again and that everyone else is wrong.

Author: м
Review Content: I hadn't played Overwatch before and when I saw it here on Steam, I wanted to give it a try.Well, I can't really say anything about the game related drama going on, don't really care either, but what I can say is that I'm already bored after just 10 hours.It's not completely bad, but it feels out of time.Graphics remind me a bit of Borderlands. That was a great game, but we got 2023, so a game shouldn't look like it came straight from a dated mobile phone.Animations look pretty poor as well.The menus also remind me of some low budget mobile games. Bling everywhere and most of the stuff is hidden behind a paywall.There are different gamemodes and a lot of different maps, but I only really liked 2 or 3, the rest feld generic and boring.I'd like to play some decent PVE modes like the MvM mode in TF2, but except for 1 map, that's also hidden behind a paywall.I bought the cheapest hero package to try some of them out, but tbh, to me it feels like at least 1/3 of the available heroes are essentially useless or underpowered compared to the other ones.In some game modes I also had problems finding other players. Sometimes you wait 2-4 minutes and nothing happens. For a "new" release that's a bad sign, and also makes me impatient enough to go to play  something else instead. For a short while it's okay, but I really don't understand why anyone would play this for dozens or even hundreds of hours. There are far better games available.  Overall, well it's F2P, so you can always see for yourself, but personally i think that this is a boring and generic, perhaps overhyped game from the past, that also looks like a game from the past.Poor animations and low quality graphics, mixed with paywalls everywhere. No thank you.

Author: Brotos
Review Content: SummaryRun like hellOverwatch 1 to Overwatch 2The main reasoning for Overwatch 1 being shutdown and Overwatch 2 replacing it was for its PVE and story content. For me personally, I don't care about this content. However, this was the pretense that Blizzard gave for shuttering the previous game. To no ones surprise, Blizzard simply relaunched Overwatch with battle passes and other money grubbing systems at the core of it. The CORE, which was the PVE and story, does not exist.All the Bad- Adding Battle Pass- Battle Pass has no currency rewards, and your'e unable to re-purchase the pass via playing for long hours (They are deviating from the standard way of the battlepass)- Deceptive Battle Pass Currency: They then added currency, after much complaint from the community. BUT they added a separate currency that can't be used for the battle pass anyways. ON TOP OF THAT: The currency you can use to buy the battle pass is GOLD. The currency they give you in the pass is supposed to be SILVER. However, in the battle pass, they color the silver one as gold to trick people into buying the battle pass.- Removed all loot boxes in exchange for in-game currency that does not match the value. Goodbye any seasonal or rare boxes!- New heroes that are locked behind obnoxious achievements. These are meant to force players to keep playing in order to pad Blizzard's abysmal player playtime stats.- Matchmaking is absolute garbage, expect a one-sided game, every game- Ranking system drops your ranks completely after each season and you have to win them all back. Because you have to start from the bottom, many newer or low ranked players are having to play top ranked players.- New skins that are paid for have no love behind them. They're absolute junk that have been pumped out quickly and not even worth the purchase.

Author: Sontron
Review Content: It’s a good thing that this game is getting review bombed. At first I thought it would kill it even more, but I soon realized that it is an outlet for community frustration and a true way we can voice our grievances in a way Blizzard can’t ignore. No, it most likely won’t incite change into Overwatch’s death snowball, but if it doesn’t then the reviews accurately reflect the attitude of a community that just wants their fun, engaging, somewhat balanced, and much less greedy game back more than anything. I believe I speak for most of the community when I say I would much rather revert back to the latest stage of OW1 than play this corporate wasteland of a game. So, Activision Blizzard. We’re not mad. We’re just disappointed.Sincerely with despair,Your real player base

Author: Raiden
Review Content: If y'all wanna know how to make the juiciest most delicious chicken breast, here's what you do. Take a tupperware container and put water and salt in it, take boneless skinless chicken breasts and put them into the water and let it soak at room temp for about an hour, that salt water will get absorbed into the chicken and season it inside and out. Once it's soaked long enough, take it out and season it however you like, at the time I just used Montreal steak seasoning. Put that in an air fryer at 400 degrees Fahrenheit for about 15-20 minutes, flipping once at the middle of the cook time. Pull that chicken out when it's done and your face will be absolutely soaked when you're done eating. In the same vein, if you want a super delicious steak, pull it out of the packaging and pat it dry with a paper towel and dust the outside of it with Kosher Salt. Put that steak back in the fridge and let it sit a couple hours, preferably overnight. Once you're done, let the steak sit on the counter so it can warm up a bit before cooking to help get a better crust, then preheat a cast iron to ripping hot, at least a 7 on most stoves (and turn off your smoke detector). Put a little bit of vegetable oil in your pan and put the steak down. Only cook a minute or so each side until you get the crust you like, then turn the heat down and cook til you get your desired doneness, I like a good medium myself. The way that overtime, the salt will draw the moisture from the steak, season it, and get reabsorbed into the meat leaves it with a flavor I have never tasted before in my life, and likely won't in any other context. Give these a try and comment how it went, if you improve on these, let me know what you did better

Author: K3W3L
Review Content: Kinda wild to be a part of gaming history playing Steam's newest worst-rated game. Apart from the gameplay (I will vigorously defend the 5v5 pivot and Push mode) it's sad to see the game sink to these depths. Godawful monetisation, new heroes stuck behind battle passes, battle pass implementation itself (no coins from battle pass tiers but just credits? How stingy can they get?) and the original promise with which OW2 was initially pitched - a full-fledged PvE mode which I was sorely looking forward to given my exhaustion with the PvP aspect - all but broken.If you're willing to overlook the negative aspects you'll have some fun for a while. The gameplay still feels great! It's an unbelievably fast FPS compared to almost everything else. It's just a shame that Activision Blizzard has completely sunk in the years since OW1's release, paralleling the downturn that would happen here.

Author: 月影流觞
Review Content: 作为一个热爱游戏的玩家，我不得不在这里表达我对《守望先锋2》这款游戏的严重失望和差评。这款游戏无疑是我在Steam平台上的一次最糟糕的购买体验，以下是我对这款游戏的详细批评：首先，游戏在技术方面存在严重问题。我在游玩过程中屡次遭遇了崩溃、卡顿和连接问题，这极大地影响了游戏的流畅性和可玩性。作为一款面向多人游戏的竞技射击，稳定的服务器和流畅的游戏体验是至关重要的，然而《守望先锋2》在这方面做得实在太差劲了。其次，游戏的内容匮乏令人失望。与其前作相比，《守望先锋2》几乎没有带来任何创新和突破，新英雄和地图的数量少得可怜，而且它们的设计也毫无亮点可言。这导致游戏很快就陷入了单调和乏味，没有足够的内容来吸引玩家长时间投入。另外，游戏的社区和玩家之间的互动几乎为零。开发者似乎对于玩家的反馈和建议置若罔闻，导致许多存在的问题得不到解决。这种缺乏沟通和互动的态度让玩家感到被忽视和冷落，进一步削弱了对游戏的兴趣和支持。总之，我对《守望先锋2》的差评无法用言语来表达我的失望和愤怒。这款游戏在技术问题、内容创新以及与玩家的互动方面表现极为糟糕，完全不值得花费时间和金钱。我诚挚地希望游戏开发方能够认真反思并采取As an avid gamer, I feel compelled to express my profound disappointment and utter disdain for Overwatch 2, a game that I had the misfortune of purchasing on the Steam platform. This game has undoubtedly provided me with one of the most abysmal gaming experiences on Steam, and I have outlined the extensive reasons for my negative critique below:First and foremost, the game suffers from severe technical issues. Throughout my gameplay sessions, I encountered a myriad of crashes, stutters, and connectivity problems that severely hindered the fluidity and overall playability of the game. For a multiplayer competitive shooter, stable servers and smooth gameplay are paramount, yet Overwatch 2 fails spectacularly in delivering on these fronts.Furthermore, the game's lackluster content is deeply disappointing. In comparison to its predecessor, Overwatch 2 brings virtually no innovation or advancement to the table. The meager number of new heroes and maps are utterly devoid of any notable design elements. This quickly results in the game becoming monotonous and tiresome, lacking the necessary content to engage players over an extended period.Additionally, the interaction between the game's community and its developers is practically non-existent. It appears that the developers have turned a blind eye to player feedback and suggestions, resulting in a plethora of lingering issues left unresolved. This dearth of communication and engagement leaves players feeling neglected and dismissed, further eroding any interest or support for the game.In summary, my scathing review of Overwatch 2 cannot adequately convey the depth of my disappointment and frustration. This game's abysmal performance in technical aspects, lack of content innovation, and absence of meaningful player interaction render it utterly unworthy of both time and money. I sincerely hope that the game's developers will earnestly reflect on these criticisms and take proactive steps to rectify the game's myriad shortcomings; otherwise, Overwatch 2 will forever remain a woeful footnote in my gaming history.

Author: Happy
Review Content: This review is only to tell you all that one day they will resurrect OW1 and re-release it as a paid Vanilla game (aka WoW). Do not give them money until then, because OW1 is leagues better than this mess will ever be.As of right now I have 2,309 hours played. As someone who has been with Blizzard since childhood and played most of their IP's, Overwatch was the one that I loved most. The heroes and the lore spoke to me, captured my imagination, and made me inspired by the beautiful world they created. Jeff was our canary in the mine - once he left it was a sign that the game I once loved so much was simply no more. As everyone else has stated, OW2 is a zombie parading around in the skin of a game that had so much potential, but due to catastrophic greed was twisted and mutilated to the point of being unrecognizable to those who have been with it from the start. On top of having no LFG system in a team-based game, charging money for story modes (which is a shell of the PvE experience that was promised so many years ago) is just one more slap in the face for those of us who still wanted to give OW2 a chance. Play for free, there's still a lot of fun that can be had, but do not give them any of your money.

Review Content: Used to be my favorite game because it had (and, quite honestly, still has) a very addictive gameplay loop. Those close-call matches used to be so exhilarating. There are so many unbalanced heroes (Hanzo, Bastion, Ramattra, Mei and some others are just horrible to have to play against).  It used to be so much fun to just jump into quick play, even if I was playing solo - now everyone is just mean to each other in the chat. Not sure if it will ever go back to what it was before, but I don't recommend playing it right now.

Author: raspy
Review Content: I can't in the right mind recommend anyone play or even try Overwatch 2.The sole reason that Blizzard released a second game and advertised the game around -- the PvE with progression systems to provide replay value -- was ultimately scrapped. Sure, they eventually released some missions, but it seems like it will be a pay-as-you-go system for missions likely of questionable quality given how the game has been handled so far. This left us with a poorly balanced husk of a game, released only to enforce a new monetization scheme that is so predatory and unfair to players' time that players ended up preferring the previous system of loot boxes.The claim that the new game brought a "new look" with a "new engine" are entirely false; Overwatch 1 was removed from BattleNET store to hide that Overwatch 2 is the exact same game, on the exact same engine; so much so that for multiple weeks after it's release, it was recognized by SEVERAL applications e.g. Windows Control Panel, NVidia GEForce Experience, and Discord as the exact same game as Overwatch 1. The inclusion of changing environmental settings within maps and claiming it's in any way new technology is laughable; Garry's Mod has had entities to change the position of the sun in the skybox, alongside sky and fog design, which would also dynamically change the maps' lighting -- since before Overwatch 1's original TEASER TRAILER RELEASED. A forum post of players asking how to use these dates back to February 2 of 2014 -- the teaser was November 7.Unlocking the shiny new heroes is locked behind a battle pass, deep enough in that it could take a couple weeks to unlock them. Alternatively cough up $10 and receive a single hero immediately. In the case of multiple heroes released such as Junker Queen, Sojourn, and Kiriko -- who have all been essential picks since their inception, topping pick rates in most elo ratings (especially higher) due to the versatility and power of their kit -- this means you either spend weeks lulling behind other players or choking up the $10 per character to be able to play the competitive mode viably.Even if you don't care for the competitive modes, the almost non-existent gameplay style gap between the competitive mode and all other gamemodes -- including any of the modes in Arcade -- results in all casual modes eventually becoming filled with players who want to play to win but are either unhappy with their performance in the competitive mode or want to avoid the stigma behind it, often making even casual play a toxic slog.There are no deeper mechanics to learn aside from aim and gamesense, which all first person shooters demand regardless. Even the most difficult heroes have kits that can easily be described in a couple sentences per ability maximum. The most intricate details possible are specific interactions between various abilities -- but those aren't mechanics to improve your skill upon, those are knowledge checks that are one-and-done, easily learnable and digestible within seconds.--Contrast this with FOUR similar games (2 FPS and 2 traditional MOBAs):FPS:Paladins:- Has deeper mechanics to tinker and learn with talents, card decks, and progressive item purchases within matches- Competitive mode doesn't allow players to swap character mid-match, making character picks more meaningful- Competitive mode also features a ban phase commonly found in literally all other competitively viable gamesTeam Fortress 2:- Has deeper mechanics to practice and master with blast jumping, surfing, and air strafing- Bustling community scene with a functional server browser and well-documented modding tools- Community-supported competitive scene is still alive and well to this dayTraditional MOBAs:- Items, progressive power increase, strategic downtime, macro play- Competitive and casual modes feature ban phases- Characters are locked past pick phaseDOTA 2:- All characters are free! Wow! Crazy!- Powerful items allow clever purchases to turn the tide of a bad game- Mostly unit-cast abilities and items makes effective ranges consistent to play around and more fair- Slow pace shifts focus more towards macro (gamesense and strategy) playLeague of Legends:- Massive roster supports a wide range of playstyles- Runes, summoner spells, items, and interactions all within grants tinkering power- Mostly missile-based abilities grants skill expression through the pushing of character limits- Fast pace shifts focus more towards micro (mechanics and execution) playAnd would you believe, all of these games are free too?Don't waste your disk space or time, Overwatch 2 doesn't respect it.

Author: Dubbz
Review Content: Sad. I have 500+ hours on OW1, but I can no longer enjoy that game because they forced everybody to play OW2. What are the differences between OW1 and 2? Other than the obligatory new characters and maps to keep a live service... alive... is a shop with overpriced skins. The monetization in this game is predatory. It is exactly like mobile app pricing, where you get very little for a ton of money. OW1 cost 60$, which would likely get you 3-4 skins in this game. If you spent 60$ in OW1, you could get toolboxes that would come with tons of skins and other items. Blizzard doesn't NEED toolboxes to monetize their game, but it needs to be worth it to the customer or NOBODY will want to buy them, and you just get bad press surrounding it. I understand people like toolboxes because they were free and easy to get, and I understand why Blizzard cant do that anymore. Nobody ever had a reason to buy them because you got so many just for playing. But the current price of skins is awful. The fact that new characters are locked behind a battle pass, OR require you to WIN 30+ games to unlock is absurd. If a player were to return, they would have to play a ton of games with old characters just to even try the new one. This prohibits new players from learning the new character, and thus they will struggle to fight against them. Apex has a much better system, where you can unlock character credits over time. That way you can play whoever you want, win with whoever you want, and stock them up for future updates. It would give players a sense of progression, while also rewarding people for playing more than others. The BIGGEST letdown is the news of the PVE. Easily. You can see from my profile I love doing the achievements in this game, and that includes the PVE missions. Even IF you're going to take away everything you promised, you couldn't even add extra goals for the leftovers of your PVE ideas. There is no achievements for doing it at harder levels, and there's no replay ability. I understand that you need to charge people for the PVE since this game is free, but it just isn't worth 15$. You can watch the cut scenes online which is arguably the best part, and that's free. Knowing blizzard, they will find a way to cease and desist users for posting them online eventually just to try and get people to buy it. I believe here's what happened. Blizzard is in the middle of scandals involving Hong Kong and it's hasty banning of pro players. The drama was bad press, so you released a trailer for OW2 to try and get people hyped in a game that hadn't received updates in years. Before we could even process the hype, Blizzard executives told developers the promises were too much, and it wasn't going to happen. Jeff left as a result, and upper management couldn't decide how to tell people it wasn't going to happen. So they promised and promised and promised, until eventually they had to tell everybody. Why did they take so long to tell people it was canceled? Because they didn't want to kill the game before it started, so they waited till the game was off the ground after the beta released to break the news. Last year in 2022, they release the game as a "beta", even though it was basically just a rushed version of OW 1.5. It was in "beta" for months, and absolutely none of the feedback was taken and used. People weren't happy about losing level portraits, people weren't happy about losing the "on fire" feature, and many others. None of this feedback was taken during the beta, and instead we were pushed towards a battle pass and a new skin shop. The battle pass is full of filler. This isn't new to anybody and I don't want to dwell on it. It takes way too much time to get all the rewards. As far as I understand, if you don't max out the battle pass you DON'T get all the rewards. This means you pay for it, and may not get to utilize all of it. Other games do this but it doesn't make it right. If I buy the battle pass, I should be able to keep it for future seasons and fill it out over time. I should NOT be motivated to play the game by fear of missing out. This game is not being respected by Bobby Kotick. He needs to go. These reviews are deserved. Give people the game you promised, or STOP making promises. This game is a perfect example of false advertising. For those of you looking for good a shooter, go play Apex legends. That game can be played completely free and you still get the most out of your experience. The team actually responds to people on twitter, and they take your feedback. They give you what they promise every time. There is nothing redeeming about this game. If you're brand new to Overwatch, it is nearly impossible to learn from scratch at this point anyway. Play something else. This series is going nowhere.

Author: Sunset, the Local Catgirl
Review Content: tldr: Paladins is better, if you're spending money, put it there so Hi-Rez sees the game is growing again and will allocate resources to its improvement. As it stands, Overwatch is digging the same grave it's been in since...well, forever.Overwatch 2 is...quite the tale. A game with fantastic promise, which would go on to be realized to a relatively small audience by a competing game, being slowly buried in its ever growing hole of problems by its developers and their higher-ups. And I feel the need to emphasize the "and" there. A lot of long-standing problems for this game, ones that predate any PvE announcements, are BALANCE ISSUES. TTK is really awkward in this game. Either you can't do any damage through the supports' healing, or you're either functionally or literally one-shotting opponents. No, there is not an in between in team fights. Also, DPS has no reason to exist in the game's current state, and we've seen this remain the case for years. Their damage is only slightly above the output of tanks and supports, and this has been the case since launch. Actually, it used to be even worse, before one of the first blanket non-answer solutions was implemented; a bunch of DPS buffs, then when it didn't work, the addition of Role Queue. Role Queue exists because the balance team couldn't be bothered to do their job, plain and simple.Prior to balance changes that affected the flow of the game at the launch of 2, gameplay could feel unimpactful as a lone player. Not as in "I can't 1v6 carry", but you'd encounter frequent situations where you were definitively having an impact, but it rarely FELT like you were. The answer to unsatisfying gameplay, and the answer to the metas in the second half of pre-2 Overwatch, was NOT to remove a tank. The entire role is designed around having two tanks, and we've seen what a fustercluck tank balance has been in 2. It's an absolute nightmare. Half of the tanks fundamentally don't work solo, and are either unplayable or broken at any given time. Oh, and the removal of a tank is another example of the balance team simply taking an easy way out instead of balancing the game people are already playing.Nearly every hero has at least one insanely frustrating element to them. Heroes feel like they're designed and balanced without ANY consideration for how being on the receiving end of their kits is going to impact the experience, and while of course that shouldn't be the primary factor, it shouldn't be a nonfactor either. Kiriko's Suzu is a band-aid solution to a host of balance oddities that needs to exist and yet shouldn't exist at the same time. Baptiste's Immortality Field is a literal ultimate on a relatively short cooldown, and one non-ultimate can swing a team fight around due to the quick TTK in this game. Sombra's invisibility and hack are an incredibly annoying combo to play against, paired witht he fact that a half decent one can just teleport away and never be punished. Widowmaker and Hanzo shouldn't be able to one-tap so many heroes, especially with Widow being a hitscan. I understand that the removal of their one-shots in the game's current state would likely kill them, but if they need to be unhealthy to be viable, then either they should be destroyed or the game should come down to a level they can work at. The game's not polished. Now, I do acknowledge that Paladins isn't either despite me saying it's a better alternative, but Paladins is made by a significantly smaller company. The quality of the game dropped significantly, with SEVERAL new bugs popping up at the release of 2 that can ruin the experience. Ultimates can be silent, your health bar can remain full after getting hit (causing you to believe you have more health than you do), and so on. This stuff has to be adressed, and unlike Paladins, Blizzard has no excuses.PvE. Sure, what we have gotten of it is fun so far, but it's a hollow shell of the game we were promised, that required killing Overwatch for such a long time to develop. It's probably worth the money, but not moreso than other games, and definitely not worth the time it took to arrive.Oh, and I did also forget when writing this review initially, but the skins in this game SUCK. There are a few decent ones, but other games with similar ideas of what "skins" are charge less for higher quality skins. $20 for a recolor is insane. $5 for a recolor is insane. The fact there are maybe 50 unique voice lines across EVERY skin is ridiculous with how expensive they are. No, silhouette recognition isn't the issue, nobody has that problem in Paladins, League, Smite, hell Siege lets you wear a PIZZA HAT or ply as RICK AND MORTY skins, and people know just fine who it is.

Author: Rarigon
Review Content: I have been playing Overwatch ever since the Beta came out. You know a game and company is a special kind of special when you make your fan base wish they had the old Overwatch and Loot Boxes back. Before i start listen well, all of the blame does not fall to the Developer Team im sure they played a role but they were absolutely forced by upper management, the share holders and executives to make these predatory changes to the micro-transations in the game today. Do not attack the Dev's.THE GOOD:Let me get into the good before the bad. Story and game play are amazing. the Developer team has limitless opportunities when it comes to the lore and story, being able to take the narrative in any direction. The addition of new Heroes is the driving force of this game. the game has that tight polish and uniqueness to it that you wont find anywhere else with Paladins being one of the only similar games to Overwatch. you will enjoy this game as long as you do not play Competitive or spend money really.THE BAD: Broken promises, greed, and rushing content out the door is absolutely putting this game in the ground. $20+ for a legendary skin a name card/ spray and a souvenir (which literally no one wants or uses) are you ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ joking?? The Battle Passes are horribly bad, locking new heroes behind them to entice you to pry open your wallet just so you can get a potentially key game play element that was free a few years ago. You can grind for the new hero and get it for free in the pass but your talking potentially hours and hours of grinding levels. The Battle Pass often has a ton of random items and skins to pad it out instead of actually including all the skins that are from the current event and sticking with a themed battle pass and Invasion is no different, the exact same formula. instead they try to sell you these select skins separately and push FOMO on you to get you to empty your wallet. Wouldnt be surprised if Blizzard put old Mythic Skins on sale for $40 or $50 later down the line. Probably the most insulting of all is the fact the now broken promises of PVE were scrapped now they are putting those said missions behind a pay wall for $15 for an hour's worth of gameplay and cutscenes. these missions are boring, base tier at best akin to the quality of the overwatch archives events years ago. Go watch the story and lore on youtube do not give Blizzard your money for these missions.I love this game i really do but i cannot recommend it at all in its current state and management. Its really fun especially with friends but if your gonna play, play for free.DO NOT. waste your money on this ♥♥♥♥, Blizzard management does not care all they want is your money.

Author: Onemuri
Review Content: Играю я в Овервотч с бета тестирования оного еще в 2016 году. И как человек, который прожил с этой игрой столько времени, я не могу порекомендовать игру в нынешем её состоянии одновременно вспоминая какой она была и во что её превратили. Я любила OW1 всем сердцем очень долго, убивалась по лору и персонажам, гриндила рейт, ждала и верила в развитие игры, смотрела киберспортивные события. Но увы OW1 был задушен отсуствием быстрого обновления меты и контента, и все ради обещаний разработки нового контента для OW2.В итоге OW2 вышел и ничего собственно не изменилось. Якобы игру перевели на новый движок, 6vs6 поменялось на 5vs5, добавили новый режим, и несколько карт, при этом полностью убрали 2cp карты и режим (то есть шило на мыло поменяли).Новый режим с толканием робота очень плох, каждый раз когда я на него попадаю, мне хочется удалить игру. Карты для этого режима тоже очень сомнительне, особенно Коллизей. Новые герои, которые выходят, либо выходят очень перебафаными (Кирико), либо абсолютно ненужными (Лайфвивер). Потом их очень долго пытаются довести до кондиции, как будто героев и баланс никто не тестирует во время разработки. Но самое плохое в OW2 это её монетизация. По факту у меня забрали OW1 под шумок мелких изменений (где хоть как-то можно было получать шапки поднимая уровень), врубили ф2п и вместе с ним просто абсолютно чудовищный донат. 20 долларов за пак с скином. 10 доллларов за батлпасс, где 80% конента ненужный мусор. Они отменили PvE составляющую игры, которую мы ждали ГОДЫ, чтобы разбить ее на несколько миссий, которые проходятся за полтора часа и продают их за 15 долларов. Самое смешное, что магазин забит скинами прошлых лет, которые я к счастью выбивала бесплатно, и теперь их продают в тридорога. И теперь если ты хочешь косметику, то либо покупай в магазине, либо покупай батлпасс, либо гринди вторую внутреигровую валюту (но ты не сможешь за нее купить некоторые скины). До 6 сезона в игре вообще отсуствовала какая-то прогрессия кроме циферок ранкеда (про циферки ранкеда вообще отдельная тема, насколько плохо сделана система и насколько она непонятна для обычного игрока). Было ощущение, что в этой игре день Сурка. А про то что разрабы вынули фичи типа "On fire", чтобы их потом вернуть с гордостью, ну просто смех. Я, конечно, не исключаю, что игроку новому, который не знал OW в его прайме, в целом игра норм, но если честно для себя я ее уже давно похоронила, с огромным сожалением.

Author: flatpancakesss
Review Content: I've been a long time fan of Overwatch since I bought it in October 2016, this "sequel" ruined my love of the game. Blizzard have turned a game that was once really fun and good into a predatory free-to-play live service game, not to mention the whole mess that is the PvE aspect of the game.Skins that were once available for free just buy playing the game are now sold at prices higher than I paid for the original game in 2016Implementation of the Battle Pass model turns the game into a grindfest where you have to play the game for many hours within a short time just to earn the cosmetics that you paid for, otherwise they're gone forever with no way to obtain themAs of the time I am writing this review, heroes are locked behind the Battle Pass forcing you to either pay for them or grind a lot of hours just to unlock them. This has a negative impact on the game as it hurts the fundamental design of Overwatch where counterpicking enemy heroes is a large aspect of the gameLastly, the entire situation with Overwatch 2's PvE is a story too long to be told within this Steam review, and I'm sure you know the story already. Well the PvE has finally released and its 15 US Dollars (I think? my currency is different) for only 3 missions that are roughly an hour and a half long in total. While the story itself is good and so are the cutscenes, this price is terrible for the amount of content you truly receive on purchase.For the price of the Battle Pass, PvE, Item Store skins or other cosmetics in this game, there are plenty of other wonderful games that you can find on Steam / other platforms for a a similar price. I highly recommend you check out some other games instead of this.
