Author: Kyxlect
Review Content: I have 485 hours in Overwatch 2 and received all of the achievements I earned from launching the game via steam. I have not played OW2 since Blizzard announced they were no longer going to deliver on the original vision promised to the community. This upgrade was the entire reason behind Overwatch 2's entire existence, however it's been made painfully clear that the only purpose behind the change was to turn Overwatch into a live service game with egregious amounts of monetization.The main issue with this is that in Blizzard fashion, they shut down the original Overwatch, which was a paid game, for this. Then somehow managed to make the worst and most greedy monetization system in the business. In Overwatch the only monetization was loot boxes and despite the fact that they contained a lot of worthless filler no one wanted, the system was at least generous by giving the player a loot box for just playing where you could also receive coins to buy whatever you really wanted if you got duplicates and despite how much everyone hated loot boxes, they hate this new system even more.In Overwatch 2, there's a battlepass with no earnable premium currency for both free and premium passes like every other game out there with a battlepass system. You can 'earn' a small sliver of the premium currency by playing the game and doing challenges but it's a fixed amount and again, very small, it would take months to unlock anything through that method. They do give you "Legacy Coins" which can be used to purchase cosmetics from Overwatch but no new ones. The amount you get is not really generous either and they raised the cost of cosmetics by an obscene amount. It is in no way shape or form a good deal to buy premium currency for these skins which cost $20 each so your only decent option to get cosmetics is via the battlepass but the problem there is you're just earning the exact same thing everyone else is. These cosmetics also seem to be Blizzards number one priority and some turn out horrendously ugly. They churn them out quickly for every new battlepass.There are three roles in the game: Tank, DPS, and Support.Most people play DPS, then Tank, then Support. Tanks are bullet sponges that do less damage as one would expect, Supports are a little too strong in my opinion and being that it's the least popular role, most of the people that do play Support focus more on getting kills like a DPS than healing because they wanted to play DPS and even though they're the only ones that can consistently heal others. DPS does feel a bit underwhelming, like they don't do as much damage as you'd expect and can be overwhelmed by Supports due to their own damage output and abilities, Tanks too obviously.Now onto the gameplay experience, it's mostly frustrating. Overwatch pretty much always has been about appealing to the more competitive playerbase and while the original development team dragged their feet when it came to balance, the new team is just unbelievably incompetent and have no idea what they're doing. That's coming from someone that derives enjoyment from playing to win so I myself have a competitive mindset. In Overwatch, my favorite characters were Mei and Sombra because they were the most fun characters to play. In Overwatch 2 they nerfed the most entertaining part of Mei and made her boring and they've already slated Sombra to be nerfed in the same way. But do they balance the character that in my opinion is the most broken one and has been since the original game, being Junkrat? Nope.Competitive mode is not enjoyable, if you're solo you'll likely be abused by your teammates who are in groups or squads and if you call them out for it they'll probably just straight up throw the whole game. Also due to squads existing, many players perform poorly because they're boosted from playing in a squad so they're not at the level for the Rank they're playing in and you can only have two in a squad in the higher Ranks. They don't like it if you play certain characters and they'll let you know, even if they have no idea how to play the character themselves. Very toxic. Some are likely to be smurfs as well. OW2 does have a league for esports but I believe they're going to be shutting it down, probably because it's not profitable enough and the company's surrounded by controversy.The new characters they introduce will likely be broken as in overpowered so the battlepass will sell more. Yes, new characters are locked behind the battlepass system. If you don't unlock the character before the battlepass ends you can 'earn' the character by completing some challenges.There are also events during holidays like Christmas, Halloween, Summer, Chinese new year, etc. but they do feel a bit underwhelming, the challenges take too long are not very fun to complete, the 'new' event gameplay is not fun to play and the rewards are usually lackluster. They do recycle old content as well, so if you didn't like it the first time, you get to not like it a second, and third time and so on. Halloween is usually my favorite time of year but after getting Junkenstein over and over, I never looked forward to it.I would not recommend this game. Blizzard is not the same company it used to be when it made good games. Now it's all about the money.

Author: shinobu
Review Content: The current state of the game is a shadow of its former self, marred by practices that do not favor the players.I have thousands of hours in Overwatch and reached GM in every role. Overwatch was my favorite game of all time, but in the past few years, things have taken a bad turn.Back in 2016, the game stood out to me with its fresh approach to the competitive shooter genre. My passion continued through my college years in 2018, where I even started to compete at the collegiate level. Though the balance was sometimes terrible (e.g., Goats, double shield, double sniper), I sensed a genuine effort and passion from the developers. However, with the announcement of Overwatch 2 and the PVE, my excitement was followed with skepticism - a skepticism that, unfortunately, has been justified.The core of this game has been eroded by corporate greed, poor management, and decisions attributed to Bobby Kotick. Now free to play, Activision Blizzard appears determined to capitalize on every facet of the game, from battle passes to $15 PVE "missions," reselling old skins, charging for heroes, eliminating free loot boxes, and even undermining the vitality of the Overwatch League.The current state of the game is a shadow of its former self, marred by practices that do not favor the players. I find myself unable to recommend Overwatch now or in the future, unless there is a monumental shift in Activision Blizzard's approach to become a company that values its community once again.

Author: ZAXSTARR
Review Content: First off, I probably have somewhere around 1000+ hours combined between PC and Xbox. The original Overwatch was probably one of the biggest highlights of my entire gaming career, and I've been playing games since the Sega Genesis. It was absolutely bleeding with style, character, and polish, and aside from some balancing missteps and bugs here and there, my friends and I had an absolute blast playing this game almost every night, for years.Then comes Overwatch 2. The "Promised Land" of sequels, meant to redefine what a sequel really was (in Blizzard's own words). The purpose of this game was to introduce a whole PVE aspect to Overwatch and breathe new life into the game. Blizzard promised "hundreds" of missions, with the ability to essentially specialize in one of the 30+ characters in the roster and level them up, making them more powerful, etc. It sounded great.What we got instead was a patch that, overnight, took away:-All aspects of account progression (they removed account levels and player borders)-The ability to earn anything for free-An entire mode and some maps for that mode-The "On Fire" feature that rewarded good plays -End-of-match cards that allowed for players to talk about the match and vote for players who did well-One player from both teams (making it a 5v5 game instead of 6v6)-Collection counts on the hero screen (likely so that you aren't able to see how little you're actually earning now)What we got in its place was:-A ridiculously expensive and predatory cash shop-A battle pass-An unfinished and uglier UI than Overwatch 1Keep in mind, this was a product that we PAID for.And that's about it. You see, the PVE mode (you know, the reason for the sequel) was canceled, but Blizzard decided to go ahead with the update and simply wreck the game in the name of making cash. 5 year old skins that were once obtainable completely for free just by playing the game, are now $20 in the shop. Speaking of the shop, the game pushes it on you constantly, trying to sell you $70 or $80 "deals" that have like 2 or 3 skins in them. Skins that, once again, you would've been able to obtain for free, before the patch, simply by playing.Technically, you can still get skins just by playing, but you will earn them at a rate of something like one every 6 months. If you play every single day. Fantastic. Keep in mind that this is a game where you can freely change heroes mid-match, counter-picking is key to winning, and there are 30+ heroes. $20 per skin, in a first-person game at that. You do the math. Recently, 3 PVE missions were released in a pack for $15. Combined, they offer around 1 hour of content. If you're thinking about buying it, do yourself a favor and shop around on steam for 5 minutes in the $15 range and tell me how many games offer you 1 hour of content (with 0 replay value) for that price.Among all of its IPs, Blizzard has continuously and relentlessly outdone itself with each passing month to show just how far the depths of its greed can go. The release of Overwatch 2 in the state it was in was the company essentially bat-signaling the middle finger into the sky to its entire current playerbase while hoping to attract as many people who are addicted to battle passes and susceptible to FOMO as possible. It's a cash grab. That's all it is. Avoid it, and don't waste your time.

Author: lucas
Review Content: Now, where to begin on this absolute trainwreck of a game? I guess a good place to begin would be the current ridiculous over monetization. Where Activision/Blizzard told us a couple years ago that revolutionary sweeping changes were coming to Overwatch, in fact these changes were supposed to be so severe  that they "couldn't do them without a sequel".  The impression that was given to the player was that there would be faster content release and a whole PVE game mode with stories and ways to level up your characters for those modes. Only one of those promises were half fulfilled, content is slightly faster to come out. Anything of any significance though is behind either a wall of legitimate YEARS of play time or 20 to 30 dollars. A lot of these new skins are either recolors of old skins that were made in the time of the first release of Overwatch, where you had the loot box system. The loot box system was set up in a way where you would get a free one for leveling up by playing, and during events there would be different challenges you could do to get them. Not to mention the weekly arcade challenge where you could get 3 free lootboxes. You could get ANYTHING in the game other than Overwatch league skins at that time. I remember lootboxes being controversial and labeled as "gambling" by some organizations and were actually investigated by some governments. The thing is though that in Overwatch 1 those lootboxes, you never had anything guaranteed ofc and on some occasion you may buy 20 dollars worth of lootboxes and you would get every skin for an event, this was hardly ever necessary though. If you played Overwatch 1 for half the amount of time that Overwatch 2 expects out of you to level their battlepasses full of garbage, then you could get every skin from an event. The current expectation is that you spend the price of a full game for a handful of skins or pay 10 dollars for the battlepass and play for a thousand hours while you unlock mainly garbage while you see things in the shop that are on theme of the battlepass that SHOULD be in the battlepass selling for 20 to 30 dollars. Not to mention the predatory manipulative slimy business practice that should be Illegal, where companies have these things in their shop that are "on sale" from release and make it appear like you are getting a bargain. When the truth is the price that it is at is what they intended in the first place, they just are trying to condition people to accept higher and higher prices for garbage. You look at some of the prices that these things are supposed to before  the "on sale" status is added to them and it is 90 dollars for 3 overwatch skins. Hmm should I pay for several whole games on steam or should I pay for 3 low effort possible recolor overwatch skins?  I think that should be a fairly easy question to answer. Why is it that the lootbox system in overwatch and in video games in general were seen as so controversial and ridiculous, but the whole "battlepass" system and locking every bit of significant content behind walls of the prices for full games is not? You could bring up the argument that at least with the battlepass and monetization of characters and skins you at least get exactly what you pay for, but I played overwatch 1 during that time I got nearly every skin and ofc I got to play every character from their release. These skins were on the same level of quality as these new skins and honestly can be argued to be even better in some cases. I spent  little to no money on this game (except for 60 dollars on release). I can only imagine what it must be like for new players, where all of those old skins are behind the battlepass leveling or 10 to 20 dollars. I would not play the game in that situation. I don't know how they expect anyone to see it as a good game to get into. Enough on the monetization though, now to the quality of the game itself. One of the few significant changes made in this "Sequel" was the change from 6v6 to 5v5, where there used to be 2 tanks 2 dps and 2 supports there is now 1 tank 2 dps and 2 supports. Now because of the "disadvantage" that tanks were given by the removal of a tank, they decided to buff tanks to a ridiculous level where they are the deciding factor each game. Tanks a lot of the times feel immortal and hitscan dps like widowmaker also feel even more oppressive. Because they took a tank out of the game and barely thought about it. New characters that are being released for the game either feel way too strong (Kiriko, Rammatra) or way too weak (lifeweaver), not to mention they made a transition from 6v6 to 5v5 with only minor changes, wildly enough it is not balanced when the same amount of healing is going out that was meant to heal a 6 person team is healing a 5 person team. There is also the fact that there is no Overwatch league anymore, so there is no competitive scene for it. The competitive system has also been ruined, you play games until you win 5 and then after that you get to see what you new rank is. Where in Overwatch 1  you would see your SR go up or down by numbers, other than when you were playing your placement matches that you could get a big increase of SR if you did well in. It was a lot more transparent and satisfying to watch your SR climb. Now it's like you are constantly playing placement matches, but the reward for doing well in them is a lot of times only a tier rank up from silver 4 to 3. I was playing on an old account and I played my 5 placement matches for the season, the game said I was considered silver 4. I played my placement matches for the season and I won 2 games lost 1 then won 3 I did well each game and had the most damage and eliminations most of the time. After playing those games I placed silver 4, the rank I was told I was at in the beginning. I played 5 more games and won all 5 of them in a row and did similarly to the way I did in my placement games. I was then taken from silver 4 to 3. I won 90% of the 10 games I played and my reward was a single skill tier up. Imagine if you played 10 valorant games and won 9 out of ten of them, or any game that has a reasonable competitive system. I should have gone a whole skill division up not a tier. I am not going to sit there and play that garbage game for several days not even in the right skill ranking, because not only is it not challenging for me. It is also ruining the game play experience of the people I am playing with and against. This game is dying and I think we will see the day the servers are shut down, sooner than later if they don't make massive changes to not only their business practices, but the way that they balance the game. I am hopeful and excited for the day I get to read that Overwatch's servers are shutting down. So do I recommend this game? Absolutely not.

Author: ★Sinon★ <3
Review Content:
So... About time that Blizzard decided to bring their games to Steam and oh boy. I want to let my frustration out.I played Overwatch for the first time in 2016 so since its launch and did quit the game around Season 10/April 2018 once Brigitte became available in ranked play. but I also played OW2 before in its first season Since then I kept on revisiting Overwatch once a year to see how the game was doing in hopes that Blizzard will learn from its mistakes and bring back OW to be a relevant game once more but that didn't happen.Overwatch 1 was doing very well from 2016 until 2018 that we kept getting real new content and constant balance changes to keep the game more fresh but also solve existing problems at the time like Mercy's Mass Rez ability that was loathed by the vast majority of the player base.Time passed on and it was clear that Overwatch was on life support with fewer hero releases and existing content being recycled like the Summer Games event for years. and at the end of its life cycle became full of cheaters as Blizzard's Warden anti-cheat solution wasn't being updated at all and was completely pointless to the point of making VAC to look like it is being actively developed.Game Balance was never the strongest thing for Blizzard. PvP World of Warcraft players of old were already accustomed to it but I will argue that OW during its first years wasn't too bad balance-wise and there was the sense that the developers were ready to listen and accept feedback to improve upon that aspect. Fast-forward to 2018 and we get Brigitte as a hard counter pick to the popular Dive meta by introducing a hero that is full of CC in a game that is based upon movement.While Blizzard did manage to shake the meta and introduce something new. it wasn't well received by the community at any capacity.


YouTube™ Video: The Character That Killed Overwatch 

			Views: 1,690,829		

			Brigitte was supposed to save Overwatch. The game was being dominated by a single meta, Dive, and every match was playing out the exact same way.		

Imagine creating a hero so broken that makes an entire role invalid due to the meta it created around the same character (GOATs) and at some point was the sole reason of why role queue was introduced into the game in the first place.And here comes Overwatch 2, Blizzard announced that OW2 was already in development since 2019 and the original idea of the newer title was to add the story mode and expend upon the universe of the game but also gameplay by introducing different systems from RPGs like talent trees and allow the player to experiment with different options and have a system that promotes progression.Fast forward to OW2's actual launch. the promised PvE component was completely missing and the game was far from being ready to go. worse matchmaking, less maps, removal of 2CP in general. even basic features like being "on-fire" was completely absent despite the voice lines still existing in the game and WERE LITERALLY TRIGGERED but no visual feedback at all.Fun fact, According to the financial reports by Activision-Blizzard themselves. they are fully aware that Overwatch 2 launched in an early access state.https://investor.activision.com/news-releases/news-release-details/activision-blizzard-announces-second-quarter-2022-financial"Overwatch 2 is planned to launch in early access on PC and console on October 4. With a free-to-play live service model designed to provide frequent and substantial seasonal updates, this launch kicks off the next chapter for the acclaimed team-based action game."Then we hit the final straw that made a large part of the Overwatch player base to quit for good and this was the cancellation of the PvE story mode and instead they did split the idea into "Story Missions" which are being sold for 15 euros for about 90 minutes of content at most without the talent tree or customization that has been showcased years prior.Blizzard as a company simply cannot be trusted and doesn't deserve . if you want to get into Overwatch 2 and expecting the game to do well in the future then I'm very sorry to tell you that you will be disappointed right away.Overwatch 2 is a downgrade with a completely disgusting monetization system that it makes people to miss loot boxes... compared to the original game that we all have fallen in love with in the past.I would advice potential players to stay away from this game and Blizzard games in general.

Author: Yugure
Review Content: Remember when Overwatch advertised itself as, "Don't play classes, play heroes!" Overwatch is, and has always been a cash cow made to appeal to escapists who just want an easy skill-ceiling based, flashy game, and to bad players who rage quit at tf2. The game has so many restrictions on skill curve development, and single player gameplay that it forces you to rely off being around your team; And since your abilities come back passively, and rapidly, making it more so ability reliant, then what reflex is there? TF2 is a semi reflex shooter sure, but even then its all about your movement control, and aim. Strong abilities take effort to charge; The few that're passive, Mad Milk/Gas Passer, don't instantly give you a powerful boost for a kill just cuz its ready. You can't even main a character without OW telling you to stop getting good at it.Overwatch doesn't complicate knowledge so all you have to do is press a button for easy rewards. Try teaching c-tapping to a Pharah main; Junkrat sticky jump dmg immunity go brr. Mercy can heal a player, but medic has to manage overheal. The perfect game for nihilistic players who didn't wanna grind out skill for glory, to learn to appreciate the ladder climb, who rage quit from tf2 for an easy to reward game like overwatch - or just outright start cheating.  Overwatch is quantity, over quality compared to TF2. TF2 class Loadouts offer a wide dynamic range of gameplay styles, and even full subclass sets that vary between weapons. Such as an ambushing crit-a-cola force-a-nature scout, degreaser flare combo pyro, revengineer, battle medic, fat scout, and even further with hard subclass loadouts like demoknight, trollgier, and the legendary hoovy. Running into a class, you never know what they'll have, and some weapons can even mitigate class counters so you best be ready. You see a scout and you know he's gonna be jumpy and dodgy, but dependent on the scouts loadout, his playstyle could be dramatically different with weapons. Overwatch on the other hand would rather split dynamic gameplay styles into their own characters. Everyone has the same single sets of weapons that can't be swapped to easily know what they'll be doing. So its much easier to read, and often times solid counter. You immediately know what they're capable of, and their limits to easily exploit right off the bat. Meanwhile for escapist players who just want big asses, and tits. Basic 'token' characters with simple dynamics, and little to no distinct, unique personalities just to milk out more names, and sometimes more waifus, in their roster. Sometimes even just for "political inclusiveness" rather than a genuine charming design. Still makes me laugh once overwatch had on their website "don't play classes, play heroes!" Though just remember, its what's on the inside that counts. Not a flashy diamond encrusted poop. Heroes die, but more often than not they can live long enough to become the villain. Just depends on the heart of it. You ready to respawn?tl;dr OW is a game designed for players who want an easy, and flashy game to get milked by greedy corpos just like genshrek im🅱️act

Author: PaulGR
Review Content: Disgusting F2P tactics deviating from the original OW formula in order to appeal to the 12yo Fortnite fanbase that can only afford "free" games while begging their parents for their credit card in order to buy ridiculously expensive skins and dances.There is absolutely no upgrade from the original OW. Everything looks and feels the same. They just slapped "2" next to the name as a marketing strategy because they decided to make the game F2P after the player-base died. I paid 60$ for OW1 and they removed it, so for owners of OW1 this is absolutely not a free game. We paid for it, and now we are forced to pay again through their awful and predatory battle-pass system if we want to get something as simple as an Emote.Everything is now locked behind ridiculous grinding and absurd weekly "challenges" that ask you to invest hours upon hours to complete them because they are based on luck (e.g., get 20 team kills). You need to pay 20 euro for a skin-recolor, or farm for 8 MONTHS to get it for "free." The supposed "free" rewards from the Battle-pass are joke-sprays and useless voice-lines. All the real things are locked behind the premium pay-wall that, upon completion, doesn't even give you your money/currency back (to invest it in the next Battle-pass). Essentially you need a bi-monthly subscription to play the game, as there is nothing to strive for in the "free" part of the Battle-pass.The new "free" players that joined are entirely oblivious to FPSs and make games very frustrating. They cannot DPS, they cannot flank, they cannot heal. They pick Moira and play her like its Call of Duty. The awful matchmaking system pairs these new users with existing veterans, making each match a steamroll. You either get destroyed and can't even leave the spawn room, or you entirely destroy the enemy team. There is no in-between. This makes games frustrating as you can lose 10 games in a row just like that.Overall, a disgusting re-release by Blizzard/Activision/Microsoft (or whatever company they sold themselves to nowadays). They turned a paid-game into a Freemium cow ready to be milked before it dies under the pretense that this is some sort of "update" or a big "overhaul."You can tell the game is dying by the mere fact that they brought this to Steam for a quick player-injection.

Author: Broccane
Review Content: This Team Fortress 2 update is a massive step backward for the franchise, a disappointing departure from the qualities that once made it shine. The game initially boasted a diverse and charismatic cast of 9 classes, each brimming with personality and charm. However, Valve's recent decision to prioritize performative diversity, resulting in the addition of 37 seemingly one-dimensional characters, has raised concerns. This move feels more like a hasty attempt to cater to certain social trends and appease Twitter, now simply referred to as 'X'.My profound disappointment doesn't stop at the casting choices. The removal of the beloved Mann vs. Machine (MVM) mode and the cancellation of other player-versus-environment (PVE) content is a bitter pill to swallow. Instead, players are offered story missions for a steep price of $15, delivering a paltry hour of gameplay at best. The lackluster execution of these missions, featuring haphazardly designed adversaries that seem to do little more than rush at players and meet their demise, further adds to the letdown.One particularly perplexing decision was the elimination of the 12v12 format, ostensibly due to concerns about an overabundance of engineers in matches. This has been replaced by a lackluster 5v5 setup coupled with a 'Role Queue' system, significantly curtailing the potential for imaginative team compositions and strategic diversity. The frustrating part is that even classic classes like the engineer have seemingly fallen victim to the pressures of conforming to modern-day trends of performative diversity.In conclusion, this update has veered away from the core essence of what made Team Fortress 2 a beloved title, trading its unique and captivating gameplay elements for what appears to be an attempt at superficial inclusivity. The result is a disappointing regression that falls short of the franchise's once illustrious reputation.

Author: 𝘽𝙡𝙞𝙏𝙯⚡♿
Review Content: I've played this for thousands of hours. Given its irreplaceable yet unique characteristic of 6v6 competitive game play, it is currently impossible to find a game that can be completely treated as a substitute of Overwatch. When Overwatch was just released in 2016, countless players were crazy about it, impressed, attracted, and addicted to this masterpiece by Jeff and his Blizzard team, including myself, and I even did not have a laptop to run the game but I still purchased collector's edition on the day of release... Sadly, the success of the game was ruined by blizzard itself after Jeff's resign. Without the "Father" of Overwatch, the development team was totally loss and they even did not know what exactly they are doing. I am lucky I was able to play Overwatch since 2020 yet was unlucky and desperate to see its current situation. With Bobby Kotick, the profit-driven nature of the bussinessman turned the game into a total piece of a trash which only cares about the money in players' pocket. The battle pass, ridiculous skin price and series of new heroes made in hurry further dragged the game into the inevitable death. As about worldview, the team no longer focus on enriching the heroes' background but turn to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ their LGBTQ experiences which is obviously overwhelming and useless except helping you trash team gathering more political correctness thus grabbing more money from a larger group of players. I still love Overwatch and play Overwatch 2, I play it because there is no alternative games, and I believe there are a lot of players have the same idea that they only love the original Overwatch (2016-2022). Blizzard, especially the Bobby guy, F u all. You deeply broke players heart.R.I.POverwatch2016-2022

Author: KingCrimson
Review Content: This game is the reason Ow 1 got no more content. We were promised so many things to make up for it. New modes, PvE and an overhaul to PvP gameplay. Now that we have all that is promised the results are lackluster. Firstly, you have to pay to unlock PvE which doesn't even have the fun stuff like skill trees anymore. Secondly, the PvE we got is ass. The move to 5v5 was a bad one in my opinion. All the Ow 1 maps were designed with 6v6 in mind. The little reworks. although better, don't make the maps feel that great. I also miss 2 tanks. Now all of the burden is on the one tank player. It can be very stressful. The new modes are hit or miss. Push is super tedious. If the enemy gets the first checkpoint, it is over. It's just running back and for for 10 minutes. I haven't played enough of Flashpoint yet but it seems to be pretty decent. It also includes a lot of running.One last thing is the skins/monetization in this game. In Ow 1 you got all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ through loot boxes or by buying them with in-game money. You got loot boxes very easily. Compare this to Ow 2 where you get new skins buying them with Overwatch coins. These coins can be purchased with real life money or through weekly challenges. You get 60 Overwatch coins a week (if you do all the tedious challenges). A new Legendary skin costs 1 900 Overwatch coins. That is 32 weeks for one skin. Another source for skins is the Battle pass. It costs only 1 000 Overwatch coins which is about 10 €. But you don't get any Overwatch coins from the Battlepass itself so you have to always buy the Battlepass again using real life money. Worst Battlepass in the history of gaming.In conclusion, don't buy anything in this game. It doesn't deserve your money. Thank you Blizzard for ruining Overwatch.Edit: Forgot to talk about the new gamemodes so I added that section in

Author: Mapet
Review Content: Unbalanced with a lack of direction, lots of meta shifting, character reworks and rebalances over the years, quantity over quality; rigid and clunky movement mechanics that enable limited verticality and reduce the skill ceiling, with everything tied to cooldowns; poor visual cohesion and legibility; full of microtransactions; false promises; an overly sanitized and unorganic "competitive scene" completely unmanaged by its community; zero mod support.The game can look great on screenshots and renders, but its gameplay is the most disappointing and offensive aspect that I can think of when talking about first person shooters in general.Them having to release this so called "sequel" here on Steam gives me hope for the future of the games industry. The fact that the 15 year old game it was supposed to kill or replace still has a healthy playerbase shows us that good gameplay, good artstyle and visual cohesion and community involvement go a long long way.

Author: TheFlashBat
Review Content: When the OG OW1 came out I recommended it to all my friends and we all played it together for about 2 or so years and they were some of the best years I've ever had playing games.Anyway fast forward to now, I couldn't recommend this game to anyone, the moment to moment game play is quite fun when the matchmaking isn't completely screwing you over. Like this game has issues on a fundamental level, so many broken or annoying characters that aren't fun to play or aren't fun to vs, the memes that come out of it are funny but still (solo shattering Sombra is never not satisfying).So the big issue with this "sequel" the greed; not only did they get rid of OW1 that you had to pay for?!? but they also made it almost impossible to get new skins without paying. In fact now (not for the first 2 or 3 seasons) you can only get like 1 or 2 legendary skins a season (these are only OW1 skins) which is disgusting. They also released this game with less content than the OG and a worse game mode that not a single person likes (push) and one less person on your team (see ya 6th guy). It is horrible that we have to play without one of our friends cause the game decided that being steamrolled or doing the steamrolling was a better solution to the shielding in the first game.Lastly this games PvE promise that was completely shattered and taken away... until it wasn't and was released in the current season with less content or features that now you have to PAY FOR like they don't earn enough from their greedy practises already. It is horrible what has happened to the game I used to love and it is amazing how the community fights back against it both in comments and now in the reviews, having this be the worst reviewed game on steam is both funny and concerning but I'm so happy we all collectively hate this game and this company. (kinda feel bad for the people who actually try to work on this game, remember not to hate the devs that try but hate the people who tell them what to do)

Author: NovaFrederick
Review Content:
As tempting as it might be to make another haha p0rnography joke.The reality is that I legitimately did not enjoy this game, and i'm talking about all the way back in 2016, during it's first Halloween event.I figured to give the game a fair shot despite my initial scepticism regarding the comparisons to Team Fortress 2, I quickly found that the comparisons, (for reasons i will get to later) were unfounded.It was alright at first, the game was well optimised and felt clean. However it quickly became stagnant, games were often very much one sided and the abilities for each character felt closer to a compensation for skill more than anything.Stuns, cheap escapes and then there was Symmetra who just felt downright useless.The sheer fact that ultimates did (and to my knowledge still do not) reset upon death basically takes out all the risk and reward factor.It's more so a tool for a free kill or two rather than something that could turn the tide of a game, such a scenario while not unlikely is a relative exception and not norm.I haven't touched the game all too much since somewhere in the winter of 2016, maybe once or twice because of peer pressure or by getting REALLY bored.Sure it's been years and this is Overwatch 2 and not 1..... but don't even bother trying to fool anyone, the number change was a glorified update.Considering the recent developments (or rather the lack thereof) surrounding PvE, I have no reason to believe it has gotten any better.Also, not really valid for game criticism but the community around the game was toxic AF, OW got praised to heaven like it invented a cure to cancer.Anything remotely critical of the game got struck down with fire and (especially) fury.Now the bit regarding the TF2 "rivalry"That there is rivalry in quotation marks because as far as i am concerned, the two games are not that alike. But hey, here we are.Instead of taking the time to write down why, I will just leave it with a (modified to better fit the review) forum post I made a while back in a thread regarding the issue.Barely anyone wanted the TF2 v OW comparisons except for out of touch journalists, some fanboys looking for an easy target and Youtubers who didn't play either.

They made the situation like it is now thinking they could easily overcome a then 9 year old game with more performance issues than an insecure skinny teen forced to wrestle a balkan bodybuilder.

Yet here we are where the cancellation of the sole justification for OW2s existence has driven them to a competing (and arguably better) storefront, owned by the same company that made TF2 no less, It really goes to show what a laughing stock OW has become.

TF2 did not invent the class-based genre, TF2 barely invented anything. Same for OW.
But hey OW was there to replace TF2! they insisted on the comparisons, and now that the situation isn't so rosey anymore, they gotta stick it into their pipes and smoke it.The gist: Avoid, play Warioware or smth.

Author: Scott the Woz (Real)
Review Content: OK, I'm breaking my character of the funny internet guy to tell you to NOT BUY ANYTHING ELSE THAT ISN'T THE INVASION BUNDLE. The only reason why is that the higher ups at Blizzard are trying to squeeze every single dollar out of your wallet, and every our of your free time. The Story Mode that they originally planned for this game is left in bits and pieces and then locked behind a paywall so you can cough up your hard earned cash to there predatory and downright disgusting micro-transactions. I started playing when it launched back in 2022 without any prior experience with the first one, I was excited to try this out and see why people called it the best Hero Shooter of the decade, only to find a hollow shell of a great game filled with $20 skins, barely any content, and a horrible Battle-Pass with no good rewards that aren't skins and critical Heroes locked behind it. I tried to give this game a fair shot, but the game had other issues as well, like a horrible matchmaking system for casual play, and the lack of anything fun that isn't casual and ranked. The way you unlock new Heroes is also very excruciating. You have to win 32 matches for each new hero by playing the class there from, but you can't do these simultaneously like every other quest in the game, you have to do each by itself for a total of 192 SEPERATE MATCHES THAT YOU HAVE TO WIN. and once the season ends, the new Hero will also be included with that with 32 more matches to win. and guess what, you can bypass this by paying $10 per hero, roughly the same price for the Battle Pass.The amount of crap that this game throws at you just to come off as a "Sequel" is laughable. And we shouldn't be blaming the crew for this. They have been trying there best to keep us satisfied while dealing with the higher ups and there constant chicanery. The only reason why I said you should get the Invasion Bundle is so you can get the game they want to make. And who knows, if we could all not buy anything else and just get the Story Missions, we can show them what game we want, not what we have.

Review Content: Don't mind the time played, I've been in since the open beta. This game has been plagued by bad design decisions since its launch almost a decade ago.The gameplay and balancing have gotten worse and worse over time, leading to more annoying, less fun matches.They tried to scrub away criticism and flagging player numbers by re-launching a worse version of the game in an update called Overwatch 2. They deleted the previous version of the game from existence and removed the ability to earn skins, while also adding battle-passes and a skin store that uses real-money currency. The creators and owners have many cases of sexual harassment towards women as well, which I find much worse than bad game decisions alone. Their response to this going public was removing sexual jokes from World of Warcraft and renaming one of the characters in this game, because he was named after a predatory man. They did not make any actual changes to the company or admit any wrong-doing, opting to try to pay-off the women making these claims.This game is bad and so is the company who owns it. Don't give them your time. Don't give them your money. You'll have a better time with the fan porn, honestly.

Author: tf2dove
Review Content: +578 hours from Battle.netPVPOverwatch's PVP gameplay loop is pretty solid. A relatively fun mode, albeit a mostly toxic community makes it a bit dicey at times. Would recommend against playing the competitive mode for that point alone.PVEOverwatch's PVE gameplay loop is currently quite stale. Fun for a singular playthrough, but to be candid, their older OW1 "Archives" event had better and more unique PVE scenarios, and therefore more replayability. There's not much variance in what you're tasked to do and the enemies you fight. Widespread PVE is still a newer part of the game, so it's very likely this'll change, but releasing a very stale free mission and putting the remaining at-launch ones behind a $15-25 paywall does not instill trust.MicrotransactionsSpeaking of, the current F2P + microtransaction setup for OW2 is awful. It attempts to coax you into cracking open your wallet at essentially every juncture. In OW1, this was just cosmetics, cosmetics you could get for free if you played enough. However now, there are some things you absolutely have to pay for, including heroes and playable content. This has the possibility of being rational, given that the game is now free, but the sheer lack of new content (both free and paid) makes this impossible to defend. OW1's monetization was great for the consumer and still offered Blizzard substantial money. OW2's painful monetization screws over the consumer and makes Blizzard even more money.BalancingAs for overall balance, OW1 and OW2 have some notable differences. The first is a change from 6v6 to 5v5. Might be a controversial take, but this has been a fresh improvement for the game. Makes the gameplay faster, makes it less about shooting and wearing down shields. However, it has forced tanks to become generalist vs a main and an off tank. Blizzard hasn't balanced this yet, and some tanks absolutely suck whereas some absolutely shred. The lack of two tanks does make the tank role a bit more stale at times too.The second and final main change is their hero balancing. They've never been great at it, even in OW1, but for OW2 they've had an obsession with converting more specialized heroes into generalists. For some heroes this has been great, for others, it has removed fun and unique parts of their kits. They've removed stuns and Mei's freeze, but still have pencil-thin one-shot snipers. Makes the gameplay a lot more stale and repetitive, makes freshness and fun depend on developer patches rather than player choice.TL;DRGiven all of this, the rebranding from OW1 to OW2 was essentially just a marketing gimmick and excuse to charge for more macrotransactions. They flopped on delivering robust PVE, and haven't really added anything substantially new in quite a while. It's clear the devs still care, as the training range and new additions have been made with notable effort, but in terms of newness and freshness, nothing to warrant a sequel just yet.

Author: joy!
Review Content: Overwatch 2 seems to have taken a different path from its previous player-focused approach, adopting a veneer of continuity from its predecessor while clearly prioritizing financial gains.Back in 2016, I initially dove into the game and, like countless others, was quickly captivated by its charm. Overwatch remained a staple among my favorite shooters over the years, even during content droughts leading up to the arrival of OW2.While the game's endearing design, captivating cast of characters, and impressive multiplayer maps remain intact, Overwatch 2 has introduced significant changes that cast a shadow over its core essence. Allow me to elaborate:#1 - Limiting Heroes through the Battlepass StructureOne of the most notable changes is the confinement of heroes within the Battlepass structure, a change of considerable significance.Overwatch is built on hero selection and team dynamics. Each character brings unique advantages, with varying levels of compatibility. In its previous iteration, Overwatch introduced new heroes to the player base, fostering an inclusive environment without financial barriers. However, Overwatch 2 now requires either a significant time commitment or monetary investment through the Battlepass to access new heroes upon release (or a fee of £9 for established heroes).While this might seem innocuous, it results in players engaging in competitive gameplay with an incomplete hero roster.Essential gameplay aspects are now locked behind a financial threshold, undermining the principles of fair competition.How can fair competition persist when some players have more options solely due to financial spending? The resemblance to a "pay-to-win" model is evident, though I leave it to your judgment to form this conclusion.#2 - The Battlepass Structure and Cosmetic EvolutionMy stance on the Battlepass structure has been somewhat agreeable in the past. However, when compared to similar systems in other games, OW2's implementation falls short. Each Battlepass iteration offers 80 tiers of rewards, typically including 8 distinct skins (plus a customizable variant at the end), along with various additional items. These extras include titles, emblems, and emotes. It's worth noting that a recent addition is "credits," a commendable addition but one that doesn't fully address the core issue of locking essential gameplay elements behind a paywall.Cosmetics have always played a significant role in Overwatch, showcasing the creativity of artists and designers behind exceptional skins. These designs still hold aesthetic value, but their pricing is audacious. Notably, legendary skins, representing more than just color variations, average around £20 each.In the past, these cosmetic items were attainable through lootboxes, granted with each player level increase, a frequency that seemed reasonable. In my personal experience, I rarely purchased lootboxes directly but managed to amass a considerable collection of skins across various characters. The transition to a commercial model was explained as a necessity due to the alleged financial strain of the lootbox system, a claim I find debatable. By 2019, a mere three years after launch, Overwatch had generated $1 billion through lootbox sales.Currently, avenues for acquiring cosmetics without spending money are limited, unless one is willing to invest months in obtaining a single legendary skin through extended gameplay.#3 - The Practice of PvE ImplementationWhile I personally leaned more toward Player versus Environment (PvE) experiences, it's crucial to acknowledge that Overwatch 2 initially highlighted this aspect as a central pillar of its offering.In theory, that was the promise; however, the actual outcome seems like a bait-and-switch maneuver, seemingly aimed at introducing new monetization methods. Surprisingly, even after the apparent scaling down of PvE efforts, isolated PvE missions persist, though they are available as separate purchases, serving as another channel for monetary gain.In ConclusionFor fans of competitive shooters, Overwatch 2 appears to deviate from the principles of competitive fairness.For those interested in cosmetic acquisition, Overwatch 2 demands a significant financial commitment.While the fun factor remains, maintaining hints of the enjoyable experience from the past, it is overshadowed by the intrusion of profit motives to an extent that leads me to withhold full endorsement for discerning enthusiasts.

Author: Keron
Review Content: I used to love this game, pre ordered it and played it for more than a year straight.Coming back to this in OW2, I don't even know what game this is anymore.Starting of, this game doesn't need the number 2, it's the same game with one less hero in the team and way less items for you to get (unless you wanna spend some money).Lootboxes were evil you say? Tell me then, how lootboxes were a million times fairer than the trash they have now.I stopped playing before Moira came out, all the characters before her are between 60-90 items collected, good luck getting even near that now, especially without spending money (which I never did btw, apart from buying the game and the first pass of OW2). The lootboxes were random af, gave you a ton of repeat items, but all the repeats gave you credits, you could get enough to buy your favorite skin pretty fast tbh.And that's all a cosmetic problem, which imo is very important in this game, but that isn't all,Gameplay wise, this game is a shell of what it used to be. The change from 6 players to 5, at least imo sucks. 2 tanks were much better than 1.And the new ranking system is very bad, feels so random. You win and then you derank, you have no idea what kind of mmr you have, there's no points system for it to be clear.I made the mistake of coming back when OW"2" came out and buying their pass, will never do that again.Random ass game, you either stomp or get stomped, there's no in between.If you wanted any good will bringing this game on steam first, you made the wrong choice blizzard.EDIT: I actually forgot about something that you clearly want us to forget. Remember the PvE mode you cancelled? Why are you selling it now, or at least parts of it?

Author: Aperture
Review Content: Team Fortress 2 is a 2007 multiplayer first-person shooter game developed and published by Valve Corporation. It is the sequel to the 1996 Team Fortress mod for Quake and its 1999 remake, Team Fortress Classic. The game was released in October 2007 as part of The Orange Box for Windows and the Xbox 360, and ported to the PlayStation 3 in December 2007. It was released as a standalone game for Windows in April 2008, and updated to support Mac OS X in June 2010 and Linux in February 2013. It is distributed online through Valve's digital retailer Steam, with Electronic Arts managing retail and console editions.Players join one of two teams—RED or BLU—and choose one of nine character classes to play as, with game modes including capture the flag and king of the hill. Development was led by John Cook and Robin Walker, the developers of the original Team Fortress mod. Team Fortress 2 was announced in 1998 under the name Team Fortress 2: Brotherhood of Arms. Initially, the game had more realistic, militaristic visuals and gameplay, but this changed over the protracted nine years of development. After Valve released no information for six years, Team Fortress 2 regularly featured in Wired News' annual vaporware list among other entries. Finally released on the Source game engine in 2007, Team Fortress 2 would preserve much of the core class-based gameplay of its predecessors while featuring an overhauled, cartoon-like visual style influenced by the works of J. C. Leyendecker, Dean Cornwell, and Norman Rockwell, alongside an increased focus on the visual and verbal characterization of its playable classes and what the developers have described as a 1960s spy movie aesthetic.Team Fortress 2 has received critical acclaim for its art direction, gameplay, humor, and use of character in a wholly multiplayer game, and since its release has been referred to as one of the greatest video games ever created. The game continues to receive official Valve server support as of July 2023, in addition to new content being released on a seasonal basis in the form of submissions made through the Steam Workshop. In June 2011, the game became free-to-play, supported by microtransactions for in-game cosmetics. A 'drop system' was also added and refined, allowing free-to-play users to periodically receive in-game equipment and items. Though the game has had an unofficial competitive scene since its release, both support for official competitive play through ranked matchmaking and an overhauled casual experience were added in July 2016. Since early 2020, the official Valve servers have seen an influx of bot accounts using cheat software, often inhibiting legitimate gameplay.

Author: osek
Review Content: Overwatch, Borderlands 2 and Crash Bandicoot 3: Warped are the best games I played in my life. They are milestones in bombarding my dopamine receptors. I'm still playing BL2 and CB3 (Insanity remaster) from time to time, but I'm not able to play OW. Instead, I'm going to write a review about that abomination which is OW2.Blizzard made so many things wrong with this title that I don't know exactly where to start, so I will focus on the biggest changes. Transition to F2P made this game more accesible to other people. Of course, that has it's own cons and pros. But looking at bigger picture, this made this game more expensive. Before, you just had to pay 60$ and that's all. F2p means that game itself is free, but other things within this game have a price, which accumulating over time can cost more, but that brings us to the biggest con of this game - characters behind a paywall. You can unlock character later in free battle pass path, which takes a lot of time, or you can buy it, and get it imedietly. You can get premium currency via doing daily chalanges, but it's really tedius. New characters usually are op (Kiriko), so if you want to play comp, you have to get them. All of those points creates such a big FOMO, I had to stop play after a month because it felt so wrong, it's a really predatory monetization.After a while not playing this game I checked what's going on with PVE. It supose to have skill trees, something like MvM. I was really hoping it's going to bring something fresh... and they scraped it. Instead, it's your regural seasonal event like Archives. And of course, behind a 15$.Opinion about change from 6v6 to 5v5 varies from person to person. To me, it's a negative. One of the core mechanics in this game is ability to change a character mid game. But, balancing everything is a hard task. So, if you have Doom Fist one trick and enemy have Orisa, that's a gg, because you can't help him tankig, because there is only 1 tank slot. Would it better if they divided roles as Tank/Tank/DPS/DPS/Support? That's your usuall composition in Paladins, but they have draft and ban system (at least in competitive). In OW2 it would still bring you to sup dif, but I think it could be less severe.Is there anything positive in this title? Everything that was positive in the first game - gameplay, characters, maps, music, net code, art style, performence. OW was a 10/10 game for me in 2016/2017. But this is a review for OW2, which feels like a rip of. This is painful because I invested arround 1KH playing it, and it's a time well spent, I had a great time. For me, it's like a son I really love, who had a really good grades in college, but he turned into a junky selling his body for a crack.TL:DR blozord bad

Author: Yuedar
Review Content: I've been playing Overwatch since the beta of Overwatch 1 in 2016. This is the most mismanaged IP that I have ever been a part of. This game had and still has a lot of potential but the devs or the suits that control the devs have turned this into a complete cash grab microtransaction ♥♥♥♥ show. I never would have gotten into this game in the state that it is in now and it saddens me that the younger gaming community accepts this sort of thing as normal now. Signing into overwatch on steam is more complicated than just using the Bnet launcher. I had to download this game a 2nd time so it now resides on my harddrive twice. That will be remedied soon. The PvE isn't worth the price tag. Play this game enough and you'll likely see your account suspended temporarily just from toxic teammates that get frustrated they lost while an automated report system never has anyone real checking it. The quality of this player base has gone drastically down hill since this game became free to play too. Gone are the days of strategy with team comps, and playing objectives. Now your tank will lose patience and just yeet themselves forward after a won fight going into the enemy spawn only to die while the rest of your team is left to defend the objective without your singular tank because Blizzard thought having a 5v5 was better than a 6v6 with 2 tanks. The battlepass system will make you yearn for the day of loot boxes. thats saying something but albeit true. When you bought Overwatch the original the entire cast of heros was available from the second you got the game. So when I saw on steam you had to buy the heros to unlock them that just seems ridiculous. That used to be just part of the game. So much for free to play? In a game thats so heavily focused on team play, coordination, communication etc how have they never built a guild/clan function into this game by now? They the devs still don't seem to know what they're doing with Symmetra. The change to showcasing your rank has gone backwards. You used to just see a flat number change after every game. Now you could go 5-2 and not get a promotion and just be left wondering why? You could ask the community and be given every theory craft imaginable but the truth is noone will know. In Overwatch 1 you would of known exactly where you stood to the singular number. This change was made to get people out of their heads for playing ranked. Yikes. Frankly the only good things that came from OW2 is the ping system and the scoreboard during a game. Give me those 2 things with the Overwatch 1 game (the new heros are fine too) and frankly i'd just be playing that over this.

Author: Aleksej
Review Content: I am writing on behalf of my sister, who was permanently banned in this “masterpiece” without any reason (I myself played from the first Overwatch and also tried the second one, but now I definitely won’t return to it). Sis: “I started playing with my brother on the release of the OW2, as he had good memories of the first one. In FPS shooters, I was a complete noob, but I liked this game and I even made friends in it, with whom I began to actively play and was able to raise the Gold 2 rank in a year without experience. But at some point, I started to come across inadequate players who thought that I was playing the support role poorly (although they themselves didn’t play so well on damage dealers and tanks - KDA was negative) and spammed unpleasant things in the chat and voice chat. I tried not to be rude to them, but sometimes I could not control myself and answered sharply. And in the end looks like I met some overly gentle aggressors (or I was unlucky and I answered the “genius” moderator) who falsely reported me and I received a permanent ban. In support, after trying to convey my position and after asking for an explanation why I received a ban, they ignored me and sent exactly the same email about the blocking. After a year of experience in this game (which I also donated to), this was a spit in the face from Blizzard. And now I have no motivation to play in this game. I no longer hope for the adequacy of support and with this review I want to warn new players what to expect: inadequate F2P community, ignoring problems from Blizzard and, in addition, overpriced customization.”

Author: larguu
Review Content: Blizzard Entertainment's 2016 video game Overwatch inspired a notable amount of fan-made pornography. The game's distinct and colorful character designs drew the attention of many online content creators, resulting in sexually explicit fanart. Character models were ripped from the beta versions of the game and subsequently spread, edited, and animated on the Internet.Animated pornography shorts and sexualized imagery featuring official character models constitute the main content of Overwatch pornography. Original pornography fan artists (animators and illustrators) are most commonly based on social media platforms such as Twitter, Reddit, and Tumblr, while they upload their works to file hosting services like MEGA, Gfycat, Webmshare, and Google Drive. Pornographic content is created primarily through Valve's Source Filmmaker (SFM) and Blender.Overwatch pornography usually consists of short pieces of video featuring characters such as Tracer, D.Va, and Mei. Blizzard initially issued cease-and-desist orders to some prolific creators through an independent security firm, though the game's director described the situation as "an inevitable reality of the internet in 2016." Video game journalists have described the abundance of (pornographic) fan works as a positive indicator for the game's longevity. Pornographic works of the game remained a topic of discussion long after that game's release, with artists making content of the game's post-launch characters, and Overwatch-related search topics continuing to be popular on porn websites.Overwatch and its pornographic community has inspired various groups and companies to produce adult content related to the game. Brazzers produced a "porn parody" based on Overwatch in September 2016. The website Overpogcom started producing a Playboy-style magazine about the game in late 2016, until they were forced to stop in February the following year. Overwatch has inspired both sexualized cosplay and pornographic virtual reality works.

Author: Soap
Review Content: How to cook enchilada fillingsIngredientsFor the Enchilada Filling:- 2 chicken breasts, cooked and shredded- 1 onion, finely chopped- 1 red bell pepper, diced- 1 teaspoon ground cumin- 1 teaspoon ground coriander- 1/2 teaspoon paprika- Salt and pepper, to taste- 1 cup canned black beans, drained and rinsed- 1 cup corn kernels (fresh, frozen, or canned)- 1 cup shredded cheddar cheeseFor the Enchilada Sauce:- 2 tablespoons olive oil- 2 tablespoons plain flour- 2 tablespoons tomato paste- 1 teaspoon ground cumin- 1 teaspoon ground coriander- 1/2 teaspoon paprika- 2 cups chicken or vegetable broth- Salt and pepper, to tasteFor Assembling:- 8 small tortillas (corn or flour)- Additional shredded cheddar cheese, for topping**Instructions:**1. Preheat your oven to 180°C (350°F).2. In a large skillet, heat a bit of oil over medium heat. Add the chopped onion and diced red bell pepper. Cook until softened.3. Add the shredded chicken, ground cumin, ground coriander, paprika, salt, and pepper to the skillet. Stir to combine and let the flavors meld for a few minutes.4. Stir in the black beans and corn kernels. Cook for an additional 2-3 minutes until heated through. Remove from heat and set aside.5. For the enchilada sauce, in a separate saucepan, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add the flour and whisk continuously to make a roux. Cook for about 1-2 minutes.6. Stir in the tomato paste, ground cumin, ground coriander, and paprika. Cook for another minute.7. Gradually whisk in the chicken or vegetable broth, making sure to whisk out any lumps. Allow the sauce to simmer and thicken for about 5-7 minutes. Season with salt and pepper to taste.8. Take a tortilla and spoon some of the chicken and bean mixture onto it. Roll it up tightly and place it seam-side down in a greased baking dish.9. Repeat with the remaining tortillas and filling, arranging them side by side in the baking dish.10. Pour the enchilada sauce over the rolled tortillas, making sure they're all covered.11. Sprinkle shredded cheddar cheese over the top of the enchiladas.12. Cover the baking dish with aluminum foil and bake in the preheated oven for about 20-25 minutes, or until the cheese is melted and bubbly.13. Remove the foil and bake for an additional 5-10 minutes until the cheese is golden and slightly crispy.14. Remove from the oven and let the enchiladas cool slightly before serving.15. Serve the chicken enchiladas with your favorite toppings, such as sour cream, diced avocado, and chopped fresh coriander.Done

Author: Todd Howard´s weakest warrior
Review Content: California Files a Lawsuit Against Activision BlizzardOn July 20, 2021, the California Department of Fair Employment and Housing filed a lawsuit against Activision Blizzard after a lengthy two-year investigation. According to Bloomberg Law, the agency accused the company of promoting a “‘frat boy’ culture” that put female employees in the crosshairs. While women only made up approximately 20% of Activision Blizzard’s employee population, they experienced “constant sexual harassment, unequal pay, and retaliation.” One of the biggest discoveries was the pervasiveness of what the lawsuit dubbed “cube crawls,” where male employees got drunk, crawled their way through cubicles, and participated in “inappropriate behavior toward female employees.” Many male employees also allegedly openly joked about rape and passed off their responsibilities to their female coworkers just so they could slack off and play video games. Moreover, female employees claimed they were passed over for promotions because “they might become pregnant.” However, arguably the most troubling accusation listed in the lawsuit is the reveal that one unnamed female Activision worker committed suicide while on a company trip with an unnamed “male supervisor.” She was allegedly the victim of “intense sexual harassment” to the point where nude pictures of her were circulated during a company holiday party.Former Blizzard President J. Allen Brack Addresses the Harassment Allegations Before Leaving the CompanyShortly after the sexual harassment allegations came to light, many prominent figures in the gaming industry expressed how much the news distressed them. One such person was then-Blizzard President J. Allen Brack. He claimed to know nothing about the harassment and wanted to help ensure the wellbeing and safety of Blizzard’s employees, which is all well and good save for one crucial detail: He was mentioned by name as having prior knowledge of the harassment and reportedly did nothing about it, all while acting “too friendly” to female employees. The other prominent Blizzard figure directly named in the lawsuit is Alex Afrasiabi. He reportedly told women he wanted to marry them and tried to kiss them, among other actions, and his supervisors had to “pull him off” his victims multiple times. While Brack and Afrasiabi left Activision Blizzard (or, in Afrasiabi’s case, was fired) due to their connection with the lawsuit, they weren’t alone. Diablo 4’s Lead Designer Jesse McCree, World of Warcraft designer Jonathan LeCraft, and Lead Game Designer Cory Stockton were all fired after their part in the company’s sexual harassment scandal came to light.Frances Townsend (or Bobby Kotick?) Sends a Troubling Internal EmailControversial Activision Blizzard Vice President Frances Townsend (who formerly worked for the Bush administration) disturbed many people in and outside of the company when she reportedly sent an email that called the allegations outlined in the investigation a “distorted and untrue picture of our company” and generally attempted to downplay the validity and severity of the situation.Later, the Wall Street Journal reported that the email was actually written by Activision CEO Bobby Kotick. Author aside, the tone-deaf nature of the email caused many Blizzard employees to immediately respond in their own way…Activision Blizzard Employees Stage A WalkoutAs news of the lawsuit and its allegations spread through Activision Blizzard’s workforce, many employees staged a walkout in response. Tempers didn’t calm down afterward. If anything, emotions rose after reports hit that many higher-ups knew about the accusations and did nothing about them. Over 100 employees walked out in protest and shared a clear demand: Fire CEO Bobby Kotick. Moreover, well over 2,000 employees signed a letter that called the company out on their response. According to the organization behind many of the employee protests, ABK Workers Alliance, many of the employees’ demands have not been met. That was true back in August of 2021, and it is still true today. Moreover, the Communication Workers of America labor union called Activision Blizzard’s $18 million settlement deal over sexual harassment allegations, “a slap in the face” since the company is worth $72 billion.Fans and News Outlets Refuse to Play and Cover Activision Blizzard GamesShortly after the sexual harassment lawsuit came to light, a huge portion of the Blizzard fanbase boycotted the company and its games. Many gamers and streamers, including those who were known for playing titles like World of Warcraft and Hearthstone, refused to touch the games. They weren’t alone, as sites such as The Gamer, Prima Games, and GameXplain elected to cease all coverage of Activision Blizzard titles. No good news, no bad news, just deafening silence until, as The Gamer Editor in Chief Kirk McKeand put it, “there’s some real change.”Allegations Against Activision Blizzard CEO Bobby Kotick Are Made PublicRecently, many allegations regarding Activision Blizzard’s CEO, Bobby Kotick, have come to light. For instance, according to the Wall Street Journal, he once sent an intimidating voicemail to one of his assistants, threatening to kill her. And yes, he also allegedly knew about the sexual harassment in his company and did nothing about it. Well, that’s not entirely true — he apparently protected the perpetrators and refused to report the incidents to the company’s board of directors. This led to another lawsuit filed by investors angry over Kotick’s “issuing materially false and misleading statements during a class action period.”I literally forgot that Tracer was lesbian because of much she gets pipe´d these days.May God bless Blender artists.Also there isn´t a single good Activision Blizzard game these days.

Author: spy-induced noise complaints
Review Content: A small premise: I am mostly a casual gamer, not interested in the competitive side of games, nor do I care about skins and other features that don't directly affect the gameplay (I played hatless for a long time even in tf2 :) ). The core game itself is solid, it's basically the original OW but 5v5 - if you don't know it's basically a FPS shooter with heroes, each of which has its own abilities and an ultimate. This is in practice a weaboo rebranding of the classic "choose your weapon" and "choose your powers" mechanic. Like all multiplayer games, it's way more enjoyable with friends, especially considering the large amount of toxic basement dwellers infesting this game :-)From a graphical perspective OW2 is not particularly innovative but at least looks pretty and doesn't require a very powerful PC to run, something which is honestly quite underrated today. From a sonic point of view, OW2 is great, but while the OST contains mostly forgettable (but still well-made!) pieces, the sound design steals the show.Now, let's talk about the elephant in the room, which is also the reason behind the (currently) very angry reviews: the F2P model. Currently a battle pass (around €10) is required to unlock new heroes in an easy and painless way AND to be able to play the latest hero; heroes introduced in previous seasons can be unlocked without paying by winning around 30 matches for each (and some other easy challenges in the practice range), and the one introduced in the current season by getting to ~50 levels in the FREE battle pass. This is not something I like but it's not as unreasonable as others say (you don't pay with your money, you pay with your time).I don't care about the PVE, but some have legit concerns about that too.Of course, compared to the previous one-off payment for OW1 this is a downgrade, but not worthy of a (currently) "10% total positive reviews", especially considering much more infamous free to play models in other games.

Author: Stealth
Review Content:
Product received for free
Steam will not save you, BlizzardWhat is there to even say? The one co-op mission available to all is just a point-defense horde mode for the majority of the level. I wanted to stop playing after 5 minutes. The only reason Overwatch 2 is a thing is because Blizz had to implement a battle pass system to tip-toe around the new laws/regulations when it comes to loot boxes, and nobody can convince me otherwise. For example, loot boxes are outright illegal in multiple European countries like Belgium, Finland, and the Netherlands.The PVE experience that was supposed to be justification for this sequel has been completely scrapped, you know, the thing that they promised years ago. So why bother with this game? This is just as big of a scam as Destiny 2, with the exception of paid content being taken from you.

Author: ihunterjack
Review Content: Activision Blizzard lied. Overwatch 1 was great, the only problem was the loot boxes. Activision knew the laws would be changed to ban gambling, which is what the loot boxes are. So the came out with Overwatch 2. Overwatch 2 has no loot boxes BUT they force you to spend money on a pointless battle pass to play any of new heroes, and then they made those heroes overpowered so have to play them if you want to be competitive, if you don't pay your heals won't be as good, your damage won't be as good etc... it's a pay to win system, it sucks. They change you for everything! Skins, guns, MISSIONS!, just more and more way to charge you and get money out of you. I'm not talking nickle and dimes here I'm talking thousands of dollars to get what you randomly got for free.The only update that Overwatch 2 received was monetization. It's not as fun, you feel annoyed because of the constant and stupid battle pass, we don't want to pay for that crap multiple times a year... Activision Blizzard then lied about the content of the game, the modes, the mods, the specs... don't spend money on this game it's all a lie. Overwatch 1 was a better and more complete game and that was the problem, they hated on the fact that you got so much for free. I hope they enjoy people not playing any of their products. FYI Diablo 4 has much of the same predatory monetization going on too. None of this is fun, it's just a massive cash grab for Activision Blizzard stock holders.It might show that I played for .3 hours but over 1000 hours playing easily. It's a shame that activision blizzard is just another cash grab company. They sell you lies, take your money and then gaslight you into thinking you should not complain.

Author: Hezrou
Review Content: Blizzard promised PvE in OW2 which was their justification to kill OW1. It's basically OW1 with 5v5 rather than 6v6. Same game, same maps, same everything but now you pay 20$ for skins, forced FOMO down your throat so you're forced to play over and over and over again or risk losing out forever, predatory behavior and remember that PvE promise I mentioned earlier? Yeah. They lied about that. There is no PvE and they said they won't add it. They probably will eventually, but it's not their FOCUS like they said it would have been. They've scammed their fanbase, ruined what made OW great and gutted it entirely. The only reason they are on steam is because they're desperate for cows to milk. You want a good game? Go play TF2 or ANY other game on Steam. Trust me. You won't regret skipping tf out of this game. Blizzard is just looking for people to milk. Don't fall for the trap. Listen to the negative reviews, do your own research, AVOID THIS GAME AT ALL COSTS.

Author: Heroshi
Review Content: No. Save your time. Save your money.Overwatch "2" is a slap in the face, not only to fans of the original release, but the industry as a whole. It's an MTX riddled clownfest that has no respect for itself, or it's players.- The original director left abruptly before the game even came out. Massive red flag right there.- FOMO tactics and horrible MTX. Free players get very little.- Removed content and features the original game had, and added very little to compensate for it.- New characters are locked behind the battlepass. When the battlepass expires, you still have to go through an obnoxious unlock process. In a hero-based shooter that makes heavy use of counter picking, I don't need to tell you how bad this is for the health of the game.- The supposed reason the game was being developed, the PvE mode, was cancelled. You can still play the missions, but there is very little replay-ability behind them without the main, advertised feature. Not only this, they still have the gall to charge for them, and will likely continue to do so with future mission releases.- The game was changed from 6 v 6 into 5 v 5. This is subjective, but I believe it greatly harmed the game and sucked a lot of fun out of it. No one liked double shield, goats, etc etc, but the game has turned into a spammy brawl fest that has made playing both tanks and supports quite miserable.All of this is just scratching the surface. I really can't recommend the game, let alone support Blizzard. Go play another shooter.

Author: Green
Review Content: As someone who played the original Overwatch beta all those years ago and bought it on release (even got the physical origins edition) its sad to see the state the game has been left in. Overwatch 1 was a great game for probably about its first two years and then Blizzard went really hard into competitive and esports when the game is the most fun in a casual environment. Then they decided to kill Overwatch 1 for this sequel which is really nothing more than a larger sized update. They have added basically nothing new except micro-transactions and questionable balance changes. Sadly they have also removed any sort of way to play the original. I hope one day fans can make some sort of way to play Overwatch 1 in its early years again. At least Mei is still cute.
