Author: Waark
Review Content: I have 1000+ hours in Overwatch/Overwatch 2 (Battlenet) and this is what I can say about Overwatch compared to Overwarch 2♦︎ Overwatch- Amazing gameplay/visuals/audio/lore;- Respectfull team committed to the game;- This game had the best lootbox system available, you simply had to play. 1 level = 1 lootbox (about 4-5 games);- Free in game items, with the lootboxes and events; and you could also buy those with in game free currency;- It felt fun.♦︎ Overwatch 2- Amazing gameplay/visuals/audio/lore;- Cash grab, awful and frustrating monetization; somewhat good skins in the battlepass but the best ones are only available in the store;- Bunch of lies and empty promisses;- Certanily not fun to play against overpowerd heroes, that are locked behind a paywall/high battlepass level (45 out of 80);- It feels abandoned The game core is still intact, it can still be saved, but the problem is Blizzard, awfull executives who are only worried with how much they can bank with the game. We lost amazing team members, who really cared for this game, as a matter of fact most of the current members do really still care about the game, and it's future is, in the most part, out of their hands.Overwatch 2 should be a new and refreshed co-op version of the game with a bunch of repetable quest to develop the lore and give a better insight in the game story, and a skill tree to help creating new ways to play the game, simple as that.I miss 2017 overwatch

Author: Relic
Review Content: There are a lot of reviews about this game that don't really explain why everyone hates it so i'll do my best to explain it to people who are newer to this gameoverwatch 1 was an amazing game, one of my favorite games of all time. They had a controversial thing called lootboxes, which many people thought of as gambling, but what made it good was that everytime you leveled up, you got a lootbox. Which was always hypebut they replaced this with an awful battlepass. Somehow especially this season, they managed to make a bad mythic skin for their battlepass. This ana skin is beyond garbage, and the tier 1 version looks miles better than the last tier which doesn't really make any senseThey promised us with a huge pve aspect of the game, which was the whole point of overwatch 2. This was going to come later on a year or so after the games release. Nobody really liked that we had to wait, but were all hype for the eventual pve that we all thought was going to be amazing. Many people including me bought stuff thinking we would be able to use it in the pve, but turns out, it never was coming out. Blizzard knew it would not be possible when the game first came out, which they even admitted. This meant that they had people spend their money thinking they could use it in pve when Blizzard was just sitting back in a chair laughing at us knowing it was just all a scam. And yes, I think this is a scam. They led people on, knowing the only way they could get money was to lie to their fanbase. Which is why everyone has lost respect for this game and Blizzard. This game deserved to be review-bombed. Now that there is an actual way for people to give feedback about this game of course this was going to happen. Now, overwatch 2 is not the worst game out there like the reviews say. The gameplay in overwatch 1 was of course much better, and overwatch 2 is a downgrade. But it is still not horrible. If any of you reading this played total mayhem in overwatch 1, that is what overwatch 2 feels like. Everyone just is much harder to kill, and with 1 less tank, I think this is just worse and a lot less fun. It sucks they shut down overwatch 1 because i know almost everyone would rather go back to that. I dont think Blizzard can fix all these mistakes, and even though its sad, I think it may die in the coming years if its not dead already.

I have 1,500 hours in this game as only a casual fan and only recently have I been able to break the hold this game had on me for years. Do yourself a favor and don't even try this game. Author: ziggyflybone3
Review Content: If this is what us OW1 players waited 3 years for, than I have lost every morsel of hope I have for this IP. Each OWL team is about to receive a $6 Mill buyout and the league will collapse. This company cancelled the main vision of the game with the "Hero Mode" being scrapped. This mode was promised in 2019 and shown off years ago! Now all we get is a souped up "Archives" type of event that you have to PAY FOR! (Archives was a free mode in OW1, and this story mode in OW2 you have to pay $15 USD LOL) I'm going to say this is worse than Cyber Punk by a long shot! Please do yourself a favour and make some room on your SSD and uninstall this horrendous attempt at a sequel. Game of the year to now a game that has hyper monetization, locks heroes behind a battlepass and doesn't even give you the content you paid for.An importing thing to note: I have over 5,000+ hrs in this game and I feel like everyone especially new players have been treated like crap since the launch of OW2 in Oct 2022. I feel the worst for the Team 4 Devs that had to see their hard work get re organised into a sorry attempt to line Blizzard Exec's pockets and please investors. This is now the Blizzard standard.Spend your time on other games please, thank you.- ziggy

Author: Dimple
Review Content: Where to begin with this one. This is absolute garbage of the game. A lot of false promises, this is underdelivered and absolutely cheap cashgrab of a game. People here criticize mostly bad monetization, awful shop update, battlepass, no PvE and I agree with everything.But what I personally hate the most is the terrible matchmaking. Most of the games are so boring to play and they are one sided. Either you are winning too easily or the enemy team annihilates you easily. Fun and tense matches where it feels that anyone can win until the last moment almost don't exist. Also game is unbalanced as well.Overwatch 1 was one of the best shooters ever made and it is shameful that this game even carries this name.Btw $15 for PvE? Seriously, there is an hour of content with no replayability and if it was ow1 that would be free (ow archives).There is nothing else to say what already hasn't been said. Shame on you Blizzard.

Author: xcrimsonlegendx
Review Content: Honestly Overwatch was a great game. But OW2 is just a cash grab. There are no meaningful updates from the OW1 base game, it was just an excuse to add a grossly overpriced cash shop and free-to-play monetization scheme. The PvP didn't benefit from the change, the PvE certainly didn't benefit, the players didn't benefit. The only benefit was to the developer who gets to rake in the profits from $20 skins and battlepasses galore. All they really did was take OW1 and smear it with a heaping helping of FOMO and greed, then shove it out the door and expect everyone to lap it up.Then to put icing on the cake they cut the PvE content that was promised, the entire reason anyone was excited for OW2 and chop it up into little pieces missing most of the features and sell them to us piecemeal. The negative reviews for the most part aren't a campaign to reviewbomb the game, they're the honest feelings of a community that has been done wrong time and time again who now have a platform to express their grievances.

Author: TheSkyeLord
Review Content: I've only played this during Overwatch 2 as a friend got me into it, never touched OW1. I also have nearly 300 hours into the game (mostly on PS5 and a tiny bit on PC) when writing this. The game play is pretty fun, but man there are a lot of issues, like:- Forced 50/50 win rates. Can't I just play against people based on my skill/MMR level? Is it really that hard?- Competitive matchmaking just sucks. Why am I, who's in diamond, getting an all gold players team vs the enemy being all diamond players?- Where the f**k is the PvE mode?? I thought that was the whole point of this game coming out?- Monetization model is super awful (like, worse than CoD Advanced Warfare, how do y'all manage that???).- No looking for team, which makes the game feel pretty isolated unless you play with friends.- Terrible stats balancing, either the character is severely busted or outright unusable for most of the characters.And I'm sure there's more I could think of. I still have a fun time playing this game with friends but Blizzard really botched this game bad. I hope they try to fix the game and make it a lot better, but it feels too little to late. I don't wanna just pile on to the negative reviews the game already has, but it'll get a thumbs down from me due to Blizzard's blatant apathy and general disregard towards this game. It's been long known by a lot of Blizzard fans, but this game, along with other recent releases from them, really shows that Bluz is dead, and not what they used to be.

Author: doritos man
Review Content:
Product received for free
																Do this instead of playing this game.Easy homemade chicken ramen, with a flavorful broth, roasted chicken, fresh veggies, lots of noodles, and a soft cooked egg. Inspired by traditional Japanese ramen, but on the table in under an hour.Ingredients2 chicken breasts (boneless, skin-on)*kosher salt and freshly-ground black pepper, to season1 Tbsp unsalted butter2 tsp sesame or vegetable oil2 tsp fresh ginger, minced1 Tbsp fresh garlic, minced3 Tbsp low-sodium soy sauce2 Tbsp mirin4 cups rich chicken stock1 oz dried shltаke mushrooms (or 1/2 cup fresh)1–2 tsp sea salt, to taste2 large eggs1/2 cup scallions, sliced2 (3 oz) packs dried ramen noodlesoptional: fresh jalapeño or chili slices, for servingInstructionsCOOK THE CHICKEN: ¹Preheat the oven to 375℉. Season the chicken generously with salt and pepper.Melt the butter in a large oven-safe skillet over medium heat. Add the chicken, skin-side down, and cook until the skin is golden brown and releases easily from the pan, about 5-7 minutes. Flip the chicken over and cook for another 4-5 minutes, until golden.Transfer the skillet to the oven and roast for 15-20 minutes, until the chicken is cooked through. Remove from the oven, transfer the chicken to a plate, and cover with foil until ready to serve.MAKE THE RAMEN BROTH:Heat the oil in a large pot over medium heat until shimmering. Add the garlic and ginger, and cook for a few minutes until softened. Add the soy sauce and mirin, and stir to combine. Cook for another minute.Add the stock, cover, and bring to a boil. Remove the lid, and let simmer uncovered for 5 minutes, then add the dried mushrooms. Simmer gently for another 10 minutes, and season with salt, to taste.MAKE THE SOFT-BOILED EGGS:Fill a pot with enough water to cover the eggs, and bring to a boil. Gently lower the eggs (still cold from the fridge) into the boiling water, and let simmer for 7 minutes (for a slightly-runny yolk) or 8 minutes (for a soft, but set-up yolk).Meanwhile, fill a large bowl with ice water. When the timer finishes, transfer the eggs to the ice bath to stop the cooking process. Wait at least 5 minutes, or until cool enough to handle, then carefully peel away the shell and slice in half, lengthwise. Set aside until ready to serve.ASSEMBLE THE RAMEN BOWLS:Meanwhile, chop the scallions and jalapeño (if using). Slice the chicken into thin pieces. Set aside. When the eggs finish cooking, add the ramen noodles to the boiling water.Cook for 2-3 minutes, until soft, then divide the noodles into two large bowls. Add the sliced chicken and the ramen broth. Top with the fresh scallions, jalapeño, and the soft boiled egg. Serve immediately. Enjoy!!

Review Content:

																Ladies and gentlemen, it's time to crank up the volume and dive into a debate that will leave no room for doubt! DJ PROFESSOR K is here to make a bold statement: Jet Set Radio and TF2 are the real champions, while Overwatch 2... well, let's just say it falls short of the mark.Jet Set Radio, my friends, is a game that oozes style, originality, and pure rebellious spirit. It's a game that takes you on a wild ride through the streets of Tokyo-to, where you become a part of the GGs crew, skating, spraying graffiti, and sticking it to the man! The vibrant visuals, the infectious beats, and the freedom to express yourself make Jet Set Radio an unparalleled experience that keeps you coming back for more.Now, let's talk about Overwatch 2. Sure, it may have its flashy graphics and a dedicated fanbase, but let me ask you this: does it truly capture the essence of rebellion and individuality? Does it make you feel like you're part of something bigger, fighting against a monotonous world? I think not! Overwatch 2 may be a team-based shooter, but it lacks the soul, the heart, and the sheer audacity that Jet Set Radio brings to the table.And let's not forget about TF2, my friends! Team Fortress 2 is a timeless classic, a game that has stood the test of time and continues to captivate players with its unique characters, hilarious dialogue, and addictive gameplay. It's a game that embraces the wackiness, the humor, and the camaraderie that makes gaming truly special. TF2 knows how to keep you on your toes, how to make you laugh, and how to create a sense of community that Overwatch 2 simply can't match.So, my friends, if you're seeking a gaming experience that's vibrant, rebellious, and packed with personality, then it's time to put Overwatch 2 on the shelf and grab hold of Jet Set Radio and TF2! Let your creativity run wild, let your skills shine, and let the spirit of rebellion guide you to victory!DJ PROFESSOR K has spoken, and the verdict is clear. Jet Set Radio and TF2 are the games that will set your soul on fire, while Overwatch 2 falls flat in comparison. It's time to break free from the chains of conformity, my friends, and embrace the true spirit of gaming. So, grab your spray cans, lace up your skates, and let's paint the world with color, because in the battle between Jet Set Radio, TF2, and Overwatch 2, there's only one clear winner - the games that dare to defy the norm!

Author: Discount
Review Content: Been wanting to leave a negative review on this pile of trash since Overwatch 2's launch.Having stuck with the game for well over 6 years, the absolute mockery that Blizzard Entertainment have made of its entire playerbase is inexcusable. They see their customers only as wallets, and this game as a cow to be milked until it's dry and ready for slaughter.The egregious monetization present since the launch of the so-called "sequel" is what's driving this game into the dirt. The entire purpose of its existence, the massive PvE campaign it was supposed to have, has been scrapped in place of smaller missions costing $5 a pop at roughly 30 minutes playtime with zero replayability. Now they vow to "re-commit" to PvP, which is in its absolute worst state ever in terms of balancing, and characters locked behind paywalls at $9 each.This leaves Overwatch 2, in comparison to its predecessor, as a worthless money-grabbing shop update with changes to the core gameplay that only make it worse.Don't even bother. It's over.I've done my part!P.S. I dearly hope the art, animation, and writing teams for the game's story and cinematics can be hired onto a project they're passionate about, one that isn't careening into the Pacific.

Author: Venky BSc
Review Content: Overwatch 2 was supposed to be the sequel we were all eagerly waiting for, a chance for Blizzard to make amends for the missteps of the past and truly deliver on their promises. But what we got instead was a bitter disappointment that left me feeling completely ripped off.I had invested time and money into the original Overwatch, believing in Blizzard's commitment to the community. When they announced Overwatch 2, I was cautiously excited, hoping they would deliver on their promise of a free PvE mode to make up for the initial investment in the first game. However, they pulled a complete 180, charging us for content they once assured us would be complimentary.Microtransactions run rampant in Overwatch 2, turning a game that once celebrated fair in-game purchases into a cash-grabbing nightmare. The constant push to buy cosmetics and loot boxes has cheapened the experience and made it clear that Blizzard's focus is on squeezing every last penny out of players.But the biggest betrayal has been the lack of respect for loyal fans. We stood by Blizzard through thick and thin, only to be slapped in the face with a game that not only fails to meet expectations but also feels like a blatant cash grab. Closing down the original Overwatch was bad enough, but to then charge us for content we were initially promised for free is a new low.I can't recommend Overwatch 2 in its current state. It's a sad reminder of how a once-great franchise can crumble when greed takes over. I feel like a pawn in Blizzard's money-making scheme, and it's disheartening to see a game that was once beloved fall so far. Save your money and find a developer that respects their players more than their profits.

Author: hee ho
Review Content: It's a game.Thoughts on Overwatch 2: InvasionThe paid story missions should have been free, they're barebones and the plot is extremely scarce. There's potential there but it ends extremely quickly. As soon as you press the purchase button, you'll regret actually buying it. With the monetization they're doing, it's extremely scummy to also ask for money for story missions when there's also $20 dollar skins in the shop. Especially when the OW community has been waiting years for story missions. At the end of the 3 short missions, it has the audacity to ask you to upgrade your intial Invasion pack to the ultimate version. I feel like there should be some sort of apology to players who expected things from Blizzard but there will never be compensation or actual love towards the game, it's players or their own developers. At the least, I can only show love to the art team and past developers who have worked tirelessly only for Blizzard to throw that passion away.Overwatch 2?Overwatch is still a fun game despite the move to 5v5. There are a lot of problems and issues but if you want some quick fun, it's still Overwatch at the end of the day. The new player grind as a free-to-play is quite daunting though. I don't think they should time gate heroes for 32(?)+ games . (You have to win those games too so that'll be a while before you actually unlock everyone) I don't think it's pay-to-win and more so pay-for-convenience since you can actually unlock those characters for free. The main monetization draw are the skins and battle pass. The legendary shop skins are at a ludicrous 20 dollars, which is insane especially when it's for 1 character. Free to Play experienceSo, how free is it? You can get 60 coins per week. Don't expect to get anything as a free-to-play player. Pay up. I think the whole system is a step down from what was in OW1 which is the universal opinion right now. It focuses too much on FOMO and tries to lure you to the shop to buy things. It's decent if you want to play but if you want cosmetics be prepared to cough up money. FlashpointI want to say that it's on par with Push. Not too great or too bad. It's a mediocre game mode that can get confusing really quickly because of the large map and rotating spawns. Both maps have similar colors to me which kinda makes it feel like they're all 1 map. I still need to play more to get a good grasp of things but it's kinda middling right now.Final thoughtsI have lots of love towards Overwatch but I wish they could get their ♥♥♥♥ together for once. I love the game and everything about it but there are too many issues to actually recommend anyone this game with my full confidence. Maybe in the future when they tone down all this stuff, eh probably not it's Blizzard. 🫢🤮🤮🤮🤮

Author: Malakai*
Review Content: I'm glad to see the overwhelming negative reviews because this is exactly what Activision/Blizzard have been building up to in the latest years. Overwatch 2 it's barely an expansion more than a sequel and a downgrade in many other ways, along the broken promises.I've never been an Overwatch fan but I've been playing ocassionally since the first one. It's a decent casual game but to me it has always felt like one of those games that gets worse and worse the more you play it and how it's been handled only made that more evident.To me, it just lacks depth, the visuals design is rather terrible when it comes to visual clarity (huge ass weapon viewmodels, flashing lights all over, colorful maps that make the characters blend so they had to add an outline to everyone) and just boring encounters due to the healing and shields. Also, it has always felt like this team requires almost TOO much teamplay which means that playing with randoms is gonna be pure suffering for the most part.Another thing that never liked honestly is the "sanitized" aesthetic and characters which some people like but I've always thought that they were terribly lame and corporate which is sorta confirmed the moment we knew there was a diversity chart to build them. OW2 is just all of that once again, but now with a sorry excuse of a PvE mode and terrible monetization with skins that don't even look good compared to the ones they had previously. Game feels polished and runs incredibly well but does that matter when it's not that fun and it's being handled like this?

Author: eco🔰chocolatcchi
Review Content: I don't care about the PVE content fiasco. Each "limited time" PVE event they did so far was middling at best. Still a horribly mismanaged live service title that was far more enjoyable in its first year than now. Its not exactly that I disagreed with the game's vision, but more so OW had years of number adjustment balance patches all done by a balance team with obviously didn't play the game outside of "work". I don't like MOBAs so my hot/cold take is that the 24 at launch was more than enough heroes, we didn't need a content dripfeed where we'll get at least two heroes between every new map.The big positives is the hit detection and overbearing moderation were annoying for 2016 standards, but compared to the cuckholding experience of modern FPS titles its not all too bad, people can still release some "steam" in chat. I also hit 165fps @1440p stable on my ancient PC so the optimization team deserves some credit.

SBM isn't there to ensure you have a "fair and balanced" experience, it's there to ensure you're always going to sweat your brains out and rage.

Author: the Doodler
Review Content: Do not play this game. Do not install this game. Stay at the very least 50 meters away from a copy of this game, in fact. while Overwatch 1 may have been fun to play sometimes (not even all times), this game just sucks, plain and simple. This is mostly due to the developers and CEO Bobby Kotick's literal incompetency at managing this "game" unfortunately.-the PvE was promised in 2019 was cancelled and blizzard only told us in 2023 and knew it was CANCELLED before OW2 was even released in the first place, back in October 5th 2022-the """PvE""" that was given to us has a total of 102 minutes of content over three "missions" when you pay ~15€ for it, and you'll have to keep paying to get the other missions. this means for three batches of these missions you'll pay a total of 45€ after three seasons IF you only buy the missions and no battle passes, almost as much as a normal AAA game with a full blown story mode, while for that much you get 5 hours not including cut-scenes.-the """PvE""" missions which as mentioned previously you HAVE TO PAY FOR are literally comparable to the previous archive events shown in previous events in Overwatch 1, with the exception that those were FREE OF CHARGE, as they should've been in the first place seeing as they are linear and the AI of the enemies (and teammates if you are playing with bots) is dumber than a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ brick-heroes, which is something pretty ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ useful to be available in a HERO BASED 1ST PERSON SHOOTER, are locked behind an impossible grind or you can just use money to unlock with premium battle passes.-the shift from a loot box system which you could earn to a battle pass you must PAY to have-the lack of ANY premium currency in said battle pass, making it so you need to pay every season actual money for the battle pass, unlike damn near every game that has a battle pass nowadays. if fortnite does it better than you, then you messed up-skins which were originally a small grind to do now take over 400 years to unlock them all. Or, if you'd prefer, you can simply hand Blizzard OVER TWELVE THOUSAND DOLLARS TO UNLOCK THEM-balancing in this game is pretty much non-existent, with new heroes (which as mentioned above, are locked behind the battle pass) being overwhelmingly powerful against almost any other hero, while others get hit with the nerf hammer harder than anything-the competitive scene is literally being destroyed by Blizzard since it started losing money, so ♥♥♥♥ it might as well nuke it into oblivion-despite the terrible "attempts" blizzard did to stomp out the toxicity in this game, the game is still a toxic wasteland comparable to league of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ legends-the game heavily encourages counter-picking heroes over actual skill, which can be annoying if you're really good with a specific hero and the enemy team chooses the hard counter then you're ♥♥♥♥♥♥. this means the game HEAVILY encourages you being a Jack of all Trades instead of just playing with a hero you may like and/or play better with.Blizzard does not care for the game as it is plainly obvious. Just stay away from this "game", if you can even call it that. this isn't a game. its a poor attempt at an update disguised as a game by Blizzard to get off a controversy back in 2019 when Blitzchung was kicked off a Heartstone tournament by siding with Hong Kong during the protests at the time, and nowadays a poor attempt at getting to your wallet. go play almost literally anything else and i guarantee you'll have a better time with it than with this lazy, poor attempt at reviving a game that became a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ attempt at a cash grab. this is Diablo Immortal all over again, but Blizzard is trying to be just a tiny bit less ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ shameless than with that poor excuse for a "sequel". just do not get anywhere near close this thing.

Author: bidiBuzz
Review Content: In 2014 when the first cinematic of Overwatch came out, I immediatly fell in love with this future IP. Beautiful, heroes, story and Ideas! Blizzard was going to make another masterclass of a game, and oh boy, what a game. In may 2016, when the game released I was overhyped, I even take a day out sick of school to play it all day long. That was amazing. Yes, lootbox system, it was feeling weird in a Blizzard game. That wasn't much of an issue to be honest. I then spent those last 7 years playing a lot of Overwatch (roughly 5000 hours). I got myself into esport in my country and it was beautiful I was enjoying the game so much even though he had some pretty important problem of balancing. In 2017 I started to dream of a campaign for such a game, Imagine ? That could be so f***** awesome no ?. And boom 2 years later ow2 is announced with all the PVE part. story mission, hero mission, new gamemodes, new maps, new characters. That was incredible, I was so hyped, and so confident into team 4. They did an amazing work on the pvp, and what they started to show us was really promising. Then we got asked to wait, 1 year, 2 years, 3 years, 3. 75 years... We had promicies, we had hope and we had the envy to discover that. Well, kinda delusional isn't it ? I will never say that they lied to us, because they didn't, Jeff and his team didn't lie to us they were really gonna bring us what they told us, I'm sure about that. The thing is, everyone left, Jeff and almost his whole crew of amazing devs left the ship. We lost a lot with thoses departures. we lost the vision of the game, talented creators, we lost hope... The actual devs are doing an amazing work, they are doing what they are tasked and they are doing it beautifully, but I'm sure they want to show us more. As a 3D artist myself, I know how passionate we are when we are on a project, all the hours of work we put to deliver something big, for people that will play it, or watch it just because we want to make them dream. It's a job of passion so I don't doubt a second. INVASIONInvasion? Well, at first I was positively surprised, new amazing maps, new amazing character, a sort of archive mission for free, this new progression system and those 3 story missions... Well i was waiting for a campaign no ? Cool, I guess I'll buy them and see what it is apparently it's not that bad, right ? Mmmmmh... The issue is that those missions are the missions team 4 was working on back in 2019 as tests. First mission, Rio well cool little mission no ? It's exactly the same mission than the one people in blizzcon 2019 had the chance to play, but without the little talent tree thing. Back then, players said to dev that it was fun but it was still a bit to simple, and they aggreed. So why we have access to less good than this experience today, august 2023 ? I'm gonna be honest, I enjoyed my time playing this missions and watching those new little cutscenes during the experience, it was fun. Some stuff is terrible though, AI is horrible and overall effort of presentation is less good than last archives missions. But the worst is that we have to pay 15 bucks for theses unfinished missions, because I'm sorry, they look like they are finished but they aren't. Devs had to use stuff that was in test in 2019, clean up in a hurry and throw it in the game to make people pay 15 bucks... and now ? Well we have to wait again, we don't even know how long, for the next chapter, whiches the one we saw in blizzcon 2021... So again, it's probably done already even if they have to polish the experience. i'm really sad with what this amazing IP has become. At the moment the game is actually good, pve is quite fun even though you'll probably only play it once, pvp is good, with nice balancing, nice new maps and nice new heroes, so it's fine, but this whole Idea of monetizing every bit of the game... it sickens me... Once again, I still believe the devs are doing a great job. But the decisions taken by Blizzard are hurting. They hurt their players, their employees and soon their precious investors. As a great man once said : "Never accept the world as it appears to be, dare to see it for what it could be."

Author: ThatFatCat38
Review Content: blizzard bad :(how to cook methMaking Methamphetamine at home:List of chemicals and materials: Diluted HCl - also called Muriatic acid - can be obtained from hardware stores, in the pool sectionNaOH - also called lyeEthyl Ether - aka Diethyl Ether - Et-0-Et - can be obtained from engine starting fluid, usually from a large supermarket. Look for one that says "high ethyl ether content", such as PrestoneEphedrine The cottons in todays vicks nasle inhalers dont contain efed or pfed (ephedrin or psuedoephedrin) but there are still lots of easy ways to get good ephed or pfed, pure ephedrin can be extracted out of it's plant matter, from a plant that can be bought at most garden stores. Or you can get pfed from decongestive pills like sudafed. Most people perfer to work with pfed from pills rather then ephed from the plant. The important thing is that you must have pure pfed/ephed as any contaminants will ♥♥♥♥ up the molar ratio leaving you with over-reduced ♥♥♥♥ or under-reduced ♥♥♥♥. Or contaminats will jell durring baseifying and gak up your product which will then be very hard to clean. So you want to find a pill that is nearly pure pfed hcl, or as close to pure as you can get. Also check the lable on your pills and see what inactive ingredients they contain. Inactive ingredients are things like binders and flavors. These you dont want and will remove when cleaning your pills. but certain inactive ingredients are harder to remove then others. You dont want pills with a red coating, you dont want pills with alot of cellose in them and you dont want pills with much wax. you also dont want pills that contain povidone. As a rule, if you have a two pills that contain the same amount of pfed hcl then take the smaller sized pill because it obviously has less binders and inactive ingredients, time released pills are usualy harder to work with because they have more binders and tend to gel up durring the a/b stage. Also only buy pills that have pfed hcl as the only active ingredient. You first have to make ephedrine (which is sometimes sold as meth by itself):If you are selling it...I would just make ephedrine and say it's meth.Distilled water - it's really cheap, so you have no reason to use the nasty stuff from the tap. Do things right.List of equipment : A glass eyedropperThree small glass bottles with lids (approx. 3 oz., but not important)one should be marked at 1.5oz, use tape on the outside to mark it (you might want to label it as ether). One should be clear (and it can't be the marked one).A Pyrex dish (the meatloaf one is suggested)A glass quart jarSharp scissorsClean rubber glovesCoffee filtersA measuring cupMeasuring spoonsPreparing your Lab:Preparing Ethyl Ether: WARNING: Ethyl Ether is very flammable and is heavier than air. Do not use ethyl ether near flame or non-sparkless motors. It is also an anaesthetic and can cause respiratory collapse if you inhale too much.Take the unmarked small bottle and spray starter fluid in it until it looks half-full. Then fill the rest of the way with water, cap the bottle and shake for 5 minutes. Let it sit for a minute or two, and tap the side to try and separate the clear upper layer. Then, draw off the top (ether) layer with the eyedropper, and throw away the lower (water) and cloudy layer. Place the ether in the marked container. Repeat this until you have about 1.5 oz. of ether. Put the cap on it, and put it in the freezer if you can. Rinse the other bottle and let it stand.Ethyl ether is very pungent. Even a small evaporated amount is quite noticeable.Ephedrine & or P-Ephedrine: Please discuss this on the neonjoint forum5. Pour 1/8 teaspoon of the lye crystals into the bottle of ephedrine and agitate. Do this carefully, as the mixture will become hot, and give off hydrogen gas and/or steam. H2 gas is explosive and lighter than air, avoid any flames as usual. Repeat this step until the mixture remains cloudy. This step neutralizes the HCl in the salt, leaving the insoluble free base (l-desoxyephedrine) again. Why do we do this? So that we can get rid of any water-soluble impurities. For 3 oz. bottles, this should take only 3 repetitions or so.6. Fill the bottle from step 5 up the rest of the way with ethyl ether. Cap the bottle, and agitate for about 8 minutes. It is very important to expose every molecule of the free-base to the ether for as long as possible. This will cause the free base to dissolve into the ether (it -is- soluble in ether).7. Let the mixture settle. There will be a middle layer that is very thick. Tap the side of the bottle to get this layer as thin as possible. This is why this bottle should be clear.8. Remove the top (ether) layer with the eyedropper, being careful not to get any of the middle layer in it. Place the removed ether layer into a third bottle.9. Add to the third bottle enough water to fill it half-way and about 5 drops of muriatic acid. Cap it. Shake the bottle for 2 minutes. When it settles, remove the top layer and throw it away. The free base has now been bonded to the HCl again, forming a water soluble salt. This time, we're getting rid of ether-soluble impurities. Make sure to get rid of all the ether before going to step 11!10. If there is anything left from step 3, repeat the procedure with it.11. Evaporate the solution in the Pyrex dish on low heat. You can do this on the stove or nuke it in the microwave (be careful of splashing), but I have found that if you leave it on top of a hot-water heater (like the one that supplies hot water to your house) for about 2-3 days, the remaining crystals will be ephedrine HCl.If you microwave it, I suggest no more than 5-10s at one time. If it starts "popping", that means you have too little liquid left to microwave. You can put it under a bright (100W) lamp instead. Microwaving can result in uneven heating, anyway.First Batch: 120mg ephedrine HClEstimated: 300mg (100% of theoretical, disregarding HCl)Now, Making Methamphetamine out of ephedrine by reducing it with Hydroiodic Acid and Red Phosphorus.Items needed: Alot of matchbooks (the kind with the striking pad)Coffee filters (or filter paper)Something that measures ml and gramsA flask (a small pot with a lid can be used)iodineHydroiodic Acid (I will tell you how to make this)Red Phosphorus (I will tell you how to make this)Lye*Optional (toluene and HCI gas)Making Red Phosphorus: The striking pad on books of matches is about 50% red phosphorus. The determined experimenter could obtain a pile of red phosphorus by scraping off the striking pads of matchbooks with a sharp knife. A typical composition of the striking pad is about 50% red phosphorus, along with about 30% antimony sulfide, and lesser amounts of glue, iron oxide, MnO2, and glass powder. I don't think these contaminants will seriously interfere with the reaction. Naturally, it is a tedious process to get large amounts of red phosphorus by scraping the striking pads off matchbooks, but who cares?Making Hydroiodic Acid: This is made by mixing iodine and red phosphorus. When making hydroiodic acid from iodine and red phosphorus, the acid is prepared first, and allowed to come to complete reaction for 20 minutes before adding the ephedrine to it. The way around the roadblock here is to just boil off some more of the water from the ephedrine extract, and make the acid mixture in fresh pure water. Since the production of HI from iodine and red phosphorus gives off a good deal of heat, it is wise to chill the mixture in ice, and slowly add the iodine crystals to the red phosphorus-water mixture.Now, Making Methamphetamine: To do the reaction, a 1000 ml round bottom flask is filled with 150 grams of ephedrine. Also added to the flask are 40 grams of red phosphorus and 340 ml of 47% hydroiodic acid. This same acid and red phosphorus mixture can be prepared from adding 150 grams of iodine crystals to 150 grams of red phosphorus in 300 ml

Author: Dision
Review Content: I used to be a big fan of Overwatch back when it was an actual game and not a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ service.My story with Overwatch began in 2017 with the Anniversary. I only knew Team Fortress 2 and didn't have any interest in Overwatch until a friend convinced me to give it a chance during the free weekend of the Anniversary event. I immediately fell in love with the game, just everything: The gameplay, the sound design, the characters, the graphics, the high skill ceiling for many of the heroes. I was somewhat lost for a regular game and at this moment I found it in Overwatch. I remember spending the following nights awake playing Overwatch just because it was so much fun for me. I still remember being dead tired on Volskaya playing Widowmaker at like 5 AM. I was addicted in the best way possible.Over the years we gathered more and more players amongst our group of friends. Sometimes we'd only queue with two people, sometimes with a full team. I used to play every evening after coming home from school and later university. Overwatch was with me through a large portion of my life and with Overwatch I got my girlfriend into PC gaming. Even when other friends left the game for a while, they would return sooner or later, in Overwatch we had something like a mutual home. And even when everyone was playing something else, I still played Overwatch with my girlfriend almost everyday. I amassed something around 800 hours and had a silver potrait. Sometimes I got bored and thought to myself, I should at least get a gold portrait before leaving the game entirely someday. I also got into ranked with time but never spent as much time on it as I wanted to - too little motivation, too little time. But I felt like the game was the best when either you were playing with friends or you were tryharding your butt off in competitive. And I will never forget the countless hours I spent playing 3v3 with my friends, even having an 11 game winstreak once. I remember us grinding the coop stuff like "Junkenstein's Revenge" and the archives missions for hours on end. I knew and somewhat loved almost every character and was able to play them in a presentable manner. Hitscan heroes were my favorites and I became an Ana OTP with time peaking high plat with the little time I actually spent grinding, wish I played more. With time I even invested time into watching the Overwatch League with the San Francisco Shock becoming my favorite team after witnessing their win over Soeul Dynasty in 2020. The team consisting of players I all liked, legends like ANS and the streamer Super. Overwatch 1 was the sole reason I upgraded my PC. At university for becoming a teacher I even made a video presenting ways to utilize Overwatch for language learning.So, I stopped playing when Overwatch 2 launched. I still vividly remember the last ranked game of Overwatch 1 I played on Blizzard World and my last game in general on Lijiang Tower sitting in Discord with my group of friends. I remember everything being shutdown and people typing stuff like "Love you all", "See you on the other side" in the general chat. Overwatch 2 came and I just didn't want to play anymore, I just hated almost everything about it. And so did my friends. All of us moved on from the game, none of us are playing it anymore, all since Overwatch 2. I'm sure somewhere in there, the game is still fun but we just don't feel it anymore. Amongst the thing we absolutely hate are:-The monetization being changed to battle passes and overpriced shops (Lootboxes were a lot more fair to consumers)-The UI losing its personality (including stuff like the "On Fire"-Mechanic, the symbols for ranks, the player portraits and so much more)-The balancing and change to 5 Players (Game just feels different, feels bad and unfun. And yes, I loved playing Reinhardt Zarya with my gf)-The fact that they basically cancelled the PvE they promised, making the idea of "Overwatch 2" obsolete-The change to free to play-Not being able to see progress made in Overwatch 1 (like prior ranked seasons and stuff like that)There are probably twenty more things I could say that I despise about Overwatch 2 but the one thing I hate the most and the one reason I even care about all of this is that they took Overwatch 1 away for this. The very product we paid money for and learned to love was taken away and replaced with this abomination of a service. After Overwatch 2, I never really touched the game again and just dropped it, just like my friends. We all just accepted Overwatch to be dead and moved on. We transitioned to other games, especially League of Legends but still have not yet found another game to include us all like Overwatch 1 did. Seeing gameplay of Overwatch 1 now just hurts because I guess we did not really understand and appreciate what we really had.So, why did I write this review and why do I have 0.4 hours in the game on Steam? I wanted to write part of my story down and share it with everyone and do my part in leaving a negative review. The reason I have 0.4 hours is because I left the gaming running while taking a massive dump, thinking about how much I hate this game. Unless we get Overwatch 1 back or some sort of "Overwatch Classic", I will not return. ♥♥♥♥ you, Blizzard

Author: AuraPSX
Review Content: Been a player since Overwatch released and I'm just here to leave my negative review because there finally is a way for me to voice my dissatisfaction with the absolute disappointment and mess that Blizzard made of Overwatch.I have never seen a developer not just ruin their reputation, but entirely fumble one of the best Multiplayer games to release in the last years this hard.Overwatch 2 is a complete downgrade of Overwatch 1 in almost every way:- Everything is locked behind a Battlepass with the design being based on FOMO so that you buy into it.- No more lootboxes, all of your lootboxes get/got opened and the only way to get anything in the game now is from the Battlepass tracks, or to grind for the near-useless ingame currency that takes you 100 hours of play to even unlock a basic skin.- Matches have been changes from the classic 6v6 to 5v5 and cut one tank from each Team, making the game a lot more boringAnd there are plenty more issues that I haven't bothered to type here and/or document because I'm quite honestly just done with Overwatch as a whole. I'll probably play a few hours on the Steam Version just to see of the changes made since the Overwatch 2's """launch""" but I doubt my mind will be changed much. If at all.

Author: NotYourWaifu
Review Content: You might think people are review bombing OW2 on Steam but it is far from truth. While it seems like it, it is a silenced voice of many people that were (and still are) dissatisfied with Blizzard-Activision policy of censorship and development. These voices and negative opinions were present for many years, but Blizz are very good at buying reviews, deleting negative ones and not letting anything even mildly negative stay on their forums for more than a few hours. That's called censorship and this corporation is very good at doing it, starting from Diablo 3 or even earlier. Negative opinions about Overwatch have been present for years, they just kept being swept under the carpet, so people that are not familiar with it could see only good reviews and then buy/try it and perhaps leave some more $$$ in the form of microtransactions.I have more than 3000h played in OW1. It was a blast back in 2016/2017. I really enjoyed this game even when i kept losing, and losing a lot since i'm not that good at shooter games. But when you like something even constant losing can't stop you from having fun. But now i can't really force myself to play it. It sucks. I don't mind racist, trans/homophobes, afker and toxic people that will make your day worse - i had long experience playing multiplayer games and i'm somewhat thick-skinned when it comes to "loud people" in pvp games. They exist and not even big price tag will make them disapppear. But the game is just not the same - it lost its shine and individuality. It shouldn't be an issue if you never tried Overwatch since you have nothing to compare to. You definitely can have fun in Overwatch 2. It is game worth trying especially now that it is free to play. Game wise it hasn't changed its core that much for all these years and i bet a lot of people could enjoy it. On top of that they seems very progressive and supporting LGBTQIA+ (personally i don't like it - companies that are keep making poor decisions shield themselves with being pride-friendly to keep people(and their money) in game but proceeding with poor choices that are rainbowcolored. In the end it seems like it is bad for game development and for LGBTQIA+ community in the long-run since we can't know for sure if they really support this community or is it just to get more cash from rainbow-painted facade). Like...do they support LGBTQIA+ in the middle-east? Why they don't fight for their rights there if they are so pride-supportive?I recommend you to try OW2, you might enjoy the game but watch out for toxic people. Play with friends for better experience. I personally lost any interest in this game. They hide their past mistakes by adding "2" to the title promoting it like it is completely new game, switching grindable lootboxes for real-cash only battle pass pissing on their loyal but poor part of community and abandoning overwatch league cause it is not profitable anymore (insert toy story "i don't want to play with you anymore" meme)Blizzard-Activision is not worth supporting my dudes - they are getting worse and worse with each and every next big decision they make. Sad to see, but maybe it is time for new king of video games?Oh, and don't forget about 2019-2021 Blizzard sexual harassment lawsuit[knowyourmeme.com]. Internet remembers.

Author: ♡RoxyPaw♡
Review Content: I have played this game since Season 3 of the Original Overwatch. I was absolutely in love with the game, the changes, the new heroes, the small PvE events we got and I loved that the Lootboxes were optional in terms of whether you'd buy them with real life currency, or play the game, level up, and get lootboxes that way. I loved the entire mechanic of it, free lootboxes, level system, the rank system wasn't absolute gopshite and people genuinely enjoyed the game, even when raging, being toxic and what else you can expect in a competitive game.What ruined this entire game, was the content drought, the empty promises of a seperate game named "Overwatch 2" that would be PvE only, for us PvE andies to enjoy without ruining the aspect of the actual PvP game we all know and love.We all believed that they would keep their promise of making this huge, openworld-ish, amazing skill-tree PvE and we were all EXCITED for it. I, like many others, bought the Pre-Release game pass/DLC/whatever you want to call it at this rate, in hopes that my money would go into making that and like many others, I was severely let down when Blizzard announced Overwatch 2.It was Overwatch, but no level system, no lootboxes, no new conent besides for updated graphics and one less teammate in the game's gamemodes. That was all we were getting at the start. Then, a year of nothing later, get bombed with "We're cancelling it, sorry guys bye" and that was it.Due to the huge backlash, they've now decided to release these tiny PvE events and new weird hero level systems that are merely a bandaid ontop of a large flesh wound that really isn't doing anything to fix what they did. Also, the Battlepass. I don't even wanna f*cking talk about that.And that's just ONE of the "Big Game Company" Activision Blizzard's Games, without actually going into the whole mess that is the Company itself. My god.

Author: StarryLuna
Review Content: I've played Overwatch from 2017 and reached Grandmaster rank on Competitive, so I want to take my frustration in this space. (Still playing on battle.net, but trying the Steam one just for reviewing it)I don't know what Blizzard think. If they want to put "2" in title for just making it 5v5 and free to play, sure. But don't give us a false hope on PvE content. The hype in that number "2" was the promising PvE, and now what we've got? Invasion? the one that's good in it just the cinematic cutscenes.I still play this just because I have friends to play with. But I DO NOT recommend this at all for people who wants some lore or story that they PROMISED. just enjoy the cinematic, comic and such. but the game? if it's competitive one that you want, sure, go on. But if you come to play for lore and such, Blizzard already let us down.And don't make me started about reward system and cosmetics. I miss loot boxes that gave us the feeling that the game gave us rewards of playing it. Now? God... nothing to reward you, how hard you play, how you want to queue that role that is short of players (often tanks). just 'exp for battle pass' bs. Oh, and the coins for weekly.. the only thing that can make us get BP for free is to play almost 2 seasons of OW with all weekly done. Even after buying with real money for 10 USD, there is some.. emptiness. It feels pointless except if you really REAAAALLLY want to get that mythic skin on BP. It feels not rewarding, the lies, the frustration. name it all. Overwatch has it.Once more for TLDR: If you want to play for competitive, go on, you can try, just make sure to look at patch notes, your main hero at some point can be really OP and be really weak. If you want lore, forget it, enjoy the cinematic shorts, comics and short stories, don't hope for the game. they don't care about putting the story on the game properly, just the cash.

Author: Makima
Review Content: Alright, let's actually provide a constructive review. Why are people "review bombing" Overwatch 2?We paid for Overwatch, we supported it throughout its lifespan, it was popular and liked by its community, and turning a happy profit each year.When Blizzard announced Overwatch 2, the big new feature they announced, the entire premise that made it "worth the sequel treatment" was the PvE campaign mode. Hero talent trees, customizable abilities, an expansive co-op campaign that would add to the story and lore. We were told it was going to be so much work that they wouldn't be putting out updates for Overwatch any more, they were re-allocating the staff to work on this new project.With no updates, and no content, Overwatch started to get stale... people grew tired and bored, spending less time in the game, or moving on. Many of us stuck with the product, playing a little each week just to keep fresh... waiting for the new campaign mode. For a lot of us, playing became a chore, something we were doing out of habit, so we'd be ready for the new campaign...But the new campaign wasn't the premise that established OW2, it was the pretext. It was a lie. Blizzard abandoned the PvE campaign a full YEAR before OW2 launched - but continued to push it in marketing as the big new feature. It's even in the announcement trailer for OW2, and on the roadmaps. They knew they'd canned it 12 months earlier, but they knew that's what people wanted, so kept putting it front and centre to get people's money, to get people to buy into the project. They took our trust and monetized it.-----What does OW2 ACTUALLY offer then? What did they work on for those two years that was so important that they couldn't make content for OW1, the product people paid for and were supporting?1) They overhauled the graphical engine:Before, Overwatch would play on a relatively low spec computer, and it'd be smooth. Now, it stutters and stammers in the menus. They've added this weird shiny plastic finish to everything in the world, heroes and environment alike - so where before, heros would "pop" against the background and be easy to follow, now everything has the same texture to it, and it all merges together into visual noise - especially at longer ranges. They've compensated for how bad this looks by adding lots of additional flashy effects and explosions, that makes it much harder to see anything amidst the chaos. A PvP game at this pace relies heavily on quick disambiguation of what you're looking at, so you can react and compete, and the new engine makes this impossible without turning all the effects back off... meaning that the two years of development is for a feature best disabled.The new engine also has a weird slippery "feel" to it. Reviewers who'd played Overwatch for 50 hours came into Overwatch 2 and reported "look! it's the same Overwatch you love, but it's F2P now! Just ignore the monetization and you can play this great game for free!" Established long term players with thousands of hours were on reddit complaining that their hitboxes were all over the place and shots that would previously "feel" like a dead certain hit were just completely whiffing, and they didn't understand why. All the timings are messed up.2) They reworked most of the heroes:TLDR: they screwed up the game balance. Previously, one of the biggest appeals of Overwatch was that you could find a hero that suited your play style, and main them, getting good at whatever suited you best. Some people like sniping, or hitscan run and gun, some people aren't good at reactionary aim and instead liked to focus on positioning, tactics and strategy. You could make a big positive different to your team by playing lucio or mercy, and paying attention to your surroundings, and positioning yourself in the right place at the right time to make the difference.With Overwatch 2, the damage and healing behaviour has been reworked heavily. Now, the one tank on the team is insanely chunky, and it's near impossible to kill them quickly - with healer support, they can just stand in the line of fire and laugh. Everyone else dies almost immediately, regardless of who their aggressor is.Team-fighting now is very one-note, you have one tank who's immortal if they have support, and you have four hitscan DPS characters following them - there's not a lot of difference between supports and DPS characters. The teams try to pick off the other team's DPS/Support characters, and when they pick a few off, they can finish the tank and take the objective. Repeat. There's no room for variation in play style at all, you either play a DPS and try to kill the other team DPS, or you play a tank, and try to position correctly - maybe picking off an enemy hero that gets too close to you.I understand a lot of this came from feedback at the professional levels, where support players were complaining that they wanted to have more direct impact in teamfights, they wanted the game to feel more like other FPS games - but for a large portion of Overwatch's playerbase specifically, the appeal of the game was that you could do something else and still matter.3. They got INCREDIBLY greedy with the monetization...It's a longstanding argument that lootboxes are terrible in modern gaming... but Overwatch was one of the few examples of Lootboxes done right. Most of the long-term players of the game actually liked the system, that just rewarded you for playing the game and let you unlock whatever content you wanted relatively quickly. I started playing OW1 with the first anniversary, cleared the weekly boxes from arcade every week, and at the launch of OW2, I owned every single item in the game. Those who didn't have the time to invest in doing everything could still quickly unlock specific items they wanted (and let's be honest, when you have your favourite skin, how much do you care about unlocking other skins?) - and those who didn't want to spend hours unlocking stuff could spend a little cash to get it - if they wanted to.The new system puts almost everything behind a paywall. The minute number of cosmetics on the "free" track are often insultingly lazy, simple recolours or minor alterations, while they put serious effort into skins that you can only buy for $20. The content you can unlock by grinding often feels like it only exists to drag you into interfaces that advertise the paid content for you. Even content from the first game, that was originally free, is now paid only.Battlepass systems suck. "Pay us for the opportunity to unlock stuff if you play a lot. If you don't you have to pay us more, or lose the stuff you already paid for." - Limited time deals, rotating shop offers, FOMO FOMO FOMO... it reeks of manipulation and insincerity.4. Occasional DLC packs of PvE adventures.These are Blizzard's "new" approach to PvE. Occasional mission packs where you can get a little bit of story and a PvE mission. You can pay (in my UK currency) £13 for the DLC pack, or £35 (the cost of a good indie game" for the "ultimate bundle".So here's the thing - this content is the same amount of content, and the same pace of release as the old mission scenarios - it's just now, instead of them being a free event to get people excited about playing and encourage their friends to join up - now they're paid DLC.Nobody likes paying a regular subscription for a product that they previously owned completely. It doesn't make anyone like Adobe Photoshop or Microsoft Office, and it doesn't make anyone like Blizzard.-----So this is why people are "review bombing" your game. You took something we paid for, supported and enjoyed for years, lied to us about your plans, and turned it into trash. Now you're telling us to pay for features and content we previously enjoyed in the game we paid for. It's greedy, it's cynical, it's manipulative, and you've lost our trust.Also you should fire Bobby Kotick.

Author: 「OMX」Eragon
Review Content: I've loved playing Overwatch since the beginning. But when Overwatch 2 came out, things changed, and not in a good way. It feels like they don't care about how much time players spend. Doing daily and weekly missions takes up a lot of time, but the rewards aren't worth it. It's disappointing because it seems like the developers care more about money than what players want. This shift has made the game less enjoyable and more like work, and it's not the same as it used to be. the developer just want your money and has no respect of what the players want anymore. Everything you will want in the game you wall have to pay for every week and every month and every season.

Author: 匚ソケム 乃レソムナ
Review Content: Overwatch players had been waiting for 2 years with barely any updates to OW1. Here's what they've got in OW2:- Loot boxes, which used to provide rewarding & nearly infinite progression to all OW1 players, were replaced with battle passes. Now if you want to be rewarded, you have to pay money every 2 months & turn your game into a part-time job, because the pass will expire at the end of a season.- New Heroes are now locked behind battle passes. A major aspect of Overwatch's core gameplay is switching heroes & adapting to the situation. This change goes against that core gameplay, put new players & those who don't want to pay money in a major disadvantage.- PVE, the major selling point of Overwatch 2, was cancelled. Blizzard is now asking you $15 for a handful of missions, with no features teased during OW2's development such as skill trees.Can't believe I'm gonna write this, but I miss Jeff Kaplan, I miss loot boxes. I'd rather learn C++ & Data structures instead of playing this "sequel".We live in a timeline where our favorite game franchises are being ruined by greed. We're in the wrong timeline, lads.

Furthermore, a lot of cosmetic packs contains ♥♥♥♥ nobody asked for or wants(what's the point of souvenirs??) just to artificially inflate the already predatory prices further. I believe there used to be a pack for $42 that included 2 skins and some other gaudy garbage.1/10.

Author: Frilly Carpet
Review Content: [Shot opens on ringing alarm bell; sirens and klaxons play in the background]The Administrator: "Intruder Alert! A RED Spy is in the base!"[Signs illuminate on a large security panel: "Intruder Alert', 'RED Spy' and 'In Base'; pull out to reveal the BLU Soldier watching the board]Soldier: "A RED Spy is in the base!?"[Intruder Alert begins to play. The Soldier reaches from off-screen and pulls a Shotgun off a rack of weapons. Cut to the Soldier dashing down the stairs and through the 2Fort sublevel while saying "Hut, Hut, Hut!" with every step he takes]The Administrator: "Protect the briefcase!"Soldier: "We need to protect the briefcase!"[Camera pans to reveal the BLU Scout trying to open the code-locked 'Briefcase Room' door]Scout: "Yo, a lil' help here!?"[The Soldier pushes the Scout aside and begins to 'decode' the combination]Soldier: "All right, all right, I got it. Stand back son. 1, 1, 1, umm... 1!"Scout: Let's go, let's go-[BLU Heavy comes around the corner, Sasha in hand, charging towards the Scout and Soldier]Heavy: "INCOMING!"[Heavy shoulder-barges the door, destroying it. The three of them are sent tumbling and screaming into the Intelligence Room. The Scout reaches the desk to discover the briefcase is perfectly safe]Scout: [while screaming, he notices the briefcase] "AAAAAHHHH- Hey, it's still here!"Heavy: "-AAAAalright then."Spy: "Ahem."[Camera zooms in to reveal the BLU Spy, with the BLU Sniper's corpse over one shoulder]Spy: "Gentlemen."[Meet the Spy' Title Card][Cut back to the Spy, carrying the dead Sniper towards the desk]Spy: "I see the briefcase is safe."Soldier: "Safe and sound, mm-hmm."Scout: "Yeah, it is!"Spy: "Tell me... did anyone happen to kill a RED Spy on the way here?"[The other three BLUs shake their heads and shrug]Spy: "No? Then we still have a problem."[He deposits the Sniper's body on the desk, revealing a bloody Knife in his back]Soldier: "...and a knife."[The Scout approaches and removes the knife]Scout: "Oooh, big problem. I've killed plenty of Spies; they're dime-a-dozen back-stabbing scumbags - like you!"[The Scout attempts to manipulate the knife like the Spy, only to cut himself on the finger and drop it]Scout: "Ow! No offense."Spy: "If you managed to kill them, I assure you, they were not like me." [The Spy deftly retrieves the knife and flicks it shut, handing it back to the Scout] "And nothing... nothing like the man loose inside this building."Scout: "What're you? President of his fan club?"[The Soldier and Heavy chuckle][The Spy turns to face the Scout]Spy: "No... that would be your mother!"[The Spy reveals a folder and slaps it down on the table, revealing several compromising photographs of the RED Spy and the Scout's mother]Scout: [stammers out of shock and disbelief]Spy: "Indeed, and now he's here to f**k us! So listen up boy, or pornography starring your mother will be the second worst thing that happens to you today."[[[Right Behind You]] plays][The Soldier and Heavy examine the photographs. The Heavy leans over and shows the Soldier one photo in particular]Soldier: "Oh!"[The Scout frantically retrieves the photos as the Spy lights and smokes a cigarillo in the foreground]Scout: "Gimme that!"Spy: "This Spy has already breached our defenses..."[Fade to the RED Spy, creeping through the Hydro tunnels. He pauses at a corner, as the camera pulls back to reveal a BLU Level 3 Sentry Gun with its Engineer. He slides an Sapper across the floor, disarming and destroying the Sentry Gun immediately]Engineer: "Sentry Down!"[The BLU Engineer throws his Wrench down and frantically reaches for his Pistol, only to have the Spy shoot him in the head with the Revolver. The dead Engineer crashes through a door and the Spy steps over him and fires at a target off-screen][Cut back to the BLU Intelligence Room. The BLU Spy leans over the dead Sniper, gesturing frantically.]Spy: "You've seen what he's done to our colleagues!"[Flashback to the BLU Sniper, now alive and sniping from a dusty attic. The RED Spy creeps up on him and steps on a creaking floorboard, alerting the Sniper, who engages the Spy with the Kukri. A struggle ensues, and the Sniper is ultimately backstabbed][Cut back to BLU Intelligence Room]Spy: "And worst of all, he could be any one of us..."[Fade to the RED Spy fighting a BLU Medic, armed with a Bonesaw]Medic: "Raus, raus!"[The Spy breaks the Medic's arm, disarming him. Close-up on the Spy's face as he disguises as the Medic, sans spectacles]Medic: [gasps] "Nein..."[The Spy kills the Medic with a well-placed chop to the throat, knocking off his spectacles, which he catches and wears, completing his disguise][Cut back to BLU Intel Room. The BLU Spy looks frantic]Spy: "He could be in this very room! He could be you! He could be me! He could even be-"[The Spy is cut off as his head explodes violently. The camera switches to the Soldier, Shotgun in hand, with a confused Heavy and a panicked Scout]Scout: "Whoa, whoa, whoa!"Heavy: "Oh!"Soldier: "What? It was obvious!" [The Soldier pumps his Shotgun, discarding the spent shell.] "He's the RED Spy! Watch, he'll turn red any second now..."[The Soldier and Heavy approach the dead Spy, with The Soldier prodding the Spy's foot with his Shotgun]Soldier: "Any second now... See? Red! Oh, wait... that's blood."[The Scout lingers behind, his expression sinister. He approaches the Soldier and Heavy, retrieving the knife he pocketed earlier, and flicking it open easily. As he approaches, he flickers and melts, revealing himself to be the RED Spy]Heavy: "So, we still got problem..."Soldier: "Big problem... all right, who's ready to go find this Spy?"Spy: "Right behind you."[Team Fortress 2 ending flourish music plays, with the stabbing of the Soldier and Heavy punctuating the beat of the tune.][Petite Chou-Fleur plays][Fade to the scattered photos of the Scout's mother. The RED Spy retrieves one of them and smiles wistfully]Spy: "Ahh... ma petite chou-fleur."[The RED Spy walks off with the BLU team's intel in tow]

Author: Da Bird
Review Content: To the overwatch fans: This is is not a review bombing from TF2 fans. Overwatch was a game with promise, a bit lacking in features and game modes but people really loved it. All it needed was support. Instead all it got was lootboxes, a few additional heroes, and a few additional maps. Then we were promised all the content that should've been added to Overwatch in a sequel called Overwatch 2. What was actually added? Additional monetization in an effort to nickle and dime every cent they can from people. Nothing new has been added to this game. A few more maps, a few more heroes, and a few copy pasted pve events that they've been rolling out temporarily every few years.There's no love behind this game, no passion, no art, nothing. It's a soulless husk being squeezed for every penny that it can and it's completely worthless. Twenty years later people still remember games like Unreal Tournament. In twenty years nothing will be remembered of Overwatch but porn.

Author: Krezg
Review Content: Let me tell you about this truly awful game company, one that seems to have no regard for its players except for how much money it can squeeze out of them. They have recently released Overwatch 2 as a free to play business model, but don't be fooled, my friend. This new model is filled to the brim with microtransactions, overpriced skins, and downright predatory behavior.But wait, it gets even worse. They have actually shut down the first game, rendering it completely unplayable for all those who had purchased it. Can you believe that? They simply expect the entire playerbase to migrate over to this free to play model if they want to continue enjoying the game. It's a blatant disregard for their loyal customers and a clear money grab.Now, you might be thinking, "Well, at least they promised a PvE Hero mode with character progression, right?" Wrong! Just when you thought there might be a glimmer of hope, they go ahead and cancel that too. Can you believe the audacity? It's as if they're actively trying to disappoint and deceive their players.But fear not, dear gamer. They do offer a lighter story mission for the low, low price of $15. How generous of them, right ? But it's a shame that they wouldn't just give the players what they wanted in the first place. In any case, we can only hope that the gaming industry will learn from this experience and be more transparent with their players in the future. Companies should be more willing to provide content that their customers are willing to pay for, without resorting to tactics like these. Additionally, they should be more open and honest about their pricing structure, so players don't feel like they're being taken advantage of. Just think of how much more money the gaming industry would make if they simply asked players for their opinion on what content they'd like to pay for, instead of resorting to these underhanded tactics!

It's like sipping on grandma's secret recipe lemonade on a hot summer day. It's got that vintage flavor, unique classes, and maps that are more memorable than your first crush.
