Author: wildwingBat
Review Content: Overwatch 1 was way better than Overwatch 2, and it isn't close. Overwatch 2 is a mobile-looking, budget version of what Overwatch 1 was. The game feels like a free for all with zero structure compared to Overwatch 1. It is significantly easier to climb the ranked ladder in OW2, causing an inflation of diamond players infesting GM/T500 matchmaking, taking away any competitiveness the game used to have. They purposely did not release content in OW1 for YEARS in order to push out this false-advertised, TRASH downgrade from what could've been. The worst part is they are just now proving they have the resources and are completely capable of maintaining the game, so why didn't they just do that in the first place? Every time I log on this game, I'm reminded why Overwatch 1 was so much better and I think about what could've been. Do not support this company. Do not be led on by their constant lies.I like the roadhog rework though! ...oh wait

Author: Kunio
Review Content: If you're looking for a fun, rewarding team-based FPS, look elsewhere. Overwatch was probably my most played game in 2016 and 2017. Got every achievement (Prior to Doomfist) on the PS4 version and had an absolute ball with it. I'm not sure what was going on in the heads of the developers between then and now. But what is it now? A ton of false promises to distract us from the many awful things Blizzard has done. Heck, I'd even be able to live with that if the game was fun to make progress on, but now it's just battlepasses and other predatory forms of microtransactions. Every new hero use to be free so that nobody was left in the dust when it came to learning how they worked, and thus learning how to counter them. Now, the only way to learn is by forking over some cash.Overwatch 1 had lootboxes, yes, but at least you can play to earn those back then and still get neat skins and whatnot without spending a nickle. This game really is just a shadow of what it use to be. More content won't fix the game.

Author: ✱MarioBlue22✱
Review Content: Although I will be trying whatever is left of the PvE can't say I will pick the game back up at this current time, what at first was a good idea to remove 1 tank turned into a unfun game of punching bag where if your the tank, your the punching bag.DPS has the most variety but that's because they are 75% of the roster.Support is as fun as DPS with the down side of having not many to choose from making the role stale after a while.The battle pass does little to excite me outside of the mythics skin most of the time, with many cosmetics being horribly over priced ranging from 10-20 bucks for 1 skin which sucks if the cool skin you like turns out to be 20 bucks.Balance changes are back and forth half the time being changes that aren't all that impactful to changes that are so out of left field they get reverted or overly nerfed next patch.As a tank main I simply refuse to really pick the game back up due to either not having fun relying on my team to do things to constantly being called out for being bad (skill issue) and outside of giving the PvE a shot (review been made before trying it out) I don't know if I will ever fully play the game again.Post One pve mission/watching a friend play the rest opinion:it's not worth the $15 for 3 missions, the cutscenes are well made and the banter is pretty good, but its basically like missions from overwatch 1, you play it one time and that's about it, only unique things are the enemies with the down side of it being scripted spawns instead of random spawns seen in left 4 dead or deep rock galactic.Also blizzard bad, there I said it.

Author: Imrür
Review Content: Overwatch 2: A Step Back for the FranchiseI recently had the opportunity to play Overwatch 2 and, unfortunately, my experience was far from satisfactory. What was once an innovative and dynamic franchise seems to have taken a turn for the worse, favoring the financial exploitation of players over creativity and commitment to a quality gaming experience.At the core of my disappointment is the fact that Overwatch 2 feels more like a costly update than a genuine sequel. Despite the change in title, the game has failed to introduce significant changes or improvements that warrant the financial investment it demands.The first point of disappointment was the introduction of the paid Season Pass. What should have been a chance to explore new heroes turned out to be a frustrating experience, having to "farm" the Season Pass to unlock them. This approach seems contradictory to the spirit of fairness and accessibility that once made Overwatch famous.Another significant issue that reflects poorly on the game's management was the balance changes. The rebalancing was so poorly executed that two characters, Torbjörn and Bastion, had to be temporarily removed from the game. This is a clear indication of the lack of foresight and testing before implementing such changes.I was also shocked by Blizzard's decision to cancel the PvE mode, reducing the scope of the game. It seems that the financial success of Diablo Immortal, which brings in $2 million a day thanks to the Asian market, led to this decision. Instead of investing in new features to enrich the game, the shift towards selling skins at €20 gives the impression of a lack of creativity and ambition.A significant issue was a bug that forced the purchase of paid skins, and Blizzard's response was to not provide refunds. This behavior raises serious concerns about Blizzard's regard for its player base and overall business practices.The removal of Assault mode, replaced by Push mode, did not contribute to enriching the gaming experience either. This gives the impression of stagnation rather than progression in the game design.As for the reward system, the more you play, the less you earn. This is discouraging and seems to go against the objective of any game - to encourage players to spend more time playing.In terms of technical issues, the game is far from stable. Bugs and crashes are frequent, hindering a smooth and enjoyable gaming experience.Finally, while veteran players can transfer their skins, newcomers to Overwatch 2 face an almost insurmountable financial or temporal wall. To acquire the complete collection of skins from the first opus, they will have to spend about $10,000 or play for 327 years. Even for smaller collections, like Kitsune's, one must either spend $156 or play for 5 years.In conclusion, Overwatch 2 is a disappointment. Instead of innovating and pushing the boundaries, it seems that Blizzard has chosen to favor financial exploitation. Given the upcoming acquisition of Blizzard by Xbox, I earnestly hope we will see a shift in the company's direction. Here's hoping that Xbox can help steer Blizzard back to its roots of quality and creativity, putting an end to these recent questionable practices.Overwatch 2 Invasion - 15€Ultimate Invasion - 40€Heros Collection - 5€Ultimate Heros Collection - 20€LOL.I still don't know why people still playing Blizzard games ...

Author: BasJack
Review Content: Preface, i played 243 hours on overwatch, most on 1 and a couple of really depressing ones on 2. Reached gold before burning out and level 302.I loved overwatch 1 it was like TF2 on steroids, more compact, focused and with character with a richer skill set. Got hooked up, trained my aim, got quite good. Unfortunately soon after i joined (around season 2) all friends playing quit because they got burned by season 1 competitive (which apparently was hell on earth). So i started playing alone and ranking, eventually reached gold and burned out. It was around the time they started the Overwatch league that all the problems started to really sprout. Updates to the meta became slow because ♥♥♥♥ if a 16 years old that is getting payed to play a video game can be expected to adapt to changes in a game. Atrocious decisions on character balance and reworks, born from the all inclusive style of character planned but the extremely competitive nature of the game (Symmetra melted people without havint to aim, Junkrat shooting grenades at random and now doesn't even take damage, i think that still stands) or just bad ideas alltogheter (Mercy Valkirye update because Mercy players where hiding like ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and using their overpowered Ultimate to res a whole team after a fight). Not to mention fun charachters immediately nerfed (Ashe).I kept following from a distance, sometimes coming back, have a couple of games and then quitting againTHAT SAID: Overwatch 2 is the worse update the game could ever have, it's a sort of miracle for how bad it ♥♥♥♥♥ up and lessens what was a great game, not understand what made the game great.Let's start with a slimy note, I bought Overwatch 1, i also bought a couple of lootboxes (like an idiot). If you delete the game, make a "second" and bring all the skins from the first and put ridicolous prices on them, I that bought and supported the first game should have them all, they were bundled with the first game, even if the caveat was that you had to "earn" (random) them. Or at least i should be able to keep earning them in the 2. It would also help the game because them there is nothing to strive for in the game, except some dumb achievement. I won't even count those challenges that give so little currency that it would take years to earn anything meaningful.Now no matter what all the brainlet streamers say, the change to 5v5 from 6v6 is the worse decision they could make, especially with the locked roles.  There is a reason why even when roles where free there was always at least 2 tanks. Between 2 points pass 1 line. 2 tanks made a wall behind which the team could hide, move, change shooting angle, try flanks confident that the team could hold for a little. With just 1 tank, even with a huge health bar, no wall can be built, the only hope is to huddle up behind it and hope it doesn't die, if it does the whole team is ♥♥♥♥♥♥. The only meta is now deathball, if someone tries to flank, as soon as it gets spotted by the other huddled team it gets shredded. The only one that could do it and have fun is Sombra (my main in 1 that brought me to burning because i was adamant in using her in competitive and climbing rank, when soldier would've been a thousand times easier but boring). I'm sure soon after they nerfed Sombra to the ground but i didn't stick to see.Another huge change is the lack of crowd controls. I at least get the idea of this, the first person nature of the game makes crowd controls feel awful, you are forced to just see the screen and wait. Problem is the game was built with them in mind. McCree(don't remember the new name) neeeeds them to survive, otherwise everyone can just push right into his face and melt him. And if the problem was that for him was a easy way for him to get headshot, i'd say skill issue, i had a 70% precision with him at my top, no flashbang needed to get headshots. Last the PVE, they worked a lot on it (allegedly) then dropped and scaled it down. Problem is they are asking a stupid price for it (Shadows of Change much?) like they are selling what was originally planned but in reality they find out they could sell the PvE events that used to be free, truly a genius move. As genius as putting the game on Steam. And Gabe i better not see you delete reviews because of "brigading", This ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ revies/rant is a long time comingSorry for it, maybe i will come back and write it again better, i doubt it.

Author: Saint
Review Content: for anyone looking for a serious review explaining why OW2 has a (at time of writing) 10% positive score:they took an incredibly fun game in OverWatch 1, and applied layers of terrible systems on top of it to destroy any sense of fun and replace it with monetization.free loot boxes when you level up? gone. Now there are 5 different currencies and skins are ~$15+ apiece.Battle Pass: a relatively good battle pass, bogged down by useless filler items like "souvenirs" that are literally just static 3d models your character holds over their head like you just opened a box in a zelda game, and a new currency that is extremely restricted and intentionally looks similar to the premium currency.gameplay: Matchmaking can take upwards of 5 minutes, and you're STILL not going to get a balanced team. As someone who's been playing the game since OW1 release, I routinely get matched with brand new players who have no idea what they're doing. Balance is terrible, where healers are now responsible for all of the healing AND damage, if you don't have a healer who can keep up with both easily, you're not going to clear the enemy team and you're not going to win. period. Games tend to flip between completely stomping and getting completely stomped, ruining all of the fun of a hard match.Menus: they reworked the entire Menu to look like a mobile game, it feels cheap, like overwatch is a cheap knockoff of itself now.

Author: ImBobbyMuddah
Review Content: Prepare yourself for a mind-boggling experience that defies all expectations of incompetence. If you thought the previous installment was a masterpiece, then get ready to have your hopes and dreams crushed like bugs under the boot of mediocrity. This sequel is less of a step forward and more of a headfirst plunge into the abyss of laziness and disregard for player satisfaction.Remember those crisp, cutting-edge graphics that left you in awe last time? Well, buckle up, because this time around, the developers decided to treat your eyes to a visually unappealing spectacle that looks like it was designed on a calculator from the 90s. The "upgrades" are so stunningly underwhelming that it's hard to believe this wasn't just a cheap attempt to cash in on the previous success.Gameplay? Oh, don't you worry – they managed to take a perfectly good formula and somehow make it worse. The controls feel like they were designed by someone who's never held a controller in their life. Forget about the smooth, responsive gameplay you used to enjoy; now you'll be struggling just to get your character to do the most basic actions without feeling like you're wrestling with a drunk octopus.And let's not forget about the stunning lack of innovation. If you were hoping for new maps, exciting game modes, or anything remotely fresh, prepare to be disappointed. This game takes recycling to a whole new level, as it shamelessly regurgitates the same old content, as if hoping you won't notice the stench of stagnation.But wait, there's more! The sound design is a symphony of disappointment, featuring uninspired weapon sounds that are about as menacing as a kitten's purr. The soundtrack seems to have been composed by someone who just discovered the "default" setting on their synthesizer.It's genuinely impressive how the developers managed to strip away every ounce of enjoyment from a previously beloved franchise. This sequel feels less like a game and more like an elaborate practical joke played on unsuspecting fans. If you're looking for a masterclass in how to take a promising franchise and drive it straight into the ground, congratulations – you've found your golden ticket.In conclusion, this sequel is the gaming equivalent of a soggy cardboard box left out in the rain: sad, unappealing, and destined for the trash heap of forgotten failures. If you're a glutton for punishment and have an insatiable craving for disappointment, then by all means, give this game a shot. For the rest of us who value our time and sanity, it's best to avoid this abomination like the plague.

Author: Green Inja
Review Content: If you're reading this, get ready for 6+ years of built up resentment.This is a review coming from someone who played OW consistently from Summer Games 2016 up until the announcement of the PVE cancellation (yes, the PVE they promised was CANCELLED! The replacement they put in game was not what was promised at all). I was a Grandmaster player for more than half of the original games lifetime and even played on a team at that level, and also frequented the game at the lowest level on an alt account. I have more experience with the game than most other people. If you think that this negative review is just part of the """review bombing,""" you obviously had never played the original game and refuse to listen to people's legitimate criticisms.With that being said: ***UNDER NO CIRCUMSTANCES SHOULD YOU PURCHASE ANYTHING IN THIS GAME, LET ALONE PLAY IT AT ALL.***The game's current state of being a microtransaction filled dumpsterfire being puppeted around as its predecessor, along with the constant lies and underdelivering from the development team should just show you how little Blizzard cares for this game anymore. From the very beginning, a solid and engaging PVE was what I wanted most out of the game. I played PVP to death and burnt out, but I still consider the original Overwatch to be my favorite PVP game ever made. If they had been able to deliver an equivalent experience in PVE, this review would be positive in spite of the multiple awful things surrounding PVP and Blizzard as a whole.I'm someone who can deal with a lot of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Brig's release, GOATs, Role Lock (Definitely the worst update in terms of game enjoyment, even worse than Brig), and the three year content drought were not enough to dissuade me from playing the game because I could always feel the passion from the dev team behind the project. I still miss playing heroes like Reinhardt, Roadhog, and Junkrat, but I can no longer gaslight myself into supporting a product that so heinously prioritizes grabbing at your wallet over actual quality. They're only after your wallet, plain and simple. Blizzard failed to realize that short-term profit boosts from battlepasses and $20 skins completely screwed their games reputation and dwindled their player numbers. They're trying to build a multiplatform brand out of Overwatch, but it will fail because even their most diehard fans from the early years no longer care about the game. They should have prioritized keeping their players happy over their investors, as their long-term financial gains from multiplatforming would have been massive. On top of making OW2 and objective downgrade from the first, you cannot go back and play OW1 (which millions paid money for), which makes this stain on the game industry an even bigger kick to the ♥♥♥♥. OW2 is the pinnacle of what gamers mean when they talk about why "modern gaming sucks." Abysmal predatory microtransactions, inconsistent at best "live service", tone deaf lead company and developers, and a lack of passion and direction. Their eyes were on the money and they choked out their golden goose. I'm surprised to see that at the time of writing, this game only has a 13% positive review on steam. It should definitely be lower. The Microsoft acquisition isn't going to save Overwatch, the dream is dead. If you still support this game (especially monetarily), please take a long look at many of the negative reviews and figure out why people don't like it instead of blindly acting as Blizzard's PR lapdog. If you aren't bothered by the issues people have, enjoy the game. But I can promise you that they will only disappoint you in the future with half-baked updates and illusions of a grand future.

Author: KingKrouch
Review Content: This is just Overwatch 2, but on Steam. No launcher nonsense (Take notes EA, Rockstar, and Ubisoft) here. Seemingly works fine on Linux via Proton as well. No complaints with how the Steam release has been handled so far.Blizzard also added FSR 2.2 for those interested, and honestly, even with the max render percentage of 67% in this mode, it looks better than native res with just SMAA. Just make sure the game runs at a high framerate (120 or higher), as TAA greatly benefits from more frame data to work with.Can't stand the monetization of this game, how much of a meme the changing meta has become, or the way Blizzard handles their PR or workspace culture though, so that might be a downside for you. I wish they'd just release a proper map editor, add LAN support, and user-hosted dedicated server tools already.I've always felt like BattleNet was antiquated, and the launcher really didn't have a reason to exist even back in the 2010's. Now just release good games again and fix up your workspace culture, and maybe I'll buy a full priced game from you again.

Author: zee.dragon
Review Content: This game is ruined by the greedy monetization practices of the current live service game landscape. Note that I bought the original Overwatch but then was forced to get Overwatch 2, when the game was just Overwatch the game was 40 dollars, and everything that was essential to the core gameplay loop which literally was just all of the heroes came with the game. Skins were not a factor for me but I got most of them through literally playing the game and events and got most of them as I did buy the Pink Mercy skin as it was for charity. Now the game is free to play and you have to buy, buy, buy to have a full core gameplay loop which involves having all of the heroes as you are picking and countering picking heroes throughout a single match.Additionally, all new skins from what I can tell you can only choose to purchase and there is no free currency to get them as the free currency from the free Battle Pass is only for classic skins for what I can see meaning Overwatch, not Overwatch 2 skins and for the Overwatch 2 skins, it seems to be the practice of fear of missing out.With that, I feel they made the change to force people to pay to win with their wallet from my perspective, and for no other reason than a literal bait and switch of products and providing empty promises (this should honestly be illegal if you ask me). One of the promises is the Hero Mode (this Mode was not a thing I was interested in but my friends and community were), which was supposed to be a free PvE/story/progression/hero trees system that was removed. Mind you that this was the whole point of Overwatch 2, or at least that's how it was marketed, toward consumers. Now they made it into an empty shell of a PvE mode that you now need to pay for whenever a new one comes out it seems.Additionally, they removed most of the crowd control mechanics of affecting the enemy at first launch for Overwatch 2 to just add back into the game for the Hero called Lifeweaver to affect your teammates which if you do not know this player and are not in communication together can lead to you want to do something and then all of a sudden being literally YEETED in a placement you did not want and in most cases, the hero does this to get teammates killed or be their bullet sponge as they are about to die (most cases they die anyway) for this reason they tend to get the title trolls and can turn a game from 5v5 to a 4v6.If what I said sounds like a game and company that you want to support then go ahead and be roped into a one-side step and then take a mile steps back as they never took a step forward from my viewpoint. If this is not a game and company that you want to support I would suggest staying away from it for the newcomers on this platform.If things change to a better state then, I may update this but this is just my honest opinion on the current state of the game as it stands.

Author: Throbert "Based" Johnson
Review Content: Overwatch 2 has seemingly deviated from its prior deference to players, adopting a veneer of continuity from its predecessor while effectively pursuing pecuniary gain.In the year 2016, I initially engaged with the game and, akin to numerous others, promptly became enamored by its allure. Overwatch continued to occupy a prominent position among my preferred shooters throughout subsequent years, even during the period marked by a paucity of content leading to the advent of OW2.While the title retains its endearing design, captivating ensemble of characters, and commendable multiplayer maps, Overwatch 2 has introduced notable deviations that cast a pall over its foundational essence. Permit me to elucidate:#1 - Restriction of Heroes within the Sphere of the Battlepass FrameworkForemost among these alterations is the confinement of heroes within the parameters of the Battlepass framework, an alteration of profound significance.Overwatch is grounded in the selection of heroes and the orchestration of team dynamics. Each distinct character confers unique advantages, with varying degrees of compatibility or incongruity. In its previous iteration, Overwatch periodically introduced new heroes to its player base, fostering an inclusive environment devoid of financial barriers. However, Overwatch 2 now demands either a protracted commitment to the acquisition of new heroes or pecuniary expenditure via the Battlepass to gain access upon release (or a fee of £9 for established heroes).Though superficially innocuous, this transformation bears consequence as players can partake in competitive gameplay with an incomplete hero roster.This presents a crucial facet of gameplay sequestered behind a monetary threshold, a construct that runs counter to principles of competitive parity.How can equitable competition persist when one cohort of players possesses a plethora of options solely due to financial disbursement? The semblance to a "pay-to-win" model is discernible, though I defer to your discretion in formulating this judgment.#2 - The Battlepass Framework and the Evolution of Cosmetic AestheticsMy disposition toward the concept of the Battlepass framework has heretofore been one of tempered concurrence; however, when juxtaposed with analogous implementations in other gaming contexts, OW2's iteration is decidedly wanting. Each iteration of the Battlepass proffers an assemblage of 80 tiers of rewards, conventionally encompassing 8 distinct skins (augmented by an admirably customizable variant as the culmination), alongside sundry ancillary accoutrements, as is the norm. This latter category encompasses designations, insignias, and gestures. It warrants mention that a recent addition includes "credits," a commendable augmentation, yet one that falls short of rectifying the foundational error of entrenching pivotal gameplay attributes behind a monetary barrier.The role of cosmetics within Overwatch has historically been of pivotal import, epitomized by the creations of accomplished artists and modelers responsible for crafting superlative skins. The aesthetic merit of these offerings endures, yet their valuation is characterized by audacity. Notably, legendary skins, denoting designs beyond mere chromatic reconfigurations, approximate an average price point of £20 or more per unit.Heretofore, these cosmetic items were obtainable through the mechanism of lootboxes, awarded with each advancement in player level, a frequency that could be deemed appreciable. In my personal trajectory within the game, my engagement with direct box purchases was intermittent, yet I managed to amass a substantial collection of skins spanning various characters. The rationale often cited in defense of the transition to a commercial model was predicated on the notion that the extant munificence of the lootbox system was compromising fiscal viability, an assertion I find subject to dispute. Evidently, by the year 2019, a mere triennium post-launch, Overwatch had amassed a cumulative revenue of $1 billion through the medium of lootboxes.Presently, avenues for acquiring cosmetic embellishments devoid of fiscal exchange are notably restricted, unless one is inclined to endure protracted trials to secure a singular legendary skin over a span of months.#3 - The Praxis of PvE ImplementationWhile my personal inclination seldom gravitated toward Player versus Environment (PvE) experiences, it is imperative to note that this facet was heralded as a focal pillar underpinning the narrative of Overwatch 2's proposition.In principle, that was the prevailing tenor; however, the eventual manifestation transpired as a bait-and-switch maneuver, ostensibly orchestrated to facilitate the integration of novel monetization mechanisms. Curiously, even in the wake of the ostensibly delineated cessation of PvE endeavors, discrete PvE missions persist, albeit available as individualized acquisitions, serving as yet another conduit to extract monetary remuneration.In Conclusive RecapitulationFor devotees of competitive shooters, Overwatch 2 appears to be wanting in its adherence to the principles undergirding competitive integrity.For adherents of the cosmetic acquisition facet, Overwatch 2 necessitates a financial commitment of significant magnitude.While the factor of amusement remains extant, thereby retaining vestiges of the gratifying experience that once resonated, its essence is overshadowed by the intrusion of acquisitive proclivities to an extent that compels me to withhold endorsement for discerning enthusiasts.

Author: CRΔZY
Review Content: Overwatch 2 an empty shell of what Overwatch used to be, a great game, not a perfect one but a game i could proudly call one of my favorite competitive games ( played over 1k hours on battle.net ) now i cant honestly recommend this game, we waited for 3 years with no content and they release this half assed game, and expect us to pay for characters on a "competitive" game, yes you can get them for free but unless you are planning to have this game as a secondary job you won't be getting them for free, also the new cosmetic system is so predatory i have over 20k coins of the old currency which i cant use on new skins or the battle pass. The sound as well they changed the sound of guns and some other stuff related to sound i would like to use the legacy sound the new sound is so garbage, there was 0 reason for them to mess with the sound, seems like they haven't heard of the saying "If it ain't broke don't fix it". I don't know for me it feels like the essence of Overwatch was lost the moment they released this game i would love to play Overwatch and not this garbage called Overwatch 2, i hate the fact that they forced the entire player-base to play their garbage sequel by completely removing Overwatch and replacing it with Overwatch 2, i paid to play Overwatch not Overwatch 2. BRING BACK OVERWATCH.

Author: Gummientchen
Review Content: I entered the Overwatch universe through its second installment, primarily due to friends. Not having experienced the first game, I was eager for Overwatch 2's launch. Sadly, my excitement was overshadowed by the letdown of unfulfilled PvE promises. Instead of substantial improvements, we got weekly PvE missions that mirrored the ones in Overwatch 1. The introduction of paid options for skins that used to be free in Overwatch 1 felt like a bait-and-switch. The Overwatch 2 release with minimal advancements left me questioning the choices made by the developers.My experience with matchmaking has been frustrating. It struggles to pair players of equal skill, resulting in an unsatisfying gameplay environment. Furthermore, the change from 6-player teams to 5-player teams feels imbalanced and has had a negative impact on my overall enjoyment.While playing Overwatch 2 with friends has had its enjoyable moments, the unfulfilled promises and the issues with matchmaking and team balance have left me feeling cheated by the developers/publisher. This makes it hard for me to recommend the game wholeheartedly.

Author: SmashinVP
Review Content: So I do like Overwatch, never played enough Overwatch 1, so I was excited to play the game with friends again when Overwatch 2 came out. Also I love that they added this to steam, with no battle.net launcher, you still need the account but I don't care for that, as long as there is no unnecessary launcher, I'm happy.Sadly the promises of PVE where totally wrong, they got changed into these weekly PVE mission things, that seem to be more of the events that we had in Overwatch 1. The Skill tree got completely removed. Old Overwatch 1 skins that were free now are in the store to be bought with real money. Also Overwatch 2 came out so much later with so little changes to Overwatch 1 that you wonder what the leadership at Blizzard was/is doing.When Overwatch 2 launched, do to bugs and glitches, you essentially had less then when Overwatch 1 was out. They have fixed most things to my knowledge.There is more to type out here, but I feel like that is enough. I have had lots of fun with Overwatch 2 but the damages that are always being done by Blizzard are just to much for me to still enjoy the game, or to even recommend it.

Author: Mayo
Review Content: Things I'm fine with OW2:-Being F2P (although it should have been F2P since OW1's decline and not NOW)-Replacing loot boxes with a Battle Pass-Not using using BNet's app-Being fine to run it on Steam Deck without additional steps so I can play while on the toiletThings I'm not fine with:-Being F2P that requires a verified phone number to combat smurfs and cheaters (it doesn't)-New heroes obtainable only through battle pass at first or endless grinding-Battle Pass not having the currency that will let you buy the next one once completed (literally almost every game that has a Battle Pass does this, what the hell?)-Poor balancing. Very, very poor balancing. And not that OW1's balancing was good either, but... man, where do I begin?-Taking away features from OW1, such as Looking for Group. How am I supposed to befriend people now in this game?-Just three paid PVE missions where only the Torb one is good-Content drought for 4+ years in this game for basically nothing

Author: Darkdrinker12
Review Content: Once upon a time this game showed a lot of promice.  The game had a fun element to it, lots of fun new characters, and playing it was a bit of a good time.  Then came the Drought.  Things became more... static.  less new characters, less maps, and less fun.  Then came Overwatch 2.  Which promised an expansive PVE experience, a more coherent story line, and elements to bring onboard the non-pvp crowd.  To make this happen they said they would need to revamp the game, rebuild it.  But, we were promised that Overwatch 1 would continue.  Both games would continue side by side.Feel free to look up what happened.  In the end, there is no expansive PVE content, the dual game format was changed and Overwatch 1 died to allow Overwatch 2 to paywall the game away and strip features, free content is now paid content, free characters are now payed characters....  This game is a mess.  Its a hellscape of pay to win content, dividing its player base into the Have Battle Pass players and the Free to Play players.  Blizard has made it clear that they do not plan to make good on this games potental, they would rather harvest money from its loyal fans.This game is a disappointment across the board.  Do somethign better with your money.  Like play the Avengers game from Squaresoft.  That game is more honest that this mess.

Author: Command217
Review Content: Overwatch has lost its way, it’s time we Petras Act it and move on. I have 2,259 hours in OW and that’s only including time in matches. Any time in the menu’s, in queue, PTR, and OW2 beta are excluded. It used to be such a great game, but it was left behind to chase a dream that ended up being a pile of cancellations and disappointment. It has been mismanaged for years now which has led the game to a place where they release minimal content, are oblivious to the games issues and even if they weren’t, are too incompetent to be able to fix them. There has been a very clear brain drain over at Blizzard across all teams and they clearly have lost a critical mass of their employee skills and knowledge as a result. Their patches show a clear misunderstanding of how the game has been balanced in the past, recreating major issues that we had thought the OW team had learned from. The team made a gamble to try to deliver on a dream to make an incredible story that would have lots of replay ability, customization, and lore. They completely failed and in the end, they decided to cancel it all. They scrapped the plan and decided not to tell the player base until several months later, all the while trying to recoup the losses of their failure from the last 5 years. In order to do this the game has turned into an extremely greedy cash grab with very little effort going into the game anymore. The game is destined to die in a pit of despair as its failures amount to digging it into a deeper and deeper hole until it reaches hell itself. Those of us who put our time and money into the game will move on to bigger and better things as heroes never die.

Author: JeffyJA
Review Content: I love this game. Ive put thousands of hours into Overwatch since I started playing in 2017 and Ive experienced every rank from Bronze to Top500, but Overwatch 2 doesnt feel like Overwatch. Blizzard has made too many mistakes in the recent years and its completely killed off my excitement for the game. Transitioning to 5v5, cancellation of the PVE, the terrible shop prices, and the locking of heroes behind battle-pass levels are just a few mistakes off the top of my head. The only things I can think of to fix Overwatch 2 would be bringing back 6v6, improving the battle-pass, fixing shop prices, and completing the PVE. I know none of these things will happen due to the insane amounts of money they're making but OW2 isnt the game I fell in love with. If I had to summarize the current state of the game it would be "Stockholm Syndrome." Pretty please Blizzard, fix your game.-JeffyJA

Review Content: This game needs to be studied to show future generations of game developers what NOT to do.  They've spent 3 years pissing away any goodwill they had from the community.  Lies, on top of bad design decisions, to more lies, to outright greed - have made what was once my favorite franchise now little more than an embarrassment to play. Every time I play this game now, I pray to God that Valve makes TF3 and saves this community from the deep dark pit that Blizzard has created here.

Author: Vi
Review Content: Nearly everything in Overwatch 2 is a downgrade, from the switch to 5V5 making the game both more frustrating in solo queue and less interesting in a party alongside the erosion of tanking, to the progression being a paid feature retroactively making all of Overwatch 1's collecting gone and the removal of defining multiplayer-FPS maps of the 2010s like Hanamura & Volskaya.Its garbage content salvaged for Kotick & Activision-Blizzard to milk every last drop out of the dumpster that was Overwatch 2's development. Blizzard learned their lesson from WoW Classic when they cried because people would rather play the defining game from 2004 than settle for their watered down live version. The original game that was so critically acclaimed (An overstatement in retrospect imo) is now lost, and this is what remains. Without dedicated server support, Blizzard get the final say, and as long as people settle their greed will continue to infest and ruin their genuinely good IPs.OW1 won't be the last defining multiplayer title lost to time.The original game had a mountain of problems, but at least, at its core, it was a unique FPS that could be full of teamwork and counterplay. Overwatch 2 lacks any of the teamplay that set Overwatch apart, while being devoid of anything resembling good movement or gunplay that more individual-focused hero shooters, such as Apex, has.I had far more fun during Overwatch 1's 'maintenance mode' than I have during Overwatch 2, More content does not mean better, especially when its as half-baked as most of Overwatch 2's additions.Overwatch 2 is just another attempt from Blizzard to force fans to settle for mediocrity for the sake of their own greed.  A complete and total waste.

Author: 你也不太硬
Review Content: 2017年用gt705这样的卡第一次接触到ow，30帧全糊画质，猩猩玩的不亦乐乎。转眼到18年夏天买了1050ti笔记本，第一个下的也是这个游戏。19年的夏天专精t上了钻石，算是人生巅峰了。20-21大三忙着考试，大四忙着毕业，ow已经渐行渐远了。到如今，不管是ow1还是ow2，过去的欢乐时间都一去不复返了，曾经一块开黑的小伙伴也各奔东西。这个游戏在或者不在，其实早已激不起波澜，过去的美好回忆埋藏在时间的黑洞里，一去不复返。真心祝福如今还在游玩这款的游戏的你们，祝你们在十七八岁的年纪里也能收获自己的独家记忆。差评给暴雪，祝早日倒闭

Author: Neon Noodles
Review Content: The saddest thing about this game is knowing where it was to where its now come. This was an amazing team shooter that valued the player by allowing you to unlock cosmetics for your favorite champs through gameplay and dedication. That is no longer the case. Everything you want to buy costs 20$ a piece. New hero? 20 bucks. New skin? 20 bucks. Recolor of the skin you just bought? Another 20 bucks. When you add that Blizzard has also gone back on the promise for extended PvE content (the entire reasoning for upgrading this from Overwatch 1 to Overwatch "2") you can see they clearly did it to maliciously monetize the game. They basically said "we've already made all the money we're going to make from selling this game at 60$, so let's make it "free" and monetize everything else." Its a great game, but Activision-Blizzard is a terrible company and nobody should invest money into their properties.Edit: Even the SPRAYS cost 5$. You know, the cute images you can throw up on a wall? Screw this company.

Author: Gem
Review Content: There once existed two team shooters,  Both were a paid experience at launch. Later down the line these games became free with additional payed PVE content. One was barley updated for over half a decade, while one had a 2 slapped onto it's name. In the end one keeps getting updated while the other wishes for one final major update. But in a twist of fate, The one that was being updated has left consumers with a overwhelmingly negative response with poorly made micro transactions and repetitive game play. While the other with no updates to call its own still strives with a community persisting and enjoying its game play even after more than a decade on the market. These games represent a duality on how the game industry makes game and how in the last decade our landscape has shifted. making it more predatory, with free to play models, making money and content for cosmetics instead of making quality and worthwhile content changes. Although both had a similar start, Tf2 and Overwatch have made highly different outcomes.  Moral of the story? Make the game before calling it a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ product

Author: Symystery
Review Content: I have played Overwatch since May 2016 when Overwatch 1 released. I have around 5,000 hours in the game Overwatch at its core is a good game and always has been, even from the switch to OW2. However it’s terribly mismanaged by the company and they mistreat it’s fans often with false promises and terrible business practices.I love this game, I really truly do, but it’s so hard to recommend even as a fan of this game from the very start. I am only recommending it because at its heart the gameplay is fun, the company however is terrible.EDIT 8/15 Steam Deck Performance: Game works perfectly on the Steam Deck, however you need to use experimental proton at the minute. The developers have made optimizations specifically with the Steam Deck in mind. Going above 60 FPS on the deck is not supported, you can go lower to extend battery life if you wish. The default graphics are a mix of medium and high, which runs flawlessly on the deck with no dips at all. i didn't personally try, but you could probably push them a bit higher, I wouldn't recommend it though.

Author: Intrepid Gaming
Review Content: Let me start off with this: I'm autistic. I'm a 24-year-old woman with heart failure. My lungs are half the size they should be.As a result, I can't physically do many of the things others my age can do. I developed heart failure due to complications from COVID-19 halfway through earning my nursing degree and now I'm not even sure if I'll be able to work as a registered nurse like I've always wanted to. So, I resort to playing video games with friends.The first team-based game I played was the original Overwatch in 2021. It quickly became my favorite game and worked its way into a part of my routine. It was a way to have some control in my life, and as an autistic person, this was appreciated. I worked my way up to Diamond rank in Competitive after only playing for a few months. My favorite hero to play above all others was D.Va because her lore kind of reminded me of my own "lore." Seeing all of the diverse heroes was so cool.And then Overwatch 2 came around. Just like my nursing career, my favorite game was ripped away from me. All of my friends stopped playing, even the one who showed me Overwatch. I can't blame them. The monetization is predatory, the "balance" changes are horrible, and what on earth did they do to mess up the matchmaking system so much?I don't even know why I still play it. I guess I'm clinging on to the nonexistent hope that the game will reach the level of glory it had before. I miss playing with my friends. I miss earning so many amazing skins simply by playing the game. I miss not being teamed up with players who have never played an FPS game in their life.The heroes? I love them. The developers? No, they aren't heroes. But the world could always use more heroes. They have time to change.

Review Content: I've played this game since season 3 and clocked up around 3k hours; every update only made the gameplay experience progressively worse.the 6->5 hero and role lock (ow1) decision has killed the game for me, this is way less flexible and just isn't fun.the balancing team does balancing by not nerfing the OP character, instead they make the counter pick character OP too, WHY??? (you create damage inflation in the process!)I would have still enjoyed this game more if it was still season 13 goats meta.plus, the new player entry barrier is horrible, the company is horrible, the community has only degraded as the cool people just leave and the toxic people stay;this game isn't worth your time.

Author: Toast
Review Content: Only comes 2nd to Bungie in the category of "video game company brutalizes their own product's lifeforce with such keen precision as to rival an obsidian scalpel" Overwatch 1 was hype. It was fun, it was simple, colorful, exciting. Overwatch 2 doesn't add to that, it just coats the whole thing in a stench of company suits' week old piss. The PvE campaign was supposed to be the breadwinner. And it would have been, had it ever come out. They scrapped it, put out a weak version of the free seasonal events you used to get every now and then for 15 corporate-♥♥♥-crusted bucks, which is 75% of what I paid for the original copy of the game before it went "free." Even the steam page itself touts "30+ heroes. 5v5 action. LIVE SERVICE!!! GUYS!!!! WE CHARGE YOU MONEYYYY TO ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ CREAM YOUR UNDERGARMENTS FOR SKINS SAY THANK YOUUUUU WE WILL DO IT AGAIN NEXT WEEK"Tone deaf, completely cringe. Thank god I get to give this a negative review.

Author: ryankrage77
Review Content: I paid for Overwatch 2, yet some of the characters and the story missions are behind a paywall. I already paid for the game! Let me play them!Blizzard's terrible management of this game and greed aside, this is a fun game. I mostly play vs bots, PvE evetns and custom games, and thanks to the in-game workshop, there's endless replayability even ignoring the core PvP gameplay.I am glad to see that the Steam version runs without battlenet, it's refreshing to see a game that doesn't just use Steam to launch another launcher. Since this is the only Blizzard game I play, I can actually uninstall battlenet now :)But yeah, I paid full price for this game at launch and got 0 benefits over anyone starting F2P today.

Author: Tungsten Oxide
Review Content: Most painful 5 minutes, just to be able to review.I enjoy this game, I probably still would if I wanted to play it, but after endlessly being disappointed, I am done.Promises broken left, right and centre. I don't hate the devs, they are doing their best, however the higher ups ruined this game. Overwatch has so much potential with its world behind it, some of the cinematics are the most enjoyable videos for me to watch, they are fantastic and expand on the characters I grew to love over time. However I fully understand why Jeff Kaplan left the overwatch team, he probably knew that his vision was not in the interest of the executives since their vision is filled by money and greed. OW2 to them was an excuse just to release battlepasses and overpriced skins, and unfortunately a fair portion of the community supported that. One of the most wasted potentials I have ever seen in the gaming industry.PvE is why I gave up after all this time. The PvE being replaced by missions similar to those found in events in OW1 instead of what we were going to get is largely disappointing, especially since you have to pay for those 3 bland missions. $23AUD, hell no.I played hundreds of hours of OW2 since its release, waiting and hoping for that hero-based upgrade filled, unique PvE only to be told months later that there was no plan to bring the PvE that was promised ever since OW2's release. I instantly unistalled and forgot about the game, never to touch it again. Yet here I am, because they had to make a desperate move to steam to try and get some players back. If it does bring numbers back and those numbers stay up,  keep going devs, good for you.All I know, is that I will not be one of those people. Thanks for the achievements, I appreciate them. I could sit here and rant about all the frustrating changes that has been made since OW1 released, and numbers have only exponentially grown since OW2. I probably put more effort into this review than blizzard ever has into Overwatch. Sad.

Author: Cxlzu
Review Content: My name is Walter Hartwell White. I live at 308 Negra Arroyo Lane, Albuquerque, New Mexico, 87104. This is my confession. If you're watching this tape, I'm probably dead- murdered by my brother-in-law, Hank Schrader. Hank has been building a meth empire for over a year now, and using me as his chemist. Shortly after my 50th birthday, he asked that I use my chemistry knowledge to cook methamphetamine, which he would then sell using connections that he made through his career with the DEA. I was… astounded. I… I always thought Hank was a very moral man, and I was particularly vulnerable at the time – something he knew and took advantage of. I was reeling from a cancer diagnosis that was poised to bankrupt my family. Hank took me in on a ride-along and showed me just how much money even a small meth operation could make. And I was weak. I didn't want my family to go into financial ruin, so I agreed. Hank had a partner, a businessman named Gustavo Fring. Hank sold me into servitude to this man. And when I tried to quit, Fring threatened my family. I didn't know where to turn. Eventually, Hank and Fring had a falling out. Things escalated. Fring was able to arrange – uh, I guess… I guess you call it a "hit" – on Hank, and failed, but Hank was seriously injured. And I wound up paying his medical bills, which amounted to a little over $177,000. Upon recovery, Hank was bent on revenge. Working with a man named Hector Salamanca, he plotted to kill Fring. The bomb that he used was built by me, and he gave me no option in it. I have often contemplated suicide, but I'm a coward. I wanted to go to the police, but I was frightened. Hank had risen to become the head of the Albuquerque DEA. To keep me in line, he took my children. For three months, he kept them. My wife had no idea of my criminal activities, and was horrified to learn what I had done. I was in hell. I hated myself for what I had brought upon my family. Recently, I tried once again to quit, and in response, he gave me this. [Walt points to the bruise on his face left by Hank in "Blood Money."] I can't take this anymore. I live in fear every day that Hank will kill me, or worse, hurt my family. All I could think to do was to make this video and hope that the world will finally see this man for what he really is.

Author: 俄区难民偷渡侠
Review Content: If Meteorite smashed Blizzard in 2016, it was a legendary gaming company.If Meteorite smashed Blizzard in 2018, it's a game company to be missed.If Meteorite smashed Blizzard in 2020, it's a sad gaming company.If a meteorite smashed Blizzard this year, it is a legendary meteoriteSi Meteorite aplastó a Blizzard en 2016, fue una legendaria compañía de juegos.Si Meteorite aplastó a Blizzard en 2018, es una compañía de juegos que debe perderse.Si Meteorite destrozó a Blizzard en 2020, es una triste compañía de juegos.Si un meteorito destrozó Blizzard este año, es un meteorito legendario   2016年に隕石がブリザードを壊した場合、それは伝説的なゲーム会社でした。2018年に隕石がブリザードを壊したとしたら、それは見逃せないゲーム会社です。隕石が2020年にブリザードを壊した場合、それは悲しいゲーム会社です。今年、隕石がブリザードを粉砕したとしたら、それは伝説の隕石です메테오라이트가 2016년 블리자드를 박살냈다면 전설적인 게임 회사였다.메테오라이트가 2018년 블리자드를 박살냈다면 놓쳐서는 안 될 게임 회사다.메테오라이트가 2020년에 블리자드를 박살냈다면 슬픈 게임 회사입니다.올해 운석이 블리자드를 박살냈다면 전설의 운석이다  Если Meteorite разбил Blizzard в 2016 году, это была легендарная игровая компания.Если Meteorite разбила Blizzard в 2018 году, это игровая компания, которую следует пропустить.Если Meteorite разбила Blizzard в 2020 году, это грустная игровая компания.Если метеорит разбил Blizzard в этом году, то это легендарный метеорит 如果陨石在2016年砸毁了暴雪，它是一家传奇的游戏公司。如果陨石在2018年砸毁了暴雪，它是一家值得怀念的游戏公司。如果陨石在2020年砸毁了暴雪，它是一家令人惋惜的游戏公司。如果陨石在今年砸毁了暴雪，它是一颗传奇的陨石

Author: That1BIGDude
Review Content: Have you ever loved something so much but you had to let it go because the relationship was so toxic that if you did not let go you would go down with them? That is the best way to describe my relationship with Overwatch and despite all its wrong doing I still love overwatch with every fiber of my soul. It hurt me quite a lot to give up on this but just like a toxic relationship I had to cut it off because all it was doing was hurting me.Everything started great when Overwatch first released I was confident that this would be it the next big thing the kind of multiplayer game that would make it to the big leagues like CSGO TF2 and Call of duty. I Loved Overwatch so much that I sunk 500 hours into the console version of the game Just to go and buy it again for PC and sink 1500 in game hours. I loved it so much that I continued to play this game religiously and Continued to buy Loot Boxes when its creators decided that the best thing to do with a freshly blooming game was to drop it and work on a PVE Sequel. This Game went from Number 1 to Lifesupport just because they had to redirect the manpower to make this amazing PVE MMO and Competitive Shooter Hybrid .  They said don't worry it will all be worth it when you finally this new PVE Story  mode we have created. This went on for several Years until finally  when I was just about to give up hope that my favorite game was dead, Came the announcement for Overwatch 2. Finally all our hopes and dreams will be solved. So Overwatch 2 came out and it was Overwatch 1 with less content one less player slot, A brand new monetization model and battle pass. There was no PVE content they said that they just needed some more time to cook and that they did not want to leave the game dead so they were going to start making more multiplayer content while the PVE was still cooking. They said don't worry its coming and this new Payment model is here because we need some extra funds to finish off the PVE. Disappointing  but I already waited this long whats a few more months.  so in those 10 months what did we get? 6 new heroes, 8 new maps and 5 maps removed. Each of those Hero's has been locked behind a $10 paywall. While you can unlock them through progression it can take up to the end of the season to even unlock them if you are  a casual player. Most of the time these hero's are extremely powerful when first released so you are at a disadvantage if you do not have them. Skins went from something you could work hard to unlock to starting at $20 a piece. The Battlepass does not pay for it self like every other game in existence it was not until a few months ago when they started including currency in the battle pass that you can use to purchase only old skins that existed before Overwatch 2 was a thing. The game does offer you ways to unlock premium currency but you have to literally play every single week for 3 whole season to be able to unlock one battle pass. This game does not respect you or your time whatsoever. You know who respects more of your time than Overwatch does? Bing you can use Bing for a few weeks and unlock the same amount of rewards that it would take you 4 months of playing Overwatch without pause.  For several months of its inception there was no way of earning any ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ at all. They also removed Several key QOL features from Overwatch 1 and spoon fed some of them back to us under the guise of new content. There was an extremely useful in game LFG where you could make groups and join strangers without having to matchmake you could do this to ensure you had a semi decent group of player to play comp or if you just wanted to chill with people that actually used their Mics. 10 months later and that feature is no where to be seen  There were dozens of these useful features that were removed for Overwatch 2.So at the end of the day this was all going to be worth it because they were going to release this super amazing fleshed out PVP game that they had to make a whole brand new engine for. I mean who cares about Overpaying for skins when it means that the actual good product that you have been waiting for several years for will be released. So where is the PVP that was promised? Never happening two months ago they told us that right before Overwatch 2 was given its final and official release Date they decided that it was no longer feasible and that they were going to scrap it. So before this "Sequel" ever came out they new that the PVP was not going to happen yet they promised it every step of the way saying that your money was going towards the funding of the PVE content and it was just a short release away. How did they tell us about this news btw? They made a long press release where 90% of it was talking about game mode designed to sell new skins and at the very end of it they said oh btw PVE is cancelled but do not worry we will still sell you the scraps. So the giant full blown PVE was not going to happen but they were still going to release some of the stuff that they already made. But they were going to charge everyone 14-$50 for non re-playable story missions that are barely 45 mins a piece. Every step of the way decisions have been made that have slowly killed this game off piece by piece and its absolutely guts me because I love this  game. I just can't support it because its only going to encourage these decision again. So I have to step away and watch my favorite game of all time slowly die So no I cannot recommend this game

Author: ValyriaN
Review Content: Do i recommend playing this game to play with friends? Yes. At a core this game might be the most fun FPS game there ever was. It has a hero cast that anyone can enjoy and the game does feel very good to play until you start to notice all the bads the game has that will make your hair grey within a span of a year. The first 3 years of the game was phenomenal, Best game ever phenomenal.. But after that they absolutely destroyed this game and yet i kept playing for 3 more years, Why? Because this game at it's core is still good.. I dropped this game because it was getting too frustrating in competitive mode and i don't really play this game casually in quickplay because i think that's the boring version of the game. There was nothing more fun than seeing self improvement and your rank reflect from that but as time went on they started changing stuff.. Now ever since Overwatch 2 the ranks are inflated, pretty much anyone can be masters/Grandmaster now if you put more than 2 hours a day into it. This was NOT the case before. There are an incredible amount of cheaters and that didn't really get any better once this game went free 2 play. So remember that 3 year drought we used to have just so they could focus on the PVE version of the game? Yea, Big fricking mistake Blizzard.. That was really enjoyable to play the game in the most horrible state it was ever been for 3 years just for you to cancel the whole PVE idea anyway and sell it in small bulks for a pretty ridiculous price. What has this game become? If you focused on PVP all those years the game would have been fine.. You know? Why your Overwatch fans started playing games! This game can still be turned around but they just refuse to do so. But hey Illari.. The new support is extremely fun to play ^^ But it's yet another dps disguised as a support you can't fool me, She pretty much replaced Cassidy at this point. I will say.. +1 point for the Steam release and i hope all Blizzard games come to steam because it's just the better platform.

Author: musk911
Review Content: Overwatch 2? More like Overwatch 1.1. The only difference between 1 and 2 is Blizzard putting new heroes behind a paywall, the introduction of a battle pass and the complete removal of being able to get cosmetic items at a consistent rate for free. The reason it's called Overwatch 2 is because there was going to be a massive PvE mode added to the game. When Blizzard announced that this mode had been scrapped it became quite apparent to me that they do not care about Overwatch fans. All they care about is attempting to milk as much money as they can from this IP through overpriced cosmetics and making it so if you don't spend money you have a much worse experience. Want that new hero? Pay us to get it instantly or grind for a long time to finally get it. In a competitive team based shooter, when a team doesn't even have access to the entire roster because none of them spent money that feels very pay to win to me. It's been reported that someone would have to grind 7-8 months to get one legendary skin for free. Or they can spend $23 to get it instantly. Overwatch 2 is an abomination and it represents how hard Blizzard has fallen from the company everyone used to know and love. TF2 better

Review Content: So, overwatch 2, born from the desire to add a proper PvE element to the game, however that would appear to not be the real reason for the 2.0 designation, it seems the real reason was just to add more ways to get people to pay for thingsThe reduction in team size to 5v5 and the complete role lock once you start a match do not make for a better game, freedom to swap roles in the middle of a match was greatBlizzards choice to gate access to new heroes behind battle pass progress was also extremely questionableBlizzard themselves have admitted that the game is no longer retaining players or bringing in the money they had hoped, this is why we even see this steam releaseAt its core the game can be fun, but the mismanagement by blizzard has ruined what was actually a fun game to play with friends and i have hundreds and hundreds of hours logged in it, but this, this does not spark joy :(

Review Content: I bought Overwatch 1 during its release month, when the hype was unrivalled. It was something special, and I have many fond memories of it, as well as many new friends. Overwatch 1 meant a lot to many people who played it back in the day, and it's really sad to see blizzard running this amazing game. Blizzard's greed, ignorance, and false promises let to downfall of this amazing game. It pains me to say this and not recommend it to new players until Blizzard gets their priorities straight. This game could have been so much more man.

Author: XDeadzX
Review Content: Somehow Overwatch 2 managed to make a progression system so bad that it made randomized loot boxes a more appealing progression system.Battle pass themes being limited to 3 characters and then the rest of the theme being released as macrotransactions to complete your set. No battlepass pay-back system either.Overwatch 2 has been a monetization update with little else, leaving us with a 3 year content gap where we were promised work was done on an expansive PvE RPG system that will not be coming to the game.

Author: Gaz
Review Content: Ah, "Overwatch 2," the long-awaited sequel that promised innovation but instead delivered a financial abyss and personal despair. It's like my mother-in-law in digital form: takes all my money, criticizes my decisions, and leaves my family in ruins.Let's start with the microtransactions. "Overwatch 2" basically reached into my pocket, took out my wallet, and started charging $20 for skins. You know, those shiny digital garments that don't keep you warm but do keep your self-esteem artificially inflated? Well, my wife looked at the credit card bill and said, "It's me or the skins, choose wisely." I chose... poorly.Gone are the days when you could earn skins through loot boxes. Now, they just straight-up charge you for them. If I wanted to spend $20 on something I don't need, I'd go to a fancy coffee shop and get a "venti-mocha-something-pretentious."And the game itself? My friends, if you take "Overwatch" and slap a "2" on it with the added bonus of bankrupting players, that's what you get. It's like they took the old game, gave it a new hat, and then charged me rent for looking at the hat.I tried to explain to my kid why Daddy was spending so much on virtual clothes. He just looked at me and said, "I don't love you $20 worth, Dad." It's a touching sentiment, really.So, if you're looking for a revolutionary gaming experience that will not only rob your bank account but also alienate your loved ones, "Overwatch 2" has you covered. Just don't be surprised when you find yourself explaining to your therapist why you value digital pants more than your family's affection.All in all, I'd like to thank "Overwatch 2" for teaching me a valuable lesson: never spend more on a digital skin than on your child's lunch. Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to sell some furniture to afford my next game purchase. And maybe a new family.They promised us a riveting PvE story mode, and what did we get? Three missions for $15. That's right, FIFTEEN DOLLARS! I could've bought three gourmet sandwiches with that money, but instead, I have three digital adventures that were over quicker than my attempts at family bonding.These three missions are like a teaser for a movie that never comes out. My wife asked me why I'd spend $15 on something so short, and I told her it was an investment in our family's entertainment. She then reminded me of our actual investments, like our child's education. Whoops.And the story? I've seen more compelling narratives in my son's finger paintings. If I wanted a shallow plot with no real closure, I'd just read my high school diary.I mean, the graphics are still nice, and I guess the characters are cool, but it's like being given a beautiful cake made of cardboard. Sure, it looks great, but try explaining to your family why you're choking on paper instead of enjoying dessert.In conclusion, "Overwatch 2" is like that shiny new toy that looks appealing but breaks after three plays. My son stopped loving his broken toys, my wife stopped loving my financial decisions, and I stopped loving myself for spending money on this. If you're looking for a game that delivers the excitement of throwing money into a pit while slowly eroding your family's affection, this is the one for you!

Author: LG Kaz
Review Content: Oh boy, where do I even begin with Overwatch 2? I mean, have you ever felt like you were promised a gourmet pizza only to be handed a soggy piece of cardboard with some ketchup smeared on it? That's pretty much the Overwatch 2 experience in a nutshell – a game that's about as satisfying as biting into a pineapple-loaded monstrosity. And speaking of pizza, let me just take a moment to express my undying love for that cheesy, saucy delight. I'd rather have a lifetime supply of pizza delivered by a slow-moving sloth than play another minute of Overwatch 2.But let's not stray too far from the utter disappointment that is Overwatch 2. I mean, Blizzard, or should I say Blizz-NOT, has really outdone themselves this time. And by "outdone," I mean they've managed to mess up a sequel so spectacularly that I'm starting to think it's some sort of performance art piece. Remember when we used to believe that Blizzard cared about their playerbase? Yeah, those were the good old days before they started treating us like guinea pigs in a sadistic lab experiment.Let's talk about how Blizzard treats their female employees, shall we? Oh wait, we're supposed to be talking about Overwatch 2, but hey, it's all related, right? Just like how pepperoni and mushrooms are related on a pizza – they might not go together, but they're both ingredients in the same mess. It's like Blizzard took a page out of the "How to Alienate Everyone" handbook and ran with it, disregarding the very people who make their games successful. But hey, at least they've got their priorities straight, like a pizza with an extra-thin crust and more cheese than you'd find at a dairy convention.Back to Overwatch 2 – I'd rather be stuck in a never-ending loop of ordering pineapple pizza and then immediately regretting it than subject myself to the lackluster gameplay and uninspired design choices this sequel offers. It's as if they thought, "Hey, why make a game that's actually enjoyable when we can just repackage the same old stuff and slap a '2' on it?" It's like ordering a pepperoni pizza and getting a pizza with nothing but crust. Yeah, that's what Overwatch 2 feels like – all crust, no substance.In conclusion, if I had to choose between playing Overwatch 2 and watching a documentary about the history of pizza dough, I'd be reaching for the popcorn and pizza-scented air freshener. Blizzard's ability to disappoint knows no bounds, much like my penchant for ordering extra cheese on my pizzas. So, if you're considering spending your hard-earned money on Overwatch 2, I'd recommend investing in a pizza franchise instead – at least then you'll have a chance of getting some real satisfaction. And who knows, maybe Blizzard can learn a thing or two from the art of crafting the perfect pizza, like how to deliver on their promises without leaving a bad taste in our mouths.But hey, at least Overwatch 2 has taught me one valuable life lesson: no matter how bad things get, at least we're not the poor souls responsible for greenlighting this disappointing excuse for a game. And that, my friends, is something to be truly thankful for.

Author: Unknown
Review Content: I have played this game since the first overwatch 1 open beta. I had been hyped for this game since the first trailer. This game on launch was the best competitive FPS on the market for its time. Pushing the limits of what a team shooter was. Over the course of Overtwatch post release. I put thousands of hours of my time into the game. While originally playing the game for fun, i found myself improving to the point where I had begun participating with open division teams and getting to 4300+ SR on accounts before role queue came out as a hitscan player. I was there for every patch, meeting new people, pushing myself competitively in tournaments with people that at the time i could call my good friends while we spent easily 50+ hours a week playing and improving. watching our POVs, scrimming, and doing whatever was best to be the players. This was a game I was happy to grind at the time enjoyed as I wanted to eventually reach the point of GosuGamers and eventually Contenders/OWL once that was started. Even when i stopped as a player I still found myself doing coaching for players and even managing of a T3 team for a short period.However, this was years ago at this point. After months, the blizzard polish wore off the cracks and flaws of the game would show. While the Dev team has a lot going against them internally, they still failed to create changes to the game that benefit its players or to improve the game. On the contrary, the dev-team actively hurt the game. We went weeks and months with stale patches. Countless new heroes additions, maps, and balance changes that further created an unfun experience for everyone in the game. A majority of the release heroes were fine, even in some niche cases like mei, she still had obvious ways to play against that felt fair. Ana was the only post release hero that felt like an overall good thing for the game. Her sleep, while one of the strongest CC tools we have seen, was balanced around being a 'hard' to aim projectile that could be interupted by anyone accidently waking up a target. It was fair. Other heroes, Sombra, Moira, Orisa, Doomfist, etc. While cool and interesting and had their issues. Which in any game could have been fine, the devs would have done or tweaked these new heroes eventually. This was sadly not the reality for overwatch. Heroes like Brigitte and Sigma were troublesome heroes for MONTHS. Just those two heroes alone tranisitioned METAs into GOATs and doubleshield. Meta shifts are fine, but these were MONTHS if not years of problematic issues that the balance team could never solve. This problem of being unable to create a positive change lead the dev team to attempt multiple rash decisions due to their inability to properly change the game. GOATs became an issue due to the strength of Brigitte's utility and the value that tanks could have over picking DPS. Instead of making radical changes to try and change up the meta, they threw in the towel and introduced 2/2/2-rolequeue. Now, this obviously fixed the issue of GOATs, but it felt like a band-aid fix. Sure, GOATs was definitely strong but i never felt that attempted any major changes to target the team composition due to fear of targeting players to make them feel weak. (Personally i loved GOATs btw, it was one of the most technical metas we had and individually each player held so much strength to improve from GM-top500 mechanically in this meta. the main people that hated GOATs was ironically the flex-dps players that were stuck on brig.)Then it was sigma with double shield right after. The near impenetrable shields of Sigma/Orisa would wreak havoc. The fast paced way of playing GOATs was replaced by a shooting shield sim. Sadly, the dev team again showed they were unable to make any significant change to the meta. This is what lead overwatch 2 to be a 5v5 game instead. Losing the possibility of Reinhardt/Zarya comps is one of the saddest decisions to happen to this game. Every major change that effected gameplay has only further limited the game.Not to mention Blizzards fear of reworking or touching problematic heroes for months. It took MONTHs to convince the devs during launch that hey, maybe having a mass-revive on a support hero. Leading to camping inside the spawn room to wait for ults on 2cp maybe wasnt the best choice. But this was all overwatch 1, the dev team worked to improve overwatch 2 right? They had put ow1 on life support, leaving players with a huff of copium every few months to keep our spirits up. So what came to ow2 after leaving the existing players left to rot?While heroes were reworked, to remove CC and PVE to look out for, Everyone was hyped for OW2. Even at the time it made no sense to re-release the game outside of money reasons but that was put to the aside, excited for what was to come. and what came?- We lost 6v6 for 5v5 due to failure of the dev team to balance. We lost the possibility of many compositions and interactions because the team couldn't figure out balance. Reinhardt/zarya - Winston/D.VA - Orisa/Sigma. All iconic tank compositions just gone from ever existing again- We lost many features from OW1 - on fire, previous season data, loot boxes. some of this is still being RE-added into OW2.- we LOST the PVE originally promised, shown and that was playable. For 4 years, the dev team worked on something that never existed, and even though they knew they were no longer providing on their original promises. The dev team kept it behind doors that PVE was trashed in what was promised for the watered down PVE experience that we had already played X amount of times. the Replay-ability heavily reduced, and player freedom was gone.- After Blizzard killed HOTS pro circuit around the rise of OWL, they just killed it recently as well, with a mass-layoff of people I had known or interacted with previously.- We lost 2cp for a gamemode thats just as frustrating. Teams were punished for winning the first fight due to counter picking on 2nd fight. Losing the possibility to gain momentum due to losing ults % or forced into playing in an unfavorable comp.- Skins that were in the game since release were re-slapped with a price tag. the only fully functional thing in overwatch 2 was the battlepass and shop. The battlepass would also lock new heroes behind a slow grind for free players.The steam release is not a decision to get more players but only for the money so that execs that see theyre in the green in their quarterly calls. Blizzard is no longer the company that has the players best interest at heart, only its shareholders. I feel bad for the Devs that put blood sweat and tears into their games just for them to be shells and forgotten relics of the time where they used to be and I hope they are able to transition to other companies successfully. I hope that OW and other blizzard IPs can make a turnaround eventually. But in the current state, i do not recommend OW2. There are better alternatives at this time for both casual and hardcore competitive players.
