Author: Mr. Cele
Review Content: I downloaded this again to write a reviewI'll  try to write an honest review hereI have according to my profile in game 156 hours clocked in.I bought this game back when it came out on the Beta phase, back then I was seriously pissed that Blizzard didn't acknowledged they took inspiration from Team Fortress 2, going above and beyond to erase any comments, ban people on twitch chat, erase forum posts instead citing to call of duty as the inspiration, well fast forward I still compare this to TF2 and it still falls short from the fun factor that game provides.Let's start:Gameplay:The game is solid it has always had great gun-play and satisfying movement.Netcode:Back in 2016 I raged at the "shotee wins" system instead of the "shooter wins" philosophy they adopted, for the uninitiated allow me to explain: net code wise the game calculates your position multiple times a second to check where you are and some games do a clever trick where with an algorithm they calculate your possible movements to compensate for lag, this is not something new, something similar is used in newer fighting games with GGPO. Back in topic, this system allowed blizzard to give people with bad connections a fighting chance, this sounds great in paper right? The problem was the implementation of it using the philosophy of the guy who was shot has an advantage, let's say you are playing tracer with a bad connection and someone is shooting at you and it's about to kill you and you break line of sight with a wall, in most online games you would be killed because on the screen of the shooter you were not yet behind cover. But with this new way of doing things the system would favor the person with a bad connection and you as the shooter would see the last hit not count this was quickly picked up by many and abused by using small plugins, .Jsons, scripts that introduced artificial lag allowing them to gain an upper hand in combat, cheaters aside for some reason back then Battle.net would match with with people too far away from you, Brazil being a constant (you could check this by seeing on windows the IP server to which Overwatch was doing a connection) I quit the game back then for the span of months.Fast forward they ironed the system out and regardless of the Shotee wins you can barely feel it on a normal match nowadays, still for the purposes of a review this is a minus as it should have not happened at all.Skill floor: easy to pick up and playSkill Ceiling: I thought Blizzard games were all about easy to pick hard to master, this doesn't feel like it's the case anymore at blizzard it feels more like "cater to casuals, maximize profit" OW feels a bit weaker when I compare it to TF2, as highly skilled players in TF2 make a greater difference on any given match, while in Overwatch it doesn't feel as big of a presence, I would argue Overwatch needs to allow great players to stomp on weaker ones, specially considering Blizz saying they took inspiration from titles such as Unreal Tournament and Quake. I don't see TF2 Soldiers rocket jumping into boot squash a n00b across the map just to RJ escape and while shooting a rocket at some one else only for a Pyro to use it to push into ground to RJ himself to chase that soldier in the air and kill him with an Axe!!Sorry out of character for me.Game modes: while people only talk about competitive and casual matches I feel the other modes OW introduced are great, I always criticized they being seasonal, to me it felt like a strategy to keep you playing in fear of missing out rewards.Community maps not accounted here since that is not Blizz's making.Balance: I feel this has not been solved all these years later, back in TF2 you didn't get new classes but weapons that changed skills and made them variations of the class, some changing how the class was played completely, Overwatch went for the character path and somehow matches still feel off, newer heroes as a general rule feel over tuned bar some exceptions, in my eyes locking team compositions killed most of the fun of the game as for me being able to quickly adapt was a key component of the gameplay loop. Class roles feel a bit of a lie to me as they can do many things besides being a Defense/Support/Offense/TanksGraphics and Design: Top notch not much to say here, the maps are gorgeous, the graphics look great even on potato PCs running the game on low, artstyle it's what I expect from Blizzard and character design, I mean there's a reason there is so much P*rn out there.Speaking of P*rn I know Blizz will never acknowledge it but the reason OW became popular to begin with was the P*rn and it needs to be said.Music and Sound Design:fantastic the music is great although the leitmotif might feel forced into everything at times, sound design it's the best for me as skills have specific sounds, footsteps let you know which character it's about to come out of a corner, voices are clear and the voice acting is great regardless of language as I played it in multiple languages over the years.Story: What story?!?!??!?Progression: honestly I don't like it, feels generic levels, the lootbox system was the begining of a dark age of gaming as it popularized and fortunately slowed down when EA stepped way too far with Starwars Battlefront 2Medals for you levels are great, but I feel there is no real bragging rights attached to it, No special cosmetics or anything.UI: Feels good, I would like a bit more numeric information but it's a solid 10 out of 10Monetization: God awful, skins were expensive to begin with having them attached to the lootbox system and made worse after the switch to OW2 with skyhigh prices and obnoxious battlepass system.Not a fan of the battle pass even though I was one of the first to applaud Dota 2's battle pass back in 2013.Since I started talking about monetization now I have to talk about OW2, to begin with the 2 is a lie, it's no secret, everyone feels the same. The game doesn't warrant the 2 on it's name, hardly an expansion, from the minor things of hero introductions feeling lifeless now to the blatant cashgrab that it feels like. Yes the game went F2P, but we all know they did this have a second "Release" window and monetize the F out their customers.New maps are great, new characters feel nice to play, wouldn't call them brilliant or groundbreaking in terms of innovation though.The steam release I feel was a low move trying to get a third "Release" window and people see though it, coming hot from the fiasco of the story mode gutted off the game, the sole reason the game had the 2 in the name to begin with.I had the chance to closely work in the Esports scene for OW as an organizer and a shoutcaster.We hated working with OW, the spectator mode it's a joke, having CS:GO's client as shining example of an spectator mode. We worked closely with the amazing people at Blizzard Mexico, I only have praises for them.But also very inflexible, we programmed our own API to get more game data in search of bettering the spectator experience, and Blizz HQ in CA shut us down while pitching it to them.Once the OW League started all community hype died out as they would never have a shot at the big leagues unlike other games where you can climb up raking competitive points.That aside watching OW matches is Boring AF, as a caster you make boring stuff interesting, theorize on the fly, take analytical data from previous matches, make predictions, but when you gut the game so hard as to have restricted classes, a lot of that goes down the drain, not having that bird's eye for the longest time also hurt the viewership.I am aware many of these have been fixed and corrected, but it's too little to late, as the hype dies down the longer you take. Case in point: the OW League being a huge disaster.OW I feel it's basically over, it's reversible. But today August 13 2023 I cannot recommend anyone play OWgo Play TF2 instead and have a blast

Author: The Tatted Native
Review Content: After enjoying Overwatch 1 for many many hours, and finding good friends on it and playing engaging pvp, I am severely disappointed with Overwatch 2.     They got rid of a lot of features I adore, and after promising pve play at launch (for people who pre purchased a specific bundle) they suddenly change their minds, and waited until like 2 days ago to release 4 pathetic missions with ANOTHER DLC. So I have purchased 2 separate DLC'S for the pve play and got shafted.    Battle pass system's are becoming outdated. I would have been more than happy to purchase the full game, if everything came included with future patches/updates.   If you are someone who has not yet played this game, but are interested, take my word for it. Pass on this one. Go and buy Baldurs Gate 3, because THATS how a development company should make games. No micro transactions, everything included at launch.

Author: Escalusia
Review Content: My honest review of Overwatch, as someone who played since OW1 Beta and Launch, and someone who has always played Blizzard games.Overwatch was the first and only FPS I was ever able to enjoy. I loved the art style, I love how snappy and clean the game felt. It felt like that Blizzard polish people would always talk about.Back in OW1, I loved sitting in queue to even get in the game when a new hero or event would launch. For events, I'd always buy 50 lootboxes and my friends and I would look through the newest Christmas Wonderland, or whatever event, skins to see which ones we should try and earn, or which skin we'd want to spend 3k credits on. It was a routine, for every event. I'm not beyond spending money in a game, but with the way OW2 is, you'd be without a home if you were to buy everything you thought was cool. The magic of events is gone. You look through the new skins, which each cost $19 or so. An insane price for something you used to get for free, and something you hardly see when actually playing the character.The battle pass is also insane. For 80 levels, you don't even get 10 skins, or if so, only barely. The rest is padded out with relatively useless stuff. You don't get the premium currency to buy the next pass either. Sure, you get legacy credits, but they are hardly useful as you get so little, or for me who has everything they can buy and 13k more to spare from OW1. They took away a game I loved, in promise there'd be PvE and progression and story, but what I got was a massive fee to get anything in the game. PvE is not necessarily cancelled, but in truth it is. There are PvE missions, which are only 15min ish each, and you have to pay to play them, but without any replayability or progression. That was what we were promised. There'll also be many months between getting new missions. For something that only lasts 15 min, it's not worth paying for.To buy a single OW2 skin, I can pay for a WoW subscription. Though the games are not at all similar, the amount of content you get out of your money is insane. There's so many games you can buy for the same price as some of these "bundles" of recycled content.Because every skin, the pass, the heroes, the events, all cost money to some degree, there's no reason to be excited about anything. If i had to spend $20 every time a new shop item came out, or a new event dropped, or $10 to get the pass, I could easily have bought so many games by now. Games full of content, and certainly stories longer than 15 min.I am not a hater of this game, on the contrary, I love the game a lot.But there's no soul or integrity left of it. It's all for money, and the game I purchased is gone.I respect the developers who make this game, and has put so much of their talent and love into it. They are not responsbile for what it has become.This is not a review bombing, this is me missing and lamenting a game that they killed and replaced with a cashgrab.The good:- Visually beautiful game, with a large cast of fun characters- Fun Mechanics The bad:- They are only trying to pry open your waller- The soul of the game is lost- The battlepass is bad- The skins are insanely expensive- Pay to play story missions- The balancing is always rattledThe sad:- Just a fan wishing I could look at the event skins with my friends and we could all dress up without having to spend money, and loads of it combined. Missing being excited for this game.

Review Content: Pros+ Mega Transactions!!+ New $30usd skin bundle every week!!+ Map changes from day to night across seasons as content!!+ No new maps so you can get better at playing 7year old ow1 maps!!+ No progression so the $20skin feels more valuable+ Deleting 3 years of pve work shows true commitment to the pvp aspect which remains the same since ow1 to make it more accessible to new and old players!!+ Adding no new heroes makes it easier to learn ow1 heroes+ Adding worthless heroes makes it easier to pick a hero from a small pool of useful heroes+ Buffing good heroes and nerfing bad ones really makes it easier to choose a hero to play!!+ You can support your favourite overwatch league teams by paying $50usd for their team skin!+ No lootboxes!+ Zero skill based matchmaking in competitive/ranked!+ Blizzard even creates heroes in their image making the best hero yet, lifeweaver!+ Creativity and morals are really just obstacles in game development so removing them really makes the process more streamlined and efficient, Blizzard are true innovators in the gaming industry and have long been a shining example for others to follow in their footsteps. This is the best timeline.Cons- Literally none!- More games arent made like overwatch 0.83, a true shame.  I was an overwatch 1 beta player

Author: totspur fc HATER
Review Content: -10/10Opened up for 5 minutes just to say:Welcome to Team Fortress 2. After nine years in development, hopefully it will have been worth the wait. To listen to a commentary node, put your crosshair over the floating commentary symbol and press your primary fire. To stop a commentary node, put your crosshair over the rotating node and press your primary fire again. Some commentary nodes may take control of the game in order to show something to you. In these cases, simply press your primary fire again to stop the commentary. In addition, your secondary fire will cycle you through all the commentary nodes in the level. Please let me know what you think after you have had a chance to play. I can be reached at gaben@valvesoftware.com, and my favorite class is the Spy. Thanks, and have fun!

Author: Astolfo
Review Content: I’m gonna do a genuine review cause I don’t think anybody should play this game despite me playing it. Overwatch is pretty clear that the devs don’t play their game. With the mid season 5 patch notes, they’ve stated that they’ve buffed headshot damage to a spam character to “promote accuracy.” Not only that, they ONLY look at statistics for their games and see if stuff is working. The downside is they’ll see a character have a 50% win rate and think it’s balanced. But the character can be super boring to play. Another aspect is they’ve completely gutted their PvE despise the whole selling point for overwatch 2 is the PvE. It’s just sad, and embarrassing. Even though they’ve switched their dedication to the PvP. It’s still super frustrating to play. They’ll take forever if one character is busted, if the change isn’t good. You have to wait another 30 days to see if that patch notes is good. Not only that, the whole Activision Blizzard team don’t care about their employees or their player base. With the terrible lawsuit including stuff such as stealing breast milk, sexual harassment which caused one of their workers to suicide, and unfair treatment to their women workers. It’s just sick reading through the allegations of the lawsuit itself. Not only they lack care in their workplace, they don’t care about you as a player. They gutted Overwatch 1 just to monetize heavily off of you, the balancing of this game is absurd and overwatch lying to us for the PvE. At this point, if you want a F2P team based shooter. Play team fortress 2. If you want to spend $15, I recommend buying a game that comes from labor of love instead coming from a horrible soulless industry. I personally recommend playing Oneshot, great game. If you still want a PvP game. Get Battlebit Remastered. Somehow a 3 dev team can add more content than an AAA studio.

Author: CakesInAPan
Review Content: I have been an avid player of Overwatch since its first release in 2016. Don't get me wrong, this game is very fun and I still play to this day (I'm at well over 2000 hours through Battle.net). I do think that if you haven't tried the game yet, you should definitely check it out for free, but it is not worth it to spend another dime on this game than what has already been invested by players over the years -- it will only lead to your inevitable disappointment. Blizzard needs to review the already overwhelmingly negative reviews from its users. Overwatch 2 was supposed to already have PvE. Overwatch 2 was supposed to already have access to new characters without them being hidden behind battle passes. Overwatch 2 was supposed to be an upgrade from Overwatch 1, and though some decent changes were made, I'd prefer Overwatch 1 any day; I think it's obvious most players would agree.Blizzard, get your sh*t together. People are tired of your broken promises. Learn from this - If not for your current patrons, then for your potential future ones.

Author: ouseVen
Review Content: Overwatch is like seeing your superhero in action. Overwatch 2 is like meeting your superhero in real life.Never meet your heroes.The first game was something cool and in some ways even new; even though hero shooters have been out there for a long while, it had it's charm and brought people to play this game. Of course, like every game, people have been losing interest, because the same thing over and over got boring, but it still was quite enjoyable. The thrill of opening a lootbox after levelling up, playing new modes with innovative mechanics, mixing up ultimate abilities to create crazy combinations; it was fun.The first game died so much that devs became desperate enough that they announced a second game with a promise of PvE, which everyone found exciting, because the missions presented to that time were fun to play. So, they closed the first game and launched the second.The PvE was, of course, delayed which was okay, because we were getting new content at the time. There was hype for the new release, but soon after; I can vouch for the word: immediatelly people noticed that it's the same thing. Same mechanics, same playstyles, they just removed 2 slots from your typical Overwatch matchmaking game and added new characters. Not only that, but devs also decided to put everything and I mean everything that was free behind a paywall; characters, charms, lootboxes, skins. You name it. You practically can't get anything new without spending real money for this game. They replaced beloved by community free lootboxes with a pathetic battlepass. Their excuse is that the mythic skin (the last reward you get) takes "very long" to make. Which is understandable, but it's only one skin for one character, nothing else. They've added nothing that was worth of people's interest. They ruined the balance of the game by removing stuns, nerfing the existing characters and adding incredibly powerful characters behind, would you guess it? A paywall or a lot of hours of grind. Nevertheless people who pay have the advantage. Worst part? They've broken their promises, cancelled the only thing that people were hyped for and now Overwatch (2) became a poor excuse of a cash grab game.

Author: myta
Review Content: This review will mainly be about the PVE, because the PVP deserves a seperate one. If your explanation for these overwhelmingly negative reviews is that we, gamers, are "Toxic", then you are completely missing the point. The game is but a shell of what it used to be. The PVE missions are unpolished, have low content, lack any replay-ability, and moreover: It's not even close to what they promised and I'm not only talking about the cancelled Hero mode when I say that.An amazing well polished coop experience that is challenging, fun, and engaging at the same time? That requires you not to abuse your developers/employees. You can see the devs had passion and vision, but that doesn't matter anymore nowadays. Because corporate greed and misconduct on the work floor taints everything. Missions; Cinematic are great, voice acting is great, animations are great, character interactions are great, story is nice. Gameplay? Too little of it and that which is there is mediocre.The AI is dumb and has very little player interaction. Difficulty is inflated by adding more health and damage. That's it. Elite enemy? More health, more dmg, still dumb. Play on higher difficulty level? Same thing. Nothing changes. AI doesn't get smarter and interactive, spawns are the same, there's just no love given to it. The Event mission has you grab heavy batteries that disable movement abilities and slow you down a ton, they're also quite a bit away from the objective so you have to overextend a bit to get them. However, no enemies get aggrod when you pick them up, there is just one of them you gotta kill in order to obtain it. Why not just spawn a wave of enemies so your entire team has to protect the VIP?I remember in the Archives Storm Rising missions, day 1, when playing on legendary the spawns were actually well thought out and encouraged tactical and cooperative play. But then they reworked the mission on day 2, and that is when well thought out coop was replaced with artificial difficulty inflation. Big enemy, big health, big damage, just peak for a few seconds to damage them and repeat infinitely until they die. Braindead gameplay, that invalidated our day 1 victory, as it spawned less enemies too.These reviews have a bandwagon, yes, but you can't just ignore reality. Gamers are toxic indeed, but that is not a valid argument here. That is not why we are outraged about how Overwatch 2 and 95% of all other AAA games have been soulless money making machines (not you Doom Eternal, Elden Ring and more <3).I'm sorry devs, you are amazing, it must hurt for you to see all this happen.I get why Jeff left, I hope he and all others that left are well <3

Author: Zombiefish1
Review Content: Pretty fun game, however it has a lot of issues and it has absolutely awful management from blizzard:- New game modes are ok, but nothing to really make me excited for.- Matchmaking is pretty slow, but games are still usually one sided.- OW2 removed a lot of basic features from OW1 which are now being added back as "updates".- The f2p model is just really bad, skins are awfully overpriced and old OW1 skins take an entire season to earn compared to a couple of levels in OW1.- The game having heroes being unlocked halfway in the BP (unless you pay for the premium version) feels quite unfair and almost "pay2win" in a hero shooter which has a massive emphasis on counter picking.- Seasonal events are usually boring and honestly feel less interesting/fun than the OW1 events (cough Starwatch).- The PvE that was promised (and was the entire reason OW1 turned into OW2) is actually 3 missions for £15, without any skill-trees or replay value.Honestly OW2 just feels like a worse version of OW1 in almost every single way, especially since the PvE feels like a cop-out (the main thing everyone was looking forward to was just removed because blizzard higher-ups realised they can make money from £40 skin bundles instead of actual game content). It really sucks since there is a really fun core game, but i just cant recommend it to anyone.

Author: DudeTheJesus
Review Content: TL;DR — a messy game that has it’s moments but ultimately isn’t worth your time due to ActiBlizz's incompetent management that led to inhumane working conditions, horrendous monetization, broken promises and disappointingly shallow & tone-deaf narrative.It’s insane to see a Blizzard game in Steam, and hopefully I’m gonna be one of reasons they’ll regret it (lol) because I’m about to tear this game a new one. Don’t mind the low playtime count — I’ve been playing OW for 760 hours since the release, it’s my second most-played game. So when you see me critisizing the hell out of this game, it’s not because I simply dislike it, but because I have a very personal connection with it, and there was a time when I not just liked, but loved this game.- MonetizationThe second-worst part of this game. OW1 popularized lootboxes, and while they are 100% bad, they nowhere near as bad as the battle-pass system OW2 uses. First, Blizzard preys on the famous Fear Of Missing Out (FOMO), and does so in a VERY stingy way, where without paying you get only the most bottom-tier items imaginable. In OW1 you bought the game, and while it was definitely incentivising buying lootboxes, you could get what you wanted without them — sometimes it felt grindy, and that sucked, but now we’ve got something much worse. In OW2 you buy battle-pass and get what the game gives you, with very little chance to beeline towards what you actually want, especially since skins are now sky-high expensive. This game was not made to be playable — it was made to be profitable, and that’s a disgusting &  exploitative way to develop games.— StoryTHE reason I personally have so much beef with this game. OW had a huge potential when it comes to lore, story and characters — but it was always spoon-fed to us at rate so slow everyone except for the most devoted fans have long burned out and stopped caring, even for that animated series Blizzard released recently — something we would’ve gone insane for 5 years ago! But instead we’ve spend many years waiting for a story to just get out of the “first chapter” phase! And those years were filled with nothing but neglect for both worldbuilding & characters, to the point where waiting for Zenyatta content was considered more a meme than reality.— RepresentationOW is very prideful (pun intended) in how progressive it is, while doing less the absolute bare minimum in this department. It took six years for them to add a black woman! And considering the next thing I’m going to discuss, their talk about respecting minorities is exactly that — just shallow talk to appear progressive without actually understanding what it means and which standards should they uphold themselves to.— Just awful peopleIf you were wondering, what’s the worst thing about the game — it’s the executives at Activision-Blizzard. There was a pretty long period where you couldn’t spend a day withough learning some awful new thing about them. Sexism, racism, frat bro culture that’s so toxic a woman committed suicide, STEALING HUMAN MILK FROM FRIDGES (YES FOR REAL) and the unpleasant implications Blizzard creates in their writing of omnics and human-omnic conflicts in OW lore, culminating in releasing OW2 trailer where Brave Policemen fights Those Omnics who are fighting for their rights But In A Bad Way, all that amongst HongKong-Blitzchung scandal (which is a whole another can of worms). Activision, Blizzard and specifically Overwatch team are not ruled by good people, and that directly affects both human lives and the quality of the games they’re making. Hey remember when they justified OW2 by announcing a full-fledged PvE campaign and then scrapped it? Because I do.~ GameplayI’m a game-designer myself so it’s usually easy for me to understand why I dislike certain games. However with OW I’m having a rough time to decipher the specifics, so apologies in advance if I’m talking out of my ass. Anyway: in my opinion OW, while has it’s moments, is a giant on clay feet, aka a good game with shaky foundations. A good online-game can last without new content for a long time, just look at TF2. Overwatch? I’m shocked it lasted as long as it did, with the whole Waiting-For-OW2 hiatus thing. The game feels restrictive — every time players find an unintended way to have fun, it gets cut immediately, at best being available only in custom games (and don’t even start me on the balance — OW is a perfect example of a game that is way too overbalanced). And even those custom games feel like a piece of what we truly needed — a game editor. Some game only as good as the freedom they provide to the player, and OW is, sadly, barely provides it. But hey, at least some characters are really nice to play — I love Zenyatta, he’s just one of those characters that feels AMAZING when you’re good at playing him. Over 7 years he was barelly touched by balance changes, and that says a lot. That’s probably why OW1 lasted during hiatus — even despite the whole mess Blizzard is today, some devs really, REALLY cared. And it shows. Sometimes. So let’s talk about positives, eh?+ Sound-designNow this is something for other devs to look up too. This game will never get you confused — each enemy has it’s own sounds for walking, attacking, using abilities, etc. Sound-design is clear and nice in this game — you could use this game’s sounds for ASMR if you want! I really like Bastion’s walking & shooting sounds for example. Bastion is a treasure.+ Visual styleAlso nice and sharp. The game looks good, both in terms of graphical fidelity and art-style. I dislike some things in it (especially sexualised designs, dear Lilith, how can someone feel no shame for designing Widowmaker LIKE THAT), but in genetal it works perfectly well, and creates a really unique impression. Also the animation is really good — every character is very well animated, and their animations often work as a characterization tool — Soldier-76 reloading his gun in a very brief, very professional manner, as a soldier should, while Junkrat’s custom-made gun shakes so hard it’s a miracle he’s able to hold it. However I dislike the redesigns they did in OW2 — they were simply unnecessary, especially considering how OW1 designs have became iconic to the point that even those who had zero interest in the game can recognize at least some of the characters.+ AccesibilityI both mean this as in “making the game accessible for disabled people” and “getting people into pvp and/or shooter games”. For example, OW has really good color-blind options, to the point where even I, a person with no color blindness, use it, to make the game easier for my eyes, and they also have subtitles — which is, sadly, quite a lot by the standards of PVP-shooters. And this game introduced A LOT of people to the genre of PvP-shooters and shooters in general, which is always appreciated. It takes a special skill to make a gameplay that looks alluring even to people who were never interested in games of that genre before.+ OptimizationWhen you are used to online-games taking from 80 to 200 Gbs you really appreciate a game that takes only 30+. And it runs well too — my old laptop was a dated piece of junk already back in 2016, but OW was perfectly playable at 30 FPS & low settings. Idk how well OW2 plays on similar devices today, but I haven’t heard any complaints.

Review Content: Having around 900 hours in this game, playing it since 2016, I can say that nowadays overwatch is a shadow of what it used to be, and I can't apreciate it for what it is now.Regardless of how you feel about how Keplan's direction with the game, starving it of content for 3 years, that was better then what it is now. Alternatively you can work yourself to the bone playing this game like it's a resposability, in order to get the battle pass for free after 3 seasons (5 months total) every week. Which is what I did since it's launch. Some of it I regreat it, some I don't.Put that in perspective with the old model where we could get the skins we wanted for free, just by playing.The gameplay is still good, for what it's worth. It's what kept many of us playing it during the 'dark days of no-contentness' after all. It's still a better team-based shooter with powers, ultimates and what-a-not than what you get from games of the same genre in that regard.The beggining of Overwatch was something special. I am sorry if you missed out.

Author: Diplopia
Review Content: In the realm of digital entertainment, where innovation and immersion flourish, Overwatch emerges as a perplexing enigma that both tantalizes and ultimately disappoints. Nestled within its vibrant facade lies a litany of missed opportunities and a pervasive sense of unfulfilled potential.One is immediately struck by Overwatch's visually arresting design, a mesmerizing tapestry woven from a palette of vivid colors and intricate character designs. Yet, as the allure of its aesthetic charm settles, the enchantment wanes under the weight of repetitive gameplay dynamics. The essence of innovation feels diluted as the core mechanics remain tethered to time-worn tropes, rendering matches as a monotonous rhythm rather than a symphony of strategic diversity.Regrettably, the narrative landscape within Overwatch is a barren terrain, devoid of the profound storytelling depth that contemporary gaming enthusiasts have come to anticipate. The game introduces a promising array of characters, each with their own hints of intrigue, only to consign them to mere two-dimensional archetypes. With the rich potential for immersive lore and interconnected narratives, the game's narrative shortcomings constitute a glaring misstep.The allure of multiplayer engagement within Overwatch is undeniably powerful, fostering a sense of camaraderie and competition. However, the experience is marred by a perplexing dearth of meaningful progression. The ephemeral thrill of winning a match fails to find resonance in a progression system that feels arbitrary, lacking the satisfying crescendo of accomplishment that distinguishes titles of this genre.Beyond its intrinsic flaws, Overwatch is overshadowed by a culture of toxicity that has permeated its player base. What could have been an arena for mutual admiration and spirited competition has descended into a breeding ground for vitriol and incivility. The developers' ostensibly well-intentioned efforts to balance the game frequently feel like belated remedies rather than proactive solutions, further exacerbating the prevailing sense of frustration.In conclusion, Overwatch stands as a testament to untapped potential and missed opportunities. The allure of its entrancing visuals and initial gameplay charm belie a deeper reality of stagnation, repetitiveness, and narrative shallowness. It is a somber reminder of the pitfalls that await when creativity and innovation are stifled by adherence to convention. The echoes of Overwatch's potential serve as both a cautionary tale and a lament for what could have been.

Author: Astraea
Review Content: Hooooo boy. Okay.I've played this game for many hours under the blizzard launcher, and I played the hell out of Overwatch 1.Please don't spend money on this game. They removed Overwatch 1 (a product I bought) and replaced it with the free-to-play Overwatch 2.Changes- 6v6 turned into 5v5 with a single souped-up tank- new heroes are no longer automatically available to everyone. Either pay up to access, or get ridiculously far in the free battle pass. This game is built around counter-picking heroes, so they've gone into pay-to-win territory- You used to get a lootbox for every level you earned, and seasonal events added seasonal items to the lootboxes. This meant that if you played the game a lot, you would get access to most customizable hero content. Now they barely give anything for free- In place of lootboxes, now you can buy things directly from a shop. Prices of new skins are around $30. Think I saw a bundle of 2 skins for $50- Graphics upgrade- Day/Night lighting for maps- Small hero balance tweaks- Removed some maps- Added some maps with a new game objective typeFrankly, there's not enough in that list to justify this being a sequel to the game. They cynically did this to force people to use their shop. They TOLD us the sequel was justified with all of the PvE content they were going to do, and they were just releasing it early, temporarily without the PvE content. Months later and we find out that the PvE content was cut, and replaced with a hollow simulacrum of what was promised. Blizzard is always looking to make a buck, even through unethical means. They've lost their soul to greed. The company that made fun games, that put the player first, is no more.

Author: Nexo
Review Content: Overwatch 2 is nothing. The game doesn't bring any emotions whatsoever anymore. There is no sense of progression, the ranked games you get are never equally balanced, you either stomp or get stomped.The balance patches are too infrequent for a game like Overwatch.Lastly, coming from a tank player - the replacement of 6v6 for a 5v5 model made this game so much worse it's incredible. 70% of joy coming from playing tank was the synergy between the 2 tanks. Now I feel like every ranked game is a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ of counterpicking, you want to play junkerqueen? Some dork will pick orisa or zarya, you want to play rein? Some other dork will also pick orisa or ball or whatever to just make you miserable and leave you not wanting to open the game ever again.Don't get me wrong, this game still has so much unused potential, maybe one day they will bring back the old ranked system along with 6v6, I've always liked overwatch for the originality, never have I seen a game which requires 12 players for a match, but I loved it and I spent countless hours in that game, please don't waste overwatch, it doesn't deserve it.

Review Content: I remember being down on Overwatch "2" when it was announced, this game looks no different, am I missing something? Oh there will be a full PvE campaign, like a true single player or co-op experience, but does that warrant another game entirely? I must admit I was pretty narrow minded back then and have to admit my faults when they come to light, Overwatch 2 is not the exact same as Overwatch 1, I was silly to think so and have done some reflection in my time playing the game since launch. Overwatch 2 is nothing like the Overwatch I bought in 2016 and loved, it is entirely, fundamentally, worse. Higher up devs were so busy stealing coworker's breast milk and sexually assaulting interns they let so many absolutely mind bogglingly bad patches and gameplay changes through the door I hesitate to even call it "development" anymore, this is more like demolition. LMAO nice c9 Blizzard, you had the game won and got off the point by releasing this "sequel".

Author: Spoonerang
Review Content: Game as a game is fine, plays well. Enjoy the free game, however I can't recommend giving Blizzard any money. This "sequel" is just an update to gameplay that the community had to wait about 3 years for as well as a major downgrade as far as everything else is concerned. Overwatch "1" was deleted in the process so earning the past cosmetics (from OW1) is a slow grind that probably isn't worth it, as they encourage you to spend money to skip the newly added grind. Game is ultimately a disappointment and doesn't deliver what it promised to do as a sequel. I used to joke and say it was a glorified expansion in the early announcement days of Overwatch 2 (showing off the campaign content and etc) which I guess would have been accurate but now it doesn't even feel like a glorified update, it's more like a downgrade across the board, with decent 5v5 gameplay. There's still fun to be had with it, sure, but it's tough love especially for early supporters and fans of the game. We deserved better.

Author: Shizar
Review Content: I have been playing Overwatch ever since it's first halloween event and I had the displeasure to see what was once one of my fav games to play slowly be butchered and turned into a shallow cash grab that stop prioritizing the fun of the player and instead it prioritisez figuring out what other gameplay feature they can lock behind a paywall. I've seen the game that once had a vision get destroyed by bad balancing,awul hero design,0 care from the devs by reusing the same events over and over again barely changing anything. And Overwatch 2 was ment to be the game that fixed it all and gave us back the amazing game we all played and enjoy,however that didn't happen. Instead the game felt like it took away stuff from the player with no real reason. It locked away heroes in a game that was design with counter picking in mind,it took away loot boxes that gave us a reason to play,something to look forward to to get,it wasn't much but hell it was something. But now I can play several matches and get nothing from it. Yeah there is a battlapass and yes there is SOME free stuff in it but the grind to get any of it is way higher than getting 1 singular loot box. But Overwatch 2 died for me when they announced PVE was officially out of the picture since that went against what this game was ment to be. Jeff Keplan himself said that he wanted overwatch 2 to be STRICLY a PVE expirience( Source for what I said[www.dexerto.com]) and as a way to move the story more forward,however as I said that was not what happen and this is probably why he left the company. Now even the PVE content which is what I was most hyped for is now just another cash grab. 15$ for 3 missions with very little replayability. And for anyone that will look at my profile and see that I played tf2 and will try to somehow use that as an argument against me let me make it clear that I was never into the whole Overwatch vs TF2 argument. Hell I wanted overwatch to be BETTER than tf2 and there was a time I preferd this game over tf2. But one game has plummeted into infamy as a cash grab ran by people that can't decide if they wanna harass my wallet or the poor girl employees while the other still having it's issues is looked at with fond memories as a classic and staple of the class based genre and it's still going strong after 16 years.

Author: GankAlpaca
Review Content: Pros+ Now on steam+ Accessibility options for people with colorblindess (not as customisable right now), motion sickness and poor eyesight+ Support of more aspect ratios added back Cons- The release of ow2 was just a marketing move. They didn't release any new characters during ow1 to then release 3 character at ones with ow2 to create a feeling of something productive being done while it was just postponing the release of characters.- Free to play is not an advantage but rather a solution to the game being bad and people leaving. Ow1 had never been having problems with online while the game had good balancing and content.-Cosmetic item prices. Legendary skins that you could get in like 2 weeks of passive playing or randomly from a FREE lootbox now cost 20$ each and furthermore you now are only able to buy some on specific days due to introduction of the shop. -The game tries to trick you into spending more money out of lack of knowledge of the buying system or from being clumsy. It is easy to buy something accidentally or buy useless stuff in a bundle thinking you can't buy it independently. -The prices. It is less costly to buy a real keychain charm in real life than it is to buy the same charm in game.-HUD. HUD quality has fallen significantly. It is a change just for the purpose of existing and not solving anything.  1. The main menu was changed and now it is weirdly spaced and some buttons were moved to Escape menu which now makes you press extra buttons if you want access something quickly.  2. Escape menu is now not transparent. This makes it hard now to change some setting if you are in a middle of a game since you can't now see what is around you. Some people may prefer opaque menu due to motionsickness and I understand that but why not just make it a toggle option then? 3. The option to adjust HUD borders is hidden inside game's config which can cause trouble for some people with old displays or non 16:9 aspect ratio users. 4. Useless details being added to the first person ui like transparent lines in the corners of the screen. There is nothing wrond visually but again it's just a change for a change. It adds nothing just obscures your vision in the corners and makes the ui look weird when you adjust screen borders leaving you with floating sharp hud parts.-Matchmaking and game modes. Quickplay is just a worse ranked. Quickplay has a SBMM system which uses hidden mmr to match people. This makes quickplay more competetive. You can get a similiar feeling of what sbmm is from games like DBD or COD MWII. Moreover there are weekly challenges that require you to win in quickplay and other non-competetive modes to get crumbs of shop currency thus resulting in sweaty games in chill modes. Quickplay doesn't even have rewards of the ranked mode.I'm too lazy to continue with the cons of the game so I will just end it here. Don't spend a dime on the game unless things get better.

Author: Ikolo
Review Content: TLDR: No, don't play this game.In 2019, Activision Blizzard began slowing down the frequency of updates and patches in order to focus on a new endeavor for the game. The last major patch for the game was on April 14, 2020, with the addition of the then newest (and last) hero in Echo, 8 months after the latest hero, Sigma. Overwatch got its last official update on June 16, 2020, where the game then sat on Blizzard's shelf, collecting dust as they began working on a shiny new version of the game in Overwatch 2, with an attempt to add in potentially a very strong, very dedicated PVE version of the game, complete with hero missions, hero talents, and a replayable, story driven game mode. This was not something seen from no where, on November 1, 2019, Overwatch 2 was announced, which is why people initially expected, and for the first while, may have accepted the slow down of Overwatch 1's updates and patches. Little did the community know, that it would essentially be killed off in order to focus more development on Overwatch 2 and it's PvE elements. After two years of little to no updates for the game, the community became vocal, angry, and unhappy with ActivisonBlizzard's lack of updates to a still live, still active game, with no true signs of progress of the upcoming, and highly anticipated 2 that was being slapped on the back end of an already established and successful game.With numbers dropping and interest waning, ActivisionBlizzard made a bold decision to finally release Overwatch 2's brand new, never removed from box, PvP version, in an attempt to sate the community that was picking up its torches and pitchforks. This was a successful attempt, a transition to 5v5, a new coat of paint on a pretty well liked game, new heroes, new maps, new game mode, but more importantly, actual content updates. People began putting down their medieval riot equipment (a good chunk of them anyway), and sat down to re-enjoy a game they've long been waiting to see some progress for. Things were okay, but people were still foaming at the mouth for the highly hyped and overly promised (we'll get to that) PvP element that would justify the 2 in Overwatch 2. Updates? Few. Progress? Seemingly null (sector, heh). Anticipation, still growing. Then finally, after years of waiting, salivating, and chomping at the bit for PvE news, we were given a big announcement in May in regards to the long overdue PvE mode for Overwatch 2. That announcement? We're not getting it anymore. For that brief period that the community was pacified with new content, during which time people were hit with paywalls for new heroes, hit with overpriced skins, hero breaking bugs and glitches that would take a week or more to fix, but with a shop that was fixed within hours of going down (let's you know they CAN be quick). But the rage had swelled up once again, this time, with the added fury of broken promises and intentional lies spoon fed to us by ActivisionBlizzard, that by this time, the community began looking at as nothing more than a small snow cloud left behind after the winter season. How were these lies intentional? Simple, by the time the launched Overwatch 2 PvP, they seemed to have already decided that PvE would not be happening to the scale they had foretold.To some, this came as no shock, the company that had pulled one team from the prior successful game to work on its "successor" and then made them work on two games simultaneously, one already Walking (as by their crawl, walk, run strategy) and the other still developing on the game room floor. Made to work through an environment fraught with harassment of varying types, an abusive hierarchy within the development teams, top end leadership that seemed to ignore and potentially even encourage it all, and even through someone being driven to losing their fight with their own inner demons. To those that remained hopeful, most remaining hopes were dashed and broken. In place of the large candy store called "endlessly replayable story missions" that was promised, it had been replaced with a mere few hours of PvE content, very similar to what we had already been receiving, the equivalent of the gas station candy section at the checkout counter.The game typically in ebbs and flows of imbalance, overpowered characters, and occasionally actually good balance, which once had a very promising and strong start, now seems to be in its death throes, as the community once again has risen up, spewed their hatred for the course this IP has taken via deceit and heavy monetization. Would I recommend this game? No. If you play, I do hope you enjoy the game, because games are meant to be enjoyed, so I sincerely hope you find fun in it, but seeing where this game has gone after playing it almost since its initial launch in 2016, I cant find the fun in this game anymore, and I'd highly recommend looking for something else. I hope the game and the community that is still active there treats you well. At least you know through all the chaos, the in-game store will always be at peak performance.

Review Content: ♛  𝙂𝙧𝙚𝙖𝙩 𝙜𝙖𝙢𝙚 𝙧𝙪𝙞𝙣𝙚𝙙 𝙗𝙮 bobby kotick  ♛To anyone saying this is a troll review heres my full review:Servers are still actively being ddos'd and the game can be sometimes unplayable.Servers have been downgraded in general since OW1 has been ended:Your ping might seem lower than it was in ow1 but it doesnt matter, your Interpolation Delay (IND) is always fluctuating between 22-27 and sometimes goes up to 29 which basically makes noregs happen every second and desyncs what you see clientside vs what actually happens serverside. (moxy loves this)basically, worse hitreg.ITS BEEN A YEAR BLIZZARD, PLEASE FIX THX.FPS overall is worse, dropping from 300-400 on low settings 1080p in ow1 to 180-300 in ow2 on my budget setup (ryzen 5 3600 gtx 1060 2x8gb 3200mhz) meaning 240hz is no longer an option even tho this is suppose to be an esport title (but i will be honest it has better optimizations than tf2)TheCommunityTM is still terrible and will continue being like that since blizzard (bobby kotick) has fired most of the employees that moderate and review chat reports to cut down on the budget and fill his pocket furthermore :)Basically people spamming the n words with hard r's is kind of common and 90% of the time they dont even get banned lolsmurfs are as common as ever making each rank feel meaningless + many boosted diamond player can be grandmaster or even top500 (and many of them mfs exist)(cheaters are fairly common aswell nowdays)top500 rewards are non existentback in ow1 you used to at least get animated season sprays as a reward for finishing as a top 500 ladder player but those rewards have been gone ever since ow2's release haha pve (real talk i dont care about pve that much)game got no updates for 3 years because of the "RPG pve" that was planned for ow2 that eventually got scrapped, oh well.anyways heh what a game, used to be a great game by a great company, now its a shell of its former self, and the company is long gone, corrupted by greed (bobby kotick)

Author: Spider-Gypsy
Review Content: downloaded it just to give it a negative reviewI bought overwatch back in 2016, and it was a fun experience back then but Blizzard has no clear direction for their game and just allowed the community to dictate balance changes was laughablePvE got me hyped despite the content drought the first game suffered, but I was looking forward to the PvE because the archives mission were bangers (except storm rising since that was just there to tease sojourn and hype ow2)I started to notice red flags in the game's development when they released pvp early and made it free to play so they can excuse in implementing the F2P monetization model into its shop.... Jeff Kaplan leaving the company before the release of PvE.... until they said it to our faces in a stream it was entirely cancelled (The road map was only there to let us down easily to show us they got something cooked up.... but I assure you, past season 6 they have no plans what to do in the future lol)This is why this game deserves the reception its getting at... They promised us a good game with great features and highly replayable missions only for that original vision to be scrapped and its remains sold to us for $15 (and thats only for the first 3 missions, I would've gladly paid $60 to play the 3 missions with my friends if the talent was added)... Dont even get me started about features from Ow1 being added back and they're hyping it up like its a positive thing (Which shouldve been there from the start lmao)sad thing this game started out strong but due to greedy higher ups and ♥♥♥♥♥♥ upper management its lesser competition at the time like Paladins outlived this game lol (Tf2 still reigns supreme)

Author: raidebaron
Review Content: How to say it... Overwatch 2 is a disappointment.Back in 2016, this game, formally known as Overwatch, was a breath of fresh air in an industry that had grown stagnant, who kept on relying on DLCs that were splitting the playerbase for every bit on content. While it was retailed at $40 ($60 for it's "Origins Edition"), Overwatch gave access to a plethora of great heroes to play, varied in their unique design, gameplay and personality. You also had the possibility to customize your hero with a selection of detailed skins, all of free (but you had to depend on luck thanks to the game's lootbox system), you could also buy said lootboxes, which quickly could go awry if left uncheked with player's addiction, and of course it all was made by design to squeeze out the money out of their players. But we didn't complain as much as today's system because there was a way to get all of the cosmetic items for free, you simply had to play the game. If you had duplicate items in your lootbox, they were converted into coins to eventually allow you to get the items you wanted. While it was an imperfect system, it certainly was fairer than the economic system in place today.But Overwatch 2's core was shaken by the departure of Jeff Kaplan, the former director of Overwatch. And came crumbling down to the whims of the Corporate wind. And it was rebuilt on a foundation of Deceit.Of Lies.Of Greed.Back in 2019, just a few months before the world went down the drainer with the Covid-19 Pandemic, it was announced at BlizzCon that the game would recieved a sequel simply titled "Overwatch 2". With a newly upgraded engine to boot, Overwatch 2 would have something that players have been clamering the developpers about for years.A actual campaign. A bigger, bolder and more ambitious PVE mode that what was available with the Archives Event at the time.While it was unclear at the time how this PVE campaign would be implemented within the game, it had bold claims such as "Highly Replayable CO-OP", "Level Up Your Heroes" and "Customize Your Abilities". We were promised a deep gameplay to allow us to customize our heroes abilities, and not just how much they hurt Null Sector's omnic goons, but how the abilities work.You could have had Tracer's Pulse bomb explosion spread amonst all enemies in a chain reaction.You could have had Mei turn into a snowball to crush her opponents.You could have had Genji shoot out cutting light circles with his katana.You could have had Reinhardt perform a 360° Earthshatter all around him.And more...But in late 2022, Overwatch 2 finally comes out on Battle.net (Blizzard's proprietary launcher), and consoles. And players the world over comes to understand how much the game has changed... for the worse.You're a new player and you don't have the old heroes? Either pay up for the Hero Bundle, or play 150 games to unlock all previous heroes up to Echo (Excluding the newer ones: Kiriko/Sojourn/Junker Queen/Ramattra/Lifeweaver/Illari and all future ones).You want to play the newest hero? Either pay up for the Battle Pass to unlock them instantly, or grind half of it to unlock the latest hero.You skipped a season in which there was a new hero? Either pay up to unlock them, or grind some challenges in the Practice Range and win 35 games in All Roles queue or playing that hero's role in "Quick Play", "Competitive Play", or "No Limits" (and don't forget to activate that challenge, or it will not count towards it. And you cannot cumulate between two locked new heroes).Don't have a phone plan? You're out of luck because you can't play the game, now. "Blame the cheaters, smurfers, and toxic players", they will tell you.You are no longer a player to them. You are only a living wallet to them.Your concerns mean nothing to them. Only your credit card has worth to them.Your critisms are falling on deaf's ear. Only what they want to hear is feedback to them.I want to hope that things will change for the better, I want to keep on supporting it but the reality is the following: I do not expect anything to change. I do not expect them to reconsider, or change their business model.I do not expect them to stop locking out the newest heroes behind their Battle Pass.I do not expect them to offer those who actually buy and grind their Battle Pass some "Overwatch Coins" (their premium currency) like most of their concurrents Battle Passes do, like in Fortnite.I do not expect them to treat their players, and more importantly, their employees with the respect and decency they deserve.I do not have hope that they will wake up from this nightmare, and stop spitting on their golden legacy like they've done with Warcraft 3: Reforged.I do not have hope for this game. Nor this franchise, or the company at large.Perhaps when Microsoft finally closes on acquiring Activision/Blizzard, things will be changing for the better but I'm already disillusioned to hope that it will happen."Overwatch was shut down for a reason. It's time to move on."

Author: Excaliux
Review Content: I loved Overwatch. It was at one point my favorite FPS game back in the day. Before I quit OW1 due to the game not getting updates, I reached mid diamond and was a Tank main. (Reinhardt and Roadhog) Overwatch 2 feels like a downgrade compared to Overwatch 1. Overwatch 1 wasn't perfect by any means. At the very least, OW1 whether having good and bad games felt rewarding. OW2 however made the issues that were in OW1 much worse. This series has been ruined for me. As much as I would love to see the game succeed. Blizzards stubbornness and desperate greed will be their downfall and it makes me sad.Overwatch 2 has: -Fun but also horribly balanced gameplay-Competitive is hardly functional, the last time I played, I ran into players that were 3 competitive ranks below or above me.-Competitive toxicity is extremely prevalent in the community, especially racial and discriminatory slurs that don't get addressed. Yet people can get banned for simply saying the F bomb. Potentially really biased reporting system. -Gatekeep heroes behind a battlepass that hardly rewards you for completing it, Causing FOMO. The Battle pass is awful. Especially the free pass.-Stupidly overpriced skins. Blizzard was once a more generous company. Now they're greedy and desperate, especially due to allegations and lawsuits (which they 100% deserve). I understand wanting to make money, but how do you go from ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to a legendary skin being over 20 dollars. Skins should be priced so much lower.-The Developers maybe listen to 20% of what the community wants and the other 80% is spitting in the faces over everyone who loves Overwatch. So many people spoke out against issues, especially the overpriced skins to just be ignored.-Worse events (For crying out loud, they gave a Winged Victory Mercy skin that was once free in OW1 AS AN EVENT REWARD and their current events ADVERTISE THEIR OVERPRICED SKINS)-They cancelled the indepth PvE... Yknow, the whole point of being a SEQUEL??? The snippets they have left CHARGE YOU 40 DOLLARS FOR 3 MISSIONS. I can play Elden Ring and have so much more hours of gameplay than like maybe 2 hours of gameplay at most with OW2. -There is no feeling of progression anymore, which OW1 had. They shove the stupid battle pass in your face. (Levels and the border changing when you reach a certain amount of levels)In conclusion: OW2 while being a fun experience, was much more fun when it was OW1. Do yourself a favor and play another game. Don't get yourself into this game, it's not worth it. If you want good FPS games, there is better out there. It makes me sad to say this but this games negative reputation is sealed and there is no coming back from it.

Review Content: 守望先锋：归西，给暴雪一点3%的小小震撼如何在不下载游戏的情况下愉快的打差评评测条件：通过挂时长软件添加游戏累计6分钟即可PC端：watt toolkit（原steam++）ASFSAM移动端：云挂卡APP如何从库中移除游戏主页 > 帐户 > 许可和产品序列号激活：点击移除即可或者客服 >> 我想从帐户中移除这款游戏来点客观评价暴雪、考迪克死一死的话估计无数人在刷了，总要谈点客观的，不然会有些自觉中立的人说点未经他人苦，却劝他人善的风凉话先说公事：停更几年，画了N年大饼的守望先锋2就是这玩意？改动还没个版本更新大，这些年员工都在忙什么？办公室性骚扰？看看当年守望2预告CG动画里老玩家的弹幕，现今看来只有2个字：心寒。逼肝骗氪就不说了，反正暴雪现在也就只会这个，我的战役模式呢？信誓旦旦的PVE一拖再拖，张口就是为了玩家更好的体验这些晦涩难懂的词。再聊私事：账号承载着老玩家的青春回忆，见证了和朋友一起欢笑犯糗的时光。你说没就没，这就是您说的为了玩家？向钱看嘛，不寒掺，哪怕您站直了脊梁骨，说几句真话，我对您的鄙夷也能少那么几分，来洗的暴白也会多一点。中国玩家不重要，但中国玩家的真金白银很重要。新玩家的避坑理由在这里，你能感受到如同上班一样的游玩快感在这里，你会发现皮肤出的比版本更新更加勤快在这里，你可以体会到原汁原味的正宗暴雪式傲慢在这里，你能够看到无数新的承诺簇拥出的艰难决定在这里，你将游玩一个拒绝中国市场和中国玩家的高贵洋产，玩之前，先低头再折腰。结语：再不刷差评，我可要给三国杀打好评了哦

Author: MyST
Review Content: The biggest issues with OW2 (and blizzard)Ranked:- blizzard artificially increases the grind to higher ranks by forcing 50% winrate for everyone for more "player engagement," giving you leavers, griefers and AFKs or just extremely bad players resulting in unwinnable games half of the time.- sometimes they won't even count your wins if your winrate somehow manages to go too positive.- their philosophy consists of: "more playtime = more potential in-game purchases made" and "more playtime = better player engagement."- nearly every game of ranked is a hard stomp one way or Author: Dr. 痛み™
Review Content: Overwatch 2 puts overpriced monetization and greed first, and player enjoyment lastI've played many hundreds of hours of Overwatch 1, ever since the game released. They made me not want to play a game I used to love and play frequently, and here's why.They replaced Overwatch 1, a game many people paid for, with Overwatch 2. In my opinion, they succeeded in fixing some aspects from OW1 that made it unfun in its latest stage of life. Since they did this and had such a great base, the game is mechanically (and in general) pretty fun. However, do not be fooled: Overwatch 2 is just the same game with a big update. They removed things people liked from the previous game and are slowly introducing them as updates, which is pathetic, it does not make sense at all."Progression" feels way worse, huge downgrade In the first game, you would level up (level is visible in matches, you get more eye-catching borders as you level up) and get "lootboxes" (each day you could easily get various of them without playing too much) very easily just by playing the game. Now, here's the thing, lootboxes granted all kinds of things: skins, profile icons, emotes, coins, etc., and keep in mind they were very easy to get, I have not payed a single cent for lootboxes and got most of the skins from the game (and there are so many). Most events were exciting mainly because of the new skins they'd release, which were really high quality and appealing.In this game, they removed levels. Now you just "advance" in the season pass, which is an extremely worse system than before, I'll get to why in the next part. If you don't pay, chances are high you will just get 1 or 2 things (or maybe even none) you actually want to get, after playing a hundred hours. Why the previous lootbox system was better than battle pass + item shopI know it sounds crazy for people who have not played it, but it really is like this. Anyone who played Overwatch 1 thinks this. This is because the previous system, while it was a "chance" to get something, you'd always get something valuable, and in case you didn't you'd eventually get coins to just go to the hero gallery and purchase whatever you wanted. So yes, even if it's a chance at getting something, it was a FAIR system, and the game did not entice you to buy lootboxes anyways. I get that Overwatch 2 is free and I'm fine with them changing this, but there are several things that make it unacceptable, which I'll explain.Overwatch 2 monetization feels more UNFAIR despite you knowing what you are getting by spending money (if you do). Overwatch? More like, Overpriced. Everything in this game is OVERPRICED. Legendary skins cost around 20€. This is NOT a fair price for a skin in a game where you don't really see the skin yourself unless you emote (it's a first-person game, you'll be just seeing the weapon most of the game). I'd rather buy a game with that money instead of some skin. So let's see: if I wanted to buy 5 new legendary skins (which are the worthier ones, besides the "mythic"), I'd have to spend almost 100€. That's insane and really not worth it. In the past, spending 0€ you'd get many legendary skins each day and each week.Events are now meaningless because the gamemodes are not that exciting, and if they are (and some of them are indeed really fun) then they usually get old after playing a few times, so you'll just go back to the standard game. The main appeal from events and what they marketed heavily were the new skins released. In Overwatch 1 it was guaranteed you'd get at least one legendary event skin, and then chances were big enough that just by playing you'll get another one, or coins to buy another directly. Overwatch 2 made me not look forward to pretty much ANY events because I'll never buy a skin for 20€, it's so stupid.Battle pass is also not worth it: it's a much worse "progression" and reward system than before. It includes some free rewards which you can get by just playing, but they are sooo uninteresting most of the time, it is really not enough. You may get one or two ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. If you pay for the battle pass (I think around 10€) then you get many rewards (they change each season), the last reward being a "Mythic" skin, which are skins you can customize slightly, and look much cooler. However, to get these rewards even if you paid, you still have to grind for them, and if you don't have a lot of time to play you may not even get the Mythic skin which is the worthiest reward in it always.Also, due to the nature of the game (how many different heroes it has, and you may not like or use half or more than half of them frequently), chances are VERY HIGH that the rewards on the battle pass do not appeal to you. The battle pass has this limited amount of rewards, and since you'll be frequently using half or less than half of the heroes, then you will just be interested in less than half of the rewards, which makes it not that interesting. Instead of giving you fixed rewards like a very specific skin in the battle pass, they should grant coupons (at least 2 per battle pass), that you can exchange for a skin. This would be more interesting and more fair, would make the battle pass much more valuable, and people would complain less.If they had made monetization NOT OVERPRICED, and if they basically hadn't introduced this monetization system into a game people purchased before (Overwatch 1), people would NOT be complaining like this. Every single bit of criticism is deserved.Competitive and hero unlockingThe competitive system has been one of the biggest focuses for the Overwatch devs for a long time. I won't go into too much detail, and it's been a while since I played ranked so I may be inaccurate, but it's worse in a few ways: ranks are not as visible (among players) in-game for some reason (they removed this, which makes no sense, you wanna display your rank since you are usually proud if you rank up), rank gets hidden and updated after a few matches. Matches take a while, so someone who does not have too much time to play may take like 1 or 2 days to actually see their rank change. However, this system is pretty frustrating, because you may think you're doing well these few matches and then when you reach the time to update the rank, boom, it stays the same. It feels pretty bad, such a bad system.New heroes now need to be unlocked by playing. Heroes that have just released are unlocked instantly by buying the battle pass, and can be unlocked for free by playing a lot. People can play competitive WITHOUT having unlocked certain heroes, and this is a HUGE problem they shouldn't allow. Overwatch is a game where switching in the middle of the match and counter-picking is very important. While most of the new heroes so far are not essential, having a Kiriko against an Ana gives you an advantage, since her grenade gets rid of the flask effect. Therefore, playing competitive in a team that does not have a Kiriko unlocked would put this team in a disadvantage. These are the kind of situations that can happen with this new forced greedy unlock system, that is put into place by rotten higher-ups who prioritize squeezing money out of their customers instead of actually making the game fair and good.ConclusionThere are many other problems I haven't mentioned. I still find Overwatch fun in its core gameplay, and I really wish things changed for the better. Sadly, the way the game currently is makes me, and many players, not want to play it. Competitive feels frustrating and like a chore. Getting anything is grindy at best and does not feel rewarding enough. Gotta pay (too much) for almost everything. Not enough enticing content released. I may just play a few matches to remember old times with friends of mine, and then I may drop the game forever. Such a shame. Goodbye, Overwatch.
