Author: oracle
Review Content: I don't think I've ever seen a bigger fall from grace than Overwatch. I put well over 1000 hours into the original Overwatch, and seeing what the game would eventually become, I'm somewhat ashamed of that now.Before this is labeled as "just another Overwatch 2 hate review," let me say that the gameplay is very nice. 5v5 plays way smoother than 6v6, and it genuinely feels like your picks matter now. However, good gameplay does NOT validate everything else about this game. I could go on for DAYS about how Blizzard took a game we payed upwards of 40 dollars for away from us, make it free-to-play, take everything we once received for free just by owning the game and lock it behind 20 dollar paywalls, I could talk about the three year development cycle this game had, just for Blizzard to scrap everything and feed us Overwatch 1.5. I could talk about the broken promises, the lies, the unspeakable acts that happen regularly at Blizzard. I could mention the shop, and how on paper it's a much better idea than lootboxes, the idea of buying a skin you want instead of gambling for it is amazing, but Blizzard sells recolors of the basic hero skins for upwards of eight dollars. You just added a form of levels to the game (which we used to have levels anyway but yeah remove something that had no harm on gameplay), why not let us earn currency by increasing that level? It doesn't even have to be every level, just as milestones or something.The point I'm trying to make is that the game itself isn't bad, everything surrounding this game gives it a very negative aura that sadly is deserved. I don't think any person who was a fan of Overwatch wanted Overwatch 2 to fail, but when it comes to disappointing their playerbase, Blizzard never disappoints. I can't even play this game without being reminded of what it used to be. I'm not acting like Overwatch 2 is where Overwatch suddenly dropped in quality, but I can safely say this is where it was made apparent. It's like they looked at the lack of content and constant recycled event modes from 2019-2022 and just said, "What if we made the sequel all about a lack of new content?"It's honestly depressing to see how far this game has fallen.

Author: Bluepoison
Review Content: Oh Blizzard... Where do I begin? Let me start of by saying, I have nearly 2k hours in Overwatch and started playing the game in late 2016. I've been through many different phases of Overwatch. I have a few main reasons why OW2 is a shadow of a game from its predecessor and it greatly saddens me that they've deleted the original game and in its place, this disgraceful want-to-be version of what used to be Overwatch. I'm certain that it's been more than thoroughly complained about when regarding the micro transactions, battle-pass model, and locked heroes and so for the sake of originality and to add some more points that I feel are worth discussing, I'm going to skip those parts. 5v5 -- but why? One of the main reasons Overwatch thrived, in my opinion, was the great need of teamwork, collaboration, creativity, and team composition. Each team was given 6 slots to fill and eventually these slots were role-based: 2 tanks, 2 dps, 2 healers. This was one of the most well-received patches (role-based queue) and bolstered the game-play. It was balanced, even, fair, and fun and offered many diverse team-comps that could be executed in any number of ways. Sure there were still "metas" but overall 2-2-2 was a lot of fun. In Overwatch 2 they have taken away one of the tank positions but kept the role-based game play in place (you can play a non-role-based version but it's less popular) so now it is 1-2-2. To help compensate for this, Blizzard made the tanks "tankier" and "stronger" and not to mention they moved a hero who was a DPS hero, to the tank role; though not the hero that would make much sense i.e. Doom Fist. In my opinion this is the most likely reason for the decline in popularity and reception of the game in general; removing 1 tank and creating a 5v5 game. just like every other game with team-based strategy... Overwatch was different and more fun than other similar titles due to the variety of heroes and back stories and flexibility that the game offered. By taking away one of the roles, you've in essence created a "super role" because the entire fate of the game is dependent upon your now only tank. Due to this, the tank role is a high-pressure, high-risk gig which requires utmost focus and attention in order to succeed in and as a team you must support your tank or lose. This is very frustrating when your tank is clearly new, trolling, or both, and creates poor game quality and in fact, most games are uneven and extremely poor quality; likely due to this reason. When it was 2-2-2 there was another tank who could help compensate for the downfall. There were synergies that could be executed and one may even argue that some tanks were only good with their counter part, such as Road Hog and Orisa. 5v5 is not fun, it's not dynamic, it's not Overwatch.  Lighting and Sound Effects When compared to OW1, the game is completely different. A different engine, different lighting, different feel, different sounds. The guns sound... like toy guns even more-so than before. The lighting in the game, while it is cool it can be adjusted from night to day on various maps, this has created confusion for me since I was so used to the maps being the same time of day. I've even gotten lost on a map I was familiar with due to this! Now this is obviously my opinion, but a fact of the new lighting system is that it is more difficult to see enemy heroes and it lost its "Overwatch" feeling and now feels more like a generic shooter. The gold shimmer on the guns, looks too real; what I mean by this is that the guns don't have a glowing essence about them, they are just gold. Like the plain gold you may have seen in real life, the dull and boring kind. I worked my ass off to get gold guns on many characters all to have a less flashy version... tisk.  Match MakingLast but not least we've arrived at the worst part of the game which is the match-making. Every game is either you destroying the enemy team or vice versa. There have been FAR FEWER, [i[if any[/i], intense Overtime plays, C9 moments, clutch wins/losses and the competitiveness of the game feels... off. This is in part due to the 5v5 system, but in large part, it is due to the matchmaking. Why is it as a plat player I am matched with silver players? This makes no sense and creates a horrible game experience for everyone. Every game feels like an uphill battle to either carry your team, or lose (when playing tank) and on every other hero it feels like you are a side show to the main event, the tank battles. It's so boring, static, and creates only toxic games. I can only imagine how higher tier players feel when they too get gold players in their games. It's not fun and hasn't been fixed and in fact is allowed per the tier descriptions which state that any player within 2 tiers can be in your game unless you're in masters (if I recall correctly) which is insane. This means as a gold player, as most Overwatch players are, you can have bronze players potentially in your lobby as well as silver or even as high as a diamond player. This creates a false sense of competitive game-play and leads me to only one question... What is the point of ranked if I still play matches that are nearly the same as quick play? The whole point of ranked is to compete at the highest skill level you are capable of and try to improve your personal performance, maybe it's your aim, maybe it's your style, maybe it's your communication skills; whatever it is, the point of ranked is to improve upon your own game play as much as possible and try to ascend the ladder to a higher tier. The point of ranked games is NOT to achieve fast queue times, make players feel included or special when they are in higher tier games, it is not to create imbalance which is the current state of affairs when considering ranked play. Your rank is utterly meaningless if you do not get to play with players of a similar skill level and instead play with players far above or below your skill level. Due to this, your rank truly means nearly nothing in this game unless you make it to master where you will finally have a higher degree of balance. This is not fun AT ALL.Overall, the game is not worth your time or money at this juncture. Blizzard has some serious reflection to do if they think they can keep rolling over the original fans to obtain new ones and retain that business. It is the original fans that bought the content, played the game, watched the streams, watched and helped fund the Overwatch league and it is in our faces that they now spit with this Overwatch shadow that they call Overwatch 2. I could rant on for hours on end about the mistakes and missteps made with this game, the hero balance (there is none it is balanced for pro play only), battle-pass, pay to win feeling, horrible map design, poor decision making, etc. as could many of my friends whom have also been playing since 2016 but it falls on deaf ears and closed minds. Nonetheless I hope that Blizzard can rethink its business model and the way they treat their players/fans in the future. It felt cathartic writing this out and that was my primary goal and intention. If you made it this far, thanks for reading.

Author: Smokey da Burrr
Review Content: Played since launch of OW1. OW2, besides being an obvious scam, has been a great disappointment in most aspects. Nothing that ruined the first game and turned away the community has changed. Regardless of the desperation they find themselves in, they continue to employ the same exact practices that drove the community away in record breaking numbers.Despite the fact that balance changes are (according to devs) made almost exclusively based on high tier meta, the game is still horrifically unbalanced. The devs are actively mad that you are not playing the way they want you to and will gladly take away any enjoyment you had here to fix that. Most changes seem to be based solely on the metric of which hero is being played the least, which can be hard to tell since they have made SO many heroes so un-fun to play. At that, the changes (you'll recognize this if you've played basically any other game from blizzblazz) are always polarized into extremely small and unnoticeable changes to characters that the community has complained about, and game breaking changes to the dev's current favorite that makes competitive borderline unplayable until the "oopsie we're sorry" patch three days later. Tanks often invalidate DPS, made worse with the fact that healers are basically expected to pick up some DPS as well. Snipers still dominate at all levels of play thanks to mobility differences and more than half the roster being in one-shot range. Torbjorn is still Torbjorn.Many heroes are now locked behind paywall, and players are able to enter into competitive with these heroes locked.New heroes can be unlocked in the season they released in by playing a certain amount of hours, but older heroes remain locked if you didn't buy OW1. Combined with the hilariously low requirement to gain access to competitive, low to mid tier ranks are plagued with inexperienced players who do not access to mechanics and strategies players who have paid for characters / been around and had time to unlock them in the battle pass. Premium currency in the original game could be gained by getting duplicates from loot boxes that you got for free at every level up, but for the new F2P model they've opted to make the premium currency MUCH more difficult to obtain without purchase. They're charging 15-20 USD for premium shop and league shop exclusive skins.Any player you asked would have told you that no one wanted a battle pass system but they did it anyway. Content of the battle pass seems to get worse with every season, loosely tied themes and leftover concepts to throw at the players so they'll subscribe to a service that they may or may not even get their money's worth from if they don't put in enough play time and pad our player statistics. This has been made even more evident in the Invasion season where the PVE content is being released episodically, which has proven to be desperate in basically every game ever. PVE content, of course, was the main selling point of OW2. In case you haven't heard, they lied about this entirely and have since made an official post backtracking on their promises for story missions and hero levels. DO NOT BE FOOLED - the Invasion update is said to contain "story missions" and "hero progression" but the story missions are they same ♥♥♥♥♥♥ 4 man co-op mode they made for some events in OW1 like Junkenstein and the hero progression is a sad shadow of what they originally promised us, with the added insult of not tracking any stats retroactively, so they expect us to care enough NOW to level our characters up for a reward of.... nothing.Truth be told, I was skeptical of the story-based content in the first place, considering the dev team uses every opportunity they can to inject politics into the game at every possible turn, literally releasing short stories about characters with the sole purpose of revealing their sexuality (you can reliably guess that they're not coming out as straight). By now we're all aware that Blizzblazz does not hire good writers or care much about their stories but the quality of those famous cutscenes that this company is widely known for has decreased and the dialogue is a little more cringe than your average Mahvel movie. This company has done nothing but lie to you for years. Do not be fooled by this sad, desperate attempt to rebuild a player base that they have hated, admonished, punished, and lied to for years. The playerbase and the league scene are dying for a reason.

Author: 😎OGDown😎
Review Content: Remember the good ol' days when Overwatch was all about fun, strategy, and camaraderie? Well, buckle up, because Overwatch 2 is here to replace all that with a grind-fest that makes climbing a mountain look like a walk in the park!Promising an epic story mode that would rival the greatest tales ever told, OW2 instead delivered... nothing. That's right, the story mode was canceled faster than you can say "microtransaction." Speaking of which, say goodbye to your hard-earned player progress and hello to paid cosmetics. Want to grind for something meaningful? Too bad! Your only option is to chase a higher rank, a journey as fulfilling as chasing a rainbow for a pot of fool's gold.Ranked mode? More like "grind mode." It's as if the developers knew that the only thing left to strive for was a higher rank, so they made it as grindy as possible. Imagine running on a treadmill, but the treadmill is made of sandpaper, and you're wearing flip-flops. That's the OW2 ranked experience.The Blizzard we knew and loved? Gone, like a snowman in the Sahara. What's left is a vampire husk, thirsting for your wallet and ready to suck every last cent out of it. At this point, the best part of Blizzard games is watching the fallout around their bad anti-consumer business practices. It's like a soap opera, but with more drama and fewer likable characters.In conclusion, Overwatch 2 is like a bad sequel to a movie you loved. You'll watch it, you'll play it, but you'll leave feeling like something precious has been lost. And in this case, it's not just your time and money; it's a piece of gaming joy.

Author: NewtonianLλw
Review Content: Overwatch 2 is an excellent game that encompasses all the critical aspects that make for an enjoyable gaming experience. The art design is top-notch with an almost Pixar look to it. The sound design provides great synchronous feedback for each weapon used, and the music is perfectly themed to each setting. The maps are well-thought-out and include beautiful destinations from around the world. The game modes are the typical ones you'd see in any other online shooter. The large roster of characters each has their own unique costumes and personalities.Consensus:While I would definitely rank Overwatch 2 above many other popular shooters and recommend it to others, I would also be hesitant to invest a significant amount of time in it. The reason for this is consistency. If you've played the original Overwatch and then transitioned to Overwatch 2, somewhere during the transition, consistency was lost. The overhaul changed small details that made the original Overwatch's gunplay streamlined and fun.

Author: Dutexo
Review Content: Overwatch 2 is a disappointing sequel that fails to capture the magic of the original game.As someone who used to be a long-time fan of Overwatch with over 3000 hours of gameplay, I had some amount of excitement to see what Blizzard had in store for their sequel, but I was left feeling frustrated and bored by the changes they made. Overwatch 2 is not a true sequel, but rather a free-to-play update that replaces the first game and adds some cosmetic features and a new game mode. It does not offer any significant improvements or innovations, but rather takes away some of the core elements that made Overwatch fun and balanced.The most noticeable change is the reduction of team size from 6v6 to 5v5, which also means the removal of one tank role. I am a tank main and this has had a huge impact on my gameplay and my team’s dynamics, since the tank player is essential for creating space, absorbing damage, and protecting my teammates. For me personally by removing one tank, Blizzard has made my games more chaotic, less strategic, and more frustrating. As the singular tank remaining on the team, I have had to bear more pressure and responsibility. The game feels less like a team-based shooter and more like a solo deathmatch, where individual skill matters more than teamwork and coordination.Another change that I dislike is the introduction of a battle pass system and a cash shop that sells skins, emotes, sprays, and other cosmetic items. While these are optional and do not affect the gameplay directly, they still feel like a greedy attempt to squeeze more money out of me as a player. The battle pass requires a ridiculous amount lot of grinding and playing to unlock rewards, while the cash shop sells items that were previously available for free or through loot boxes in the first game.The biggest disappointment for me is the lack of the extensive PvE expansion that Blizzard had promised before. Overwatch 2 was supposed to have a rich story mode that would explore the lore and characters of the Overwatch universe, as well as co-op missions that would challenge us players with different objectives and scenarios. However, what we get instead is a shallow and repetitive PvE mode with no meaningful progression or variety. The broken promise of a PvE mode now feels like an afterthought that was added to justify the name of Overwatch 2, rather than a main feature that would enhance the game.Overwatch 2 is a letdown for me as a fan of the original game. It does not deliver on its promise of being a sequel, but rather strips away some of the best aspects that I loved in Overwatch 1 and replaces them with inferior ones. It feels like Blizzard has lost touch with what made Overwatch great and has succumbed to the trends of free-to-play games. I do not recommend Overwatch 2 to anyone who enjoyed Overwatch 1, as it will only ruin your memories and sour your experience.

Author: 𝔔𝔲𝔦𝔫𝔷𝔢𝔩
Review Content: "My family tells of an ancient legend about two great dragon brothers -- the dragon of the north wind, and the dragon of the south wind."This was from an Overwatch cinematic that came out adjacent to the games release. The amount of foreshadowing this would endow in the mind of fans with was unknown at the time, but seems remarkable in hindsight.There were always two sides (or dragons in this metaphor) within Overwatch -- as there always is in art that has turned into a lucrative business. You have the creatives; those with ambition, drive, passion, and a remarkable ability to sacrifice for the art form they love -- the other, those who wish to exploit and sell the art of others. Those who sell themselves as the logical mind behind the creatives."Together, they upheld balance and harmony in the heavens."For the most part this was true in Overwatch 1. Though they had lootboxes, they contained so much of so little that their purchase was inconsequential. During this period of 2016-2018, creativity was allowed to flourish -- before the balance wasn't so upheld in the blizzard heavens."But the two brothers argued over who could better rule their land. Their quarrel turned to rage and their violent struggle darkened the skies until the dragon of the south wind struck down his brother."From 2019 until overwatch 2 released in November 2022 was when I imagine this struggle happening. Their was silence from the development team. No new content on their new game that was making millions. Devs wanted to create and executives wanted to sell -- resulting in ever-changing goals and no new content for their starving fan base. With Overwatch 2 it seems the creatives at Blizzard have finally given up their struggles for artistic freedom and given into the demands of intellectually stunted and churlish businessmen."The dragon of the south wind knelt down on the ground and was finally able to see the world around him."I want this game to succeed. Millions of us do. We love what this game was and what it could be. I want Blizzard to realize their mistakes, become human -- but their gigantic success seems to have severed their ties to the humanity that once defined them.At the end of the cinematic I've been referencing, the brother who was thought to have been killed came back and faces his brother who killed him, beating him in a duel.  The ending remark of this cutscene perfectly describes my feelings on this game.The brother who comes back from the dead says to his murderous, evil brother "perhaps I am a fool for thinking their is still hope for you -- but I do."

Author: † Ghost †
Review Content: The result of greedy sharks who drowned the creativity and passion of developers in the name of money, I introduce you to Overwatch 2 !Maybe it's still possible to have a little fun with it, but there are so many negative points that fun is quickly replaced by bitterness. Overwatch 1 was a fine experience, certainly too generous by market standards compared to other shooters that adopted the battle pass system earlier than it did. But to turn it into such a bad, penny-pinching opposite... I really feel sorry for the developers who see their work crumble year after year.Blizzard won't be able to restore its reputation in the eyes of gamers by continuing down this path. It's not all about money. It's not all about pressure, crunch and abuse of employees. We don't know everything that goes on in Blizzard's offices, but if it comes down to making games that are so money-grubbing and disrespectful of players and developers alike, it's time to stop. Take a deep breath. And clean up this mess. Change the industry. Do something right for once. It happens to make mistakes, no matter how horrible, but it's also possible to fix them, to change. The hypocrisy has to stop.I doubt we'll find the same sensations as in Overwatch 1, but it was great to discover them back then. We miss you, buddy. Version 1.5 of yourself will never be anything but a fetid lie that saddens its fans, a lie because the very purpose of this "2" was to go for something new and so exciting, but it will never be that way. Because the slim glimpse we'll be served up like hungry dogs will require us to spend a fortune to access denatured, premature and filthy content. Life is expensive enough these days that we don't need to be knowingly robbed.Don't force people who are too weak and still have a tiny shred of hope left in them to pay. You know very well that there are plenty of them. The point of a game is to be able to play it, not to rub a company's balls regularly with a credit card and then gain access to it. Please don't think of the players as your wh0res, Kotick. Think of people as human beings.You can still try to play Overwatch 2, but it'll be frustrating, the players will be angry/frustrated, the content you'll get will be poor and scattered. Have fun with this crap.

Author: Treesama
Review Content: You guys remember when EA commented on that guys Reddit post about having to pay $80 to unlock Vader in Battlefront 2? The same comment that now holds the record for most downvoted comment in all of Reddit history? Yeah they practically shot themselves in the foot with that. Now Blizzard is doing the same by releasing Overwatch 2 on steam. So here's hoping this becomes the most disliked game on Steam. Positives  Steam takes a 30% cut of the microtransactions, meaning less money lining Blizzard exec's pockets Negatives  Cancelled PvE Being lied to for months and months about cancelled PvE Went from being 6v6 to 5v5 Paywall on just about everything Minimal rewards that you can actually "earn"  Literally just Overwatch 1 on a new engine, a new engine that Blizzard specifically said was needed for them to be able to properly create the PvE mode The PvE missions that WERE added are maybe 20 minutes at most, and there's 3 of them. $15 for one hour of content just to put it in perspective.  Kiriko skin that costs $40 lol This game singlehandedly has made me miss lootboxes because at least my time spent playing was somewhat respected.

Author: Baguette
Review Content: And now the end is here, and so I face that final curtain. My friend I'll make it clear, I'll state my case, of which I'm certain.I've lived a life that's full, I traveled each and every highway. And more, much more, I did it, I did it my way... Regrets, I've had a few... But then again... too few to mention... I did what I had to do, I saw it through without exemption. I planned each charted course, each careful step along the byway. But through it all, when there was doubt, I ate it up and spit it out. I faced it all and I stood tall and did it my way. For what is a man, what has he got? Author: DrexiNッ
Review Content: Title: A Dumpster Fire of a Sequel: Overwatch 2 Drops the BallRating: ★☆☆☆☆Oh boy, where to begin with this mess? Overwatch 2 is like a bad joke that you wish you could unhear. Here's the ugly truth about this fiasco:Gameplay Mechanics: This isn't a game; it's a torture device. Characters are unoriginal, the balance is all out of whack, and playing feels like slogging through mud. Whoever designed these "innovative" updates must've been having a bad day—every day.Graphics and Visual Appeal: Did they make this in a garage over the weekend? The graphics look like they're from the Stone Age, and the animations are about as lively as a cardboard cutout. Talk about cutting corners!Storyline and Mission Design: The plot is as shallow as a kiddie pool, and the missions are as thrilling as watching paint dry. It's a masterclass in how NOT to tell a story.Monetization Strategy: If you like flushing money down the toilet, you'll love Overwatch 2's in-game purchases. The entire model feels like a shameless cash grab.Technical Issues: Bugs, glitches, and more bugs. It's like playing "Whack-a-Mole" with issues. Someone seriously dropped the ball on quality control.Community Interaction and Support: Trying to get support is like yelling into a void. Good luck getting a response that's not as robotic and disconnected as the game itself.Overall Experience: Overwatch 2 is a disaster, a letdown, and an embarrassment to the franchise. It's like taking everything good about the original and chucking it out the window. Save yourself the frustration and steer clear of this train wreck.--Written by chatGPT--

Author: choccymi1k_3003
Review Content: Don’t let my steam hours fool you: I’ve played this game for 400 hours. Embarrassing, I know. So take me seriously when I say play any other game. You deserve better, I assure you, you do. This game is a massive disappointment to those whose patience was tested for years on end. This game is an unbalanced hellscape with characters that were so obviously unprepared for the switch from 6v6 to 5v5, balancing changes that have no real direction, characters left in near unplayable conditions. The worst part of all imo is that the entire purpose for this game existing, the reason why ow1 was left treading water for years, the extensive hero and story modes, were thrown to the ditch. What’s left of “””OW2””” is a mission pack with archive missions packaged in a bundle promoting a battle pass; Unbelievable. I’m not original for saying this, but I hate this game. But that hate stemmed from a place of love. Many players are so angry because we WANTED this game to succeed; we wanted Overwatch to come back bigger than ever. But because daddy kotick wanted another couple million dollars in his pockets, a game that fostered beloved memories and moments, despite being given ample chance to rise from the ashes, simply didn’t. RIP Overwatch, maybe if Doomfist was a good character, you’d be a 10/10. If you really want your overwatch fix; the porn has more quality tbh.

Author: LexGear
Review Content: Would I recommend this to new players? No, and here is why:- The matchmaking has no balancing. They just throw whoever is around together making the games very one-sided.- With no objectives or personal journeys, progress is non-existent. There is just nothing to work towards. To use Team Fortress 2 as a comparison, at least in TF2 you can work on achievements or contracts.- PvE is very boring with nothing but primitive AI and damage sponges.- Game is constantly unbalanced. I do not understand why after all this time they cannot get this right?- Skins and cosmetics are very expensive and pointless when all you can see are your hands.- And worst of all, Overwatch 1, the game I paid good money for, is gone.

Author: dpninja
Review Content: I think the most important thing to state first is that I'm very bad at this game. Is that why I don't recommend it? No, but I will admit that there is a bit of spite in this review. Overwatch (2) is a game that reminds me a lot of League of Legends. Not in the gameplay or the visuals, but the feeling of frustration in not understanding something. While LoL has characters that have more power or abilities than others, it's much easier to understand because of how the top-down gameplay works. Even with such a massive list of characters, all you have to do is play two games at the most to understand enough to fight them. Still, this does not circumvent the problem with characters being more powerful or having more utility than you. Overwatch takes this complication to the extreme in the fact that you have made it 3D, an FPS, and basically a movement shooter at the same time (not that all of those three aren't the same thing most of the time anyway). Positioning in LoL is important, but Overwatch makes you consider a third plane that isn't always on screen. This isn't necessarily a bad thing, but it can add to the frustrations. My point in this whole comparison is not to go play LoL, I am just saying that both games are frustrating because of unbalanced characters, and adding the complications of gameplay on top can just make it all fall apart. I'm not good at LoL or Overwatch, but I can still find enjoyment with friends. Still, I can't recommend them. Because why play something if it isn't fun?

Author: Naraic
Review Content: Although I am a stranger on the internet, I hope you can take my word to heart when I report that Overwatch (I'll refer to it as OW) was my favorite and casual 'go-to' game for many years. I have 1960+ hours in-game with my top three, and favorite, 'heroes' being Ana, Zarya, and Reaper. I started playing back in beta (yes, I have the Widowmaker skin). With this information divulged, allow me to share my insight further.From a gameplay standpoint, OW is still a good game. It combines the fundamentals of Team Fortress and, on a basic level, any MOBA. The result is spectacular! Niche characters with niche abilities that [can] combo and create unique, niche experiences each round / session. I have enjoyed hours-upon-hours of back-to-back games. When you have an itch for a team-based shooter, OW is a great way to scratch. Load it up, find a game, and you can be done in less than 10 minutes. In and out, clean and simple. It's great!That written, let me get to the 'meat and potatoes' (read: overall) subjects at hand. I have spoiled you, the reader, by serving dessert first. The good is in the past. I hope you're ready for the rest of the meal!As everything does, OW has changed. In the past, this was cause for excitement; the game would get spiced up and the balance changes were, usually, quality of life (i.e. quality of game) driven at a tier 2, casual level. These days the changes are infrequent, nominal, and [feel] financially driven. As the son of a business owner, I understand 'profit' is an easy way to attach success to effort. That said, I also understand that reaching out to Steam is Activision Blizzard's way of handing a crutch to a failing model. As written by many before me: the OW development team issued many statements (I interpreted these words as goals and promises) that, after years, have not come true. On top the failure(s) to produce, the game has become an unbalanced amalgamation. While OW has a healthy roster of characters, if your "main(s)" don't fall under the OP category, prepare yourself to get flamed by foes AND allies in competitive play. This, on a gameplay level, is not okay. Since every character has a niche, balance is key to creating a fun and interactive environment for players. So, today, I dare ask OW devs: why are there SUPPORT class heroes  consistently  out damaging DPS class heroes? Why were tanks, the most diverse and impactful characters in the game, reduced to one player? Why is it okay to charge for underwhelming content that was  promised  to your playerbase years ago? For those of you still reading: allow me to summarize the rest of my thoughts in a simple TL;DR with solutions:1) The characters are not balanced. Adding a 'Ban Phase' would alleviate many issues. Tuning some numbers would create less hostile and lopsided environment.2) Certain game modes are not fun. Adding a 'Preference' or 'Do Not Allow' for maps or modes would alleviate this frustration. Yes, the queues would take longer but, the quality of match would increase.3) The battlepass is  effectively  a subscription to a F2P game. I feel betrayed that most of the new content is locked behind a paywall. As someone with  just  under 2k hours  ingame  I would hope to have the majority of content unlocked. With the new things locked behind a paywall, I have become content with having a diminishing unlock %.4) The PvE content is uninspiring. I was under the impression that we would be allowed access to 'perks' that would modify and resculpt playstyles. Now, instead of playing against players, I can play the  same normal ingame characters  against robots. The fact that it's paid content? As a Reaper main:  pathetic 5) The scoreboard screen is a mistake. Everyone on a team being able to see (although this doesn't mean they can properly identify) teammate's stats is a mistake. It enables toxic comparison in a real-time environment. The number of games that I have played that ended in toxic flaming has  increased .6) The standard 'new character' release method is  frustrating . New heroes are consistently overtuned and overperforming until they get hit with the nerf bat.  IF  the nerf happens. Sometimes it doesn't. Seems to me that the 'patch testers' are, relative to the average player, too good or bottom tier (i.e. NOT average).7) After  roughly  22 in-game hours I have hit level 45 in the battlepass. This, for F2P players, is the level requirement to unlock the newest [overperforming] hero: Illari. To be honest, I understand that Blizzard is trying to coerce players into spending money; this methodology feels wrong. Choosing between $10 or a  literal  day of in-game time to unlock a character? I am openly disappointed.To wrap it up, OW ought to be a paid game. Something manageable ($20?!?) to get players ingrained and committed to the community while fueling the devs passion to produce quality content. Instead, we have a 'F2P' game with microtransactions (that get advertised to you each time you open the game) and, borderline, meaningless updates. This written, it seems to me that this style of game is  ready  for a new Name / Brand to scoop up the majority of the playerbase.If you see me online, let me know how I wrote! I'll still be playing despite all the signs of an abusive relationship. GL HF DDNaraic

Author: Viaphex
Review Content:
Product received for free
																The gameplay is still fun, because it's just OW1, but there's just so many downgrades:- The monetisation is horrible, the first game had lootboxes that you could buy, but you got them for free at a flat rate by just playing. In OW2 you have a premium battlepass, have to buy new heroes, a lot of the skins are locked behind virtual currency, and you also have to purchase the PvE mode. It's bizarre to think that lootboxes were the better option.- The further reworks of heroes are just terrible, I don't understand why they keep making the classic heroes less fun.- Endorsements are more confusing without labelling their team or what they got awards for.- The awards themselves are gone completely so only play of the game remains (which most of the time isn't even impressive because it's just someone using an easy ult), And only damage dealers get play of the game, there's no award for giving the most healing for support or anything like that.- I find the removal of the second tank to be a dubious change at best. It makes playing the tank very restrictive as they have to work twice as hard now to keep the time alive, and cannot do anything beyond that (like flanking) otherwise their team will die.

Author: Pangolin
Review Content: I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2016 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching some yellow YouTube. So I decided to get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my son many happy memories.

Author: lizbean
Review Content: from someone with 1600+ hours who actively plays the game since beta, i do enjoy it but wouldn't recommend it if you haven't played before or for a long time, especially not spending money on it.here's a list of all the things wrong with the game i'll edit and add to as i remember them :p- broken ranking system- bad matchmaking- overpriced skins- no premium currency in battlepass, amount you get from challenges is laughable- some balance changes make no sense and feel added for the sake of change- frequent disconnects- incredibly toxic playerbase, even in the most casual modes. playing comp requires chat off to keep your sanity- removing progression- adding back worse progression- 6v6 is better than 5v5, feels more like TDM now- devs focused too heavily on OWL and top 500 with updates and balancing- PvE with no replayablilty when workshop modes can easily put it in- OW1 PvE the same or better than new paid for PvE- charging for old OW1 skins- removed OW1 comp stats from career profile- UI downgraded from OW1- a lot of lazy recolours resold as new full priced skins- souvenirs are bad and are just in the game to pad the battlepass and shop bundles- most weapons charms are very badly made and placement on some heroes is horrible- worse audio, footsteps and spacial awareness compared to OW1- reducing the amount of comp points from end of season to make you play more than you want- most seasonal events / game modes are low tier, even a lot of workshop modes are better

Author: neapawlitans
Review Content: Never played the first game before, but from what I've heard everyone seems to agree that the old game was better in nearly every aspect. From what I've experienced in the second game, the game play itself isn't too bad, it's just that everything around it is. Very.Starting to play the game, a large amount of the heroes are locked. After I played the game for a considerable amount of time, it became clear to me that they were behind a paywall and unless you didn't want to spend money in the game, you would have to put a lot of hours into the game. There are even some heroes that are behind battle passes, which is a huge problem when part a large part of the game is counter-picking heroes against your opponent. Any level of pay-to-win has no place in a competitive FPS at all. This made me even more disgruntled when hearing that the first game had no locked heroes at all.Additionally, this game has a pretty bad matchmaking system. Just playing quick play, I managed to rack up over a 12-game loss streak despite me playing not bad at all and playing with friends who were better than me. I understand this is just a casual game mode and I may have gotten unlucky with who i was going against and who i had on my team, but I've never had this happen to me in any game before. This is an even bigger issue for me after learning that there are deliberate systems in the game to not put such unequally skilled players in a single game. Losing and getting steamrolled certainly isn't fun at all, and apparently this issue even extends to competitive matchmaking which is obviously really bad.My biggest gripe with this game, however, are these terrible blunders that Blizzard keeps making. I've already mentioned a bit of the microtransactions with heroes, but the microtransactions in general are way too egregious even for a F2P game. One really scummy thing I encountered was Gingerbread Bastion being in the shop for 1 Overwatch coin. At that point I had about 20 hours into the game and no coins at all. Trying to earn any was nearly impossible, and if I wanted to buy just one coin, I would've had to get 500 at $5. Why not just make it free at that point? I went through the hassle of trying to grind out the game to get some coins for free last-second before the skin went away in the shop and I eventually gave up. My gf actually gifted me some coins so that I could get the skin, but for some stupid reason it took over 24 hours for the coins to show up in my account, way after the skin was gone.Aside from that very dumb and frustrating situation, I have to mention what they've done to the PVE mode. Everybody knows that story at this point and how ridiculous of a decision that was, but now they're putting out PVE missions for $15 a pack. Apparently, they're not even worth the $15 at all and can be completed in a couple hours. Even worse, people that have bought the Steam DLC are saying that it's not even working. Blizzard is straight up scamming people at this point... The list of the really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ things that Blizzard has done keeps going on and on. The way they've treated their employees, how they're literally supporting the termination of Overwatch 2's esports scene by giving teams millions of dollars if they leave, and now how they've brought the game to Steam, which anybody with a brain could foresee that this game would just be bombed with negative reviews, and nothing else. And it deservedly gets mostly negative reviews.I don't think anybody wished for this game to be this mistreated by Blizzard. I just wanted to find an alternative hero-based FPS to Team Fortress 2 that isn't left abandoned and neglected by devs to rot, but it seems like I still haven't found it. Nobody should be supporting this company at all. This game and its devs have to be the biggest gaming disappointments of 2023.

Author: Mamasboy
Review Content: Title: A Disheartening Regression from Potential: Overwatch 2 ReviewRating: ★☆☆☆☆ (1/5)Overwatch 2 had all the potential to be a fantastic sequel that builds upon the foundation set by its predecessor. However, after spending countless hours with the game, it's with a heavy heart that I write this review, as it's evident that the developers have missed the mark on several critical aspects.Visual Stagnation:For a game that boasts a "2" in its title, the visual improvements are shockingly minimal. Character models and textures seem almost identical to the first game, leaving me questioning where the development time has been spent. Given the significant advancements in graphics technology, the lack of visual evolution in Overwatch 2 is baffling and disappointing.Uninspired Gameplay Additions:The touted new game modes and features come across as desperate attempts to remain relevant in a rapidly evolving gaming landscape. Pushing the narrative-focused elements to the forefront should have been a bold move, but the execution is lackluster at best. The "Story Experience" feels like an afterthought, with uninspired missions that offer repetitive objectives and shallow storytelling. The lack of innovation in gameplay modes is disheartening, making the game feel stale even before its official release.Balance Woes Persist:Overwatch 2 seemed like a chance for the developers to address the glaring balance issues that plagued the first game. Unfortunately, it appears that they've carried over the same problems, rendering some heroes almost unplayable due to their ineffectiveness in certain scenarios. It's bewildering how characters can go untouched for so long, leaving the competitive scene in a constant state of frustration.Communication Breakdown:Effective communication between developers and players is paramount for any live-service game. However, Overwatch 2 seems to have regressed in this aspect, with a lack of transparency about the game's progress, upcoming changes, and overall development roadmap. This disconnect erodes the trust between the community and the developers, fostering an environment of frustration and uncertainty.Microtransactions and Monetization:It's disheartening to witness the focus on microtransactions and cosmetic items overshadow genuine gameplay improvements. The introduction of new skins and other cosmetic items is seemingly prioritized over addressing core issues, which feels like a slap in the face to the dedicated player base. This shift towards monetization tarnishes the game's integrity and leaves a sour taste in the mouths of long-time fans.A Dull Story Experience:One of the most anticipated additions was the story mode, promising to delve into the Overwatch universe's lore. However, what we get is a lackluster campaign that fails to captivate players with its shallow storytelling and repetitive missions. The potential for an engaging narrative is squandered in favour of padding out the game with forgettable content.Uninspired Gameplay Additions:The introduction of new game modes and features was a promising prospect, but the execution feels uninspired. The "Push" mode, while offering a slight twist on the classic formula, doesn't add the depth or excitement that the original modes provided. The "Story Experience" missions, despite the intent to expand the narrative, often devolve into repetitive objectives that become tiresome to replay.In conclusion, Overwatch 2 feels like a missed opportunity to elevate the franchise to new heights. With minimal visual improvements, uninspired gameplay additions, persistent balance issues, and a lack of effective communication, it's hard to justify this sequel's existence. While I hold a fondness for the original Overwatch, this follow-up is a painful reminder that sequels don't always live up to expectations. I sincerely hope that the developers take this feedback to heart and work towards rectifying the glaring issues that currently mar the Overwatch 2 experience.

Author: im on lexapro
Review Content: Just finished playing my first session of Overwatch in 3 years and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ it's so much worse than I remember.I used to play OW1 with the friends I had in highschool that I couldn't convince to play TF2 instead. I can't remember how many hours/how much money I wasted on it in total. Back in it's earlier days(I started playing around 2017-2018), I remember it being pretty fun. I mainly played tanks before my faves were nerfed to the point where they became next to useless. Then, they kept adding in new heroes that were so OP or broken that they ruined the entire ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ game. The seasonal PvE events became boring fast. Overwatch's story was basically nonexistent and characters were being ignored. I started breaking free from my debilitating addiction around 2019-ish and finally uninstalled around early to mid 2020, but I kept an eye on the upcoming ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ from afar. Now, this supposed titan of a class-based shooter game that everyone said would kill TF2 has joined Steam in a shameless attempt to save itself from dying a second time as the previously-mentioned 17 year old hat wearing simulator is reaching record highs in player count(though the bot issue isn't totally fixed lol valve u gotta get on that ♥♥♥♥ pronto. since this game's dying again these devs r gonna need jobs so how ab u hit em up)Everything I hated about OW1 is back but amplified. First off, the gameplay. I remember it being decently fun back when the game had half as many heroes with the quality steadily decreasing as time passed. Now? It's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ miserable. There's no skill involved, only pain. You're constantly getting stunned, frozen, thrown around, slept, etc until someone on the enemy team who's been playing for a total of 10 minutes accidentally hits Q and instakills you. It also doesn't help that, with there being so many playable heroes that have the same skinny Caucasian frame, you can't tell who's who in the heat of battle until it's too late. It's just mindless. I don't care who wins or loses, just save me from this hellhole. I didn't even bother looking into their PvE ♥♥♥♥. It looks just as boring as it was before, and I'm not spending actual money to find out if that's the case in this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ economy. The worst part is definitely the microtransactions and other paid DLC content. For some reason, Blizzard thought that lootboxes were appropriate for a game that costs $60 but not for a game that's free to play. You used to be able to get legendary skins through free lootbox drops just by leveling up. Now you're expected to pay anywhere between $15-$30 to purchase a single ugly, over-designed skin. You can also purchase items with coins, but they give you so few each week that they're practically useless. This is only covering cosmetics. In-game content, the stupid ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ battle pass, and even playable heroes are also locked behind steep paywalls, and none of it is worth it. Meanwhile, I can hop in Steam's own community market and purchase multiple whole outfits for all 9 TF2 mercs for a total of $5 or trade my abundance of scrap metal for cosmetic case keys. Team Fortress 2's cosmetics also allow for better customization while staying true to the game's art style(with a few exceptions). Blizzard shares no such care for its game or the people who play it, only wishing to milk as much cold hard cash from its playerbase as possible before their servers empty. I wanted to give OW2 a genuine chance. I used to love this game, and I wanted to see actual good things done with it. I didn't wanna log back on after 3 years and see that everything was the same but far worse, but it is. There's nothing here, just the dried out husk of a game that once was. I'm convinced that everyone still stuck playing this game at this point is suffering from Stockholm syndrome, because there's no ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ way you people actually like playing this ♥♥♥♥. There's no soul, just a pathetic cash grab from a pathetic company. Blizzard is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ out unneeded heroes that are locked behind paywalls when the free heroes fulfill their main purpose without the ♥♥♥♥♥♥ gimmicks. They hype up the game's story when there's none to be had. They suck themselves off when it comes to diversity and acceptance, yet 1) make sure none of the characters have a personality aside from being annoying and make most of the POC characters evil, 2) sameface all of the female characters/copy and paste the same body types, 3) add racist skins that offend the groups they claim to care about and refuse to remove them from the store, 4) censor any mentions of characters being LGBT from foreign releases, and 5) punish players for speaking out against injustice and mistreat their own employees. Not to bring TF2 into this review section for the millionth time, but there really isn't a reason to play Overwatch when it exists. Instead of clogging up the game with ♥♥♥♥♥♥ characters that do the same ♥♥♥♥, TF2 features 9 extremely charismatic, lovable, fun to play mercenaries with their own far unique abilities. Each individual class can be customized with different weapons that are useful in different gameplay situations, giving players multiple creative ways to play a single character. Each class is fun to play in its own way and actually feels useful, not to mention playing TF2 actually takes skill(lol). It's had an incredibly fun and replayable PvE mode since 2012 that's FREE TO PLAY(unless you do tours in which case u can purchase or trade for tickets but that's optional), on top of other really fun gamemodes with the most recent being Versus Saxton Hale being officially added. The holiday updates are also wayyyyy better(if you try and tell me that any of overwatch's seasonal events come close to topping scream fortress you're a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ liar). Team Fortress 2 has a complex story that's explored through comics and animated shorts and, despite taking itself less seriously, has more heart and emotion than the majority of Overwatch's side media. Even TF2's porn is better. Does Overwatch have community game modes where you can play as the heroes with their ♥♥♥♥♥ and balls out? Or art of Roadhog ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ into Junkrat's open mouth? I didn't think so. Honestly, TF2's community itself puts it so far ahead of OW. I meet so many nice, accepting people in matches, and I have more fun playing it than any other multiplayer experience. Blizzard doesn't even care about you guys enough to release a good game with all of its promised features, yet Valve lets fans add their own custom TF2 content in the form of cosmetics, weapon skins, gamemodes, weapons, taunts, comics, events, and even animated shorts. SFM/GMOD animations, fanart, memes, etc are still being made featuring the TF2 mercs even after all of this time. Overwatch will continue to fail until it's but a distant, bitter memory, and people will only come back to jerk off to Widowmaker getting railed by a Fortnite character. This went from being a review to me trying to convince you ding dongs to move on to a superior gaming experience lol. Even in it's current crusty, neglected, bot-filled state, Team Fortress 2 a far better experience than anything Overwatch Poo has to offer, and I highly recommend it, especially since it's currently experiencing a resurgence after 7 years. Anyways, drop this turd and come play a game that'll give you a thick bush. Feel free to add me, I'm looking for ppl to play Mvm and comp with lol and if you're coming from Overweight I'll show you the ropes. :-)

Author: MarlinMcFish
Review Content: TLDR:played since releasegame is fun at its coregrind sucks though and isnt new player friendlyseason 6 is actually pretty goodpve is a bummer but its not badhope for the futureits free, runs on any computer, who tf caresSo lets go through the pros and cons because there is a LOT of misinformation and to be frank rough launch of OW 2 we need to cover.I am low Diamond with probably around 1k hrs from Pre-order in 2015 so I would like to say i have Veteran knowledgeI will not argue that I have extreme bias since I play Scrimmages and I have all the characters since owning OW 1 Pros: It's free so why notSO MANY HEROESsurprisingly well balanced for A) the amt of heroes and B) the diversity of them5v5 is much less chaotic than old 6v6 (but boasts new problems)great artstyle and easily runs on low end PC's and even better on linux (so i have heard)they will now have rotating FREE PVE events that are fun but unfortunately arent really replayablethey have paid Story PVE DLC and i hear it is good and fun from friends (but i have not played)season 6 boasts a host of new content and probably the best battle pass skins seen yetservers are no longer being DDOSED on seasonal release making season 6 probably the smoothest season release to date meaning the devs are learning and activision has most likely given them more servers. I got in this season without needing a queue time Cons: The community is really whiny and really toxic especially in competitive. Some people forgot you're supposed to have fun in a game and not care about virtual numbersI said SURPRISINGLY balanced but the game's meta basically is held bent on fractions of decimal numbers and character swapping. The OW 2 update brings several challenges to its progression system by locking charactersthe grind for each character is not something I have had to experience but i cant imagine it would be that funnew characters are locked behind tier 45 of the battlepass which wouldnt be a problem with most games HOWEVER OW's meta has been COUNTER SWAPPING. AKA Ramattra is one of the BEST tanks right now and not having him is extremely unfortunate given the tank's viability in 5v5.although battle pass skins are extremely detailed and great looking, they are character specific and the amount is fewShop items should be ignored. The price range for any skin worth money is around 20 dollars PER SKIN and unlike valorant, no reload animations, no new gun sounds (unless mythic; only in BP) and are character specific meaning you have to: A) like the character B) hope the character is viable and C) own the actual character. the competitive system is STILL being worked on due to F2P player influx so as a new player you might get dunked on plat lobbies for some reason on your first ever competitive match Conclusion Overall, it is free. I'm not sure how hard meta is below high gold but i cant expect it to mean very much so hopefully all the counter swapping meta characters wont matter as I hope by the time you get out of bronze.with the newest character Illari having some of the most solo carry potential in the support category and mechanical skill scaling really well with DPS characters, climbing out of low ELO should be a breeze and if you lack mechanical but make up for strategic positioning, you will find yourself carrying lobbies and outsmarting the mechanically gifted History of Review Bombing HateSo why all the hate? and why all the news?TLDR:the OW community is really annoyed and are acting like children with trigger finger on reviews because they are upset that a PVP on release game is going to be a PVP game primarily from now on.I sympathize with the lost time between the 3 years but lets move on and review the game we have now not the game we hoped for.OW 2 is arguably doing better than many other games ex: Escape from Tarkovthe game hasnt died yet and its free so just play the game and see if you like it. the 30gbs aren't worth review bombing for if you actually enjoy it.Basically, PVE was heavily scaled back and OW 1 was abandoned for 3 years before OW 2's release with lots of teasing and no communication.During the release of the first few seasons of OW 2 the Devs did nothing to tell us about the scaled back PVE and allowed the community and content creators to continue hyping up the PVE release when the devs had already decided to scale it back but knew the game would not do well if there was no PVE hype.It is important to note that the entire community was allowing the Devs to get off the hook for many bugs and little PVP balancing throughout this time in hopes that this was all for a well polished PVE Champaign with lots of replayability.This original vision was scaled back by eliminating replayability basically making the paid for champaign a lore/story driven idea (something like halo infinite in this case) the community felt lied to and the backlash was felt.To top off everything, Blizzard was sinking a TON of money into esports which for OW was at an all time low which has resulted in the next season of Overwatch League to be fully canceled.Although all of these grievances are felt and i very much feel them too, this review bombing spree is unwarrented and i would like to keep an open mind to the future as I HOPE all of this back-scaling on Overwatch as a franchise will give more time to work on WHAT MATTERS: PVP gameplay.I wish PVE would be amazing, I wish that the MMO vision was accomplished and I wish there were two seperate fully kitted out dev teams for PVP and PVE but we don't live that fantasy and the devs have realized that and have stopped overworking themselves balancing OWL, PVE, and PVP all at the same time for a stupidly small dev team with a AAA publisher that doesn't realize the money cow this game could be for AGES. Why Do I Recommend? Its free, its really small, it works on almost any device so WHO CARESthe newest season released really well and the content they have created is something I hope they keep up with especially on the patch notes side.I play scrimmages: Player headed 5v5 matches that last with the same two teams several maps in a row organized through discord servers.they are extremely fun to play and toxicity is at an all time low and it is how I keep hope for what this game could very easily be.I recommend anyone to find these servers and play in them as they are open to all skill divisions where you are placed in a rank of your choosing. (also you can play any character you dont own  :shh:)

Author: AnkhaAnkhaFootManiac1941
Review Content: Overwatch 2 was touted as a sequel to the original game that would feature a PvE game mode that was comprehensive and you could play with your friends.What you get instead: The deletion of the original game, which was already ruined with updates, now quite literally destroyed. A game that is mostly the same as the original with balance updates and a monetization system that priorities the prospects of free to play with the current market trends. Such as battle passes and unlocking heroes. -Not to say the original monetization was better, gambling is objectively worse than not gambling, but it is seen as worse because it is unsatisfying compared to the original because of the length it takes to unlock things. No doubt, and I agree. It is industry standard practices and not as unethical. Too bad industry standards are garbage, and I don't agree it even fits in the argument of "you know what you were buying" because you don't. You buy Overwatch 1 and lose it. That was not advertised, and you get Overwatch 2 which doesn't even get the PvE feature they advertised. You do not get what you pay for and even if you did, it doesn't make the willing purchases worth it.The one chance they had to somehow make me a convert, launching the game through the Proton layer to get the play time to review this, failed. Because it crashed immediately while trying to run it. If you aren't even gonna have the proton layer work I don't even know why they are on steam other than the smell of desperation or lawsuits from anti competitive practices or something similar.------Meta-discourse bottomline: This is getting review bombed because as a company Blizzard has pissed everyone off and this is just one of many examples of how. They've earned such hatred it goes beyond reason for many people and it IS a trend and I acknowledge that. But essentially the devs and the very structures of Blizzard. For many people like me, have passed the event horizon. To claw back from their position would take such extreme measures it wouldn't even be the same company it has become. One that destroys their past legacy content like WC3 and OW1. Is known for internal assault, playing good boy (evil) for the CCP's propaganda arm on Taiwan and Hong Kong because the mighty dollar matters more. Diablo immortal... Need i say more? Generally even all of that could be forgiven if they made ♥♥♥♥ that was good. Because people don't care if you do bad things unless you stop giving them what they want...And they can't even manage that. Because they have only the most feeble devs that want to be "a real developer at a real company" but debase themselves for that vague, worthless dream. Inject their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ because they'd rather be doing -anything else- and just use the companies intellectual properties -and our attachment to them- as a vehicles for exploring their own ideas unrelated to the source material or good game making. Or good story telling honestly. Why did both ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ WoW and Diablo have planned rape plot lines that were scrapped again? From the company known for SA? That removed ♥♥♥♥ from wow that was too lewd not long ago? Sure the board of directors is evil, but they aren't begging the devs for more rape in games.

Author: Snipar
Review Content: One of the few times I want to write a genuine review Problems with the game entirely:  Putting heroes behind the battle pass is a joke. A character can be so game changing at times can make the game seem pay to win. I get that you can unlock these heroes by doing challenges, but that was something i had to go out looking for. I did not know this until LIfeweaver because Blizzard is more focused on promoting to buy the battle pass.  The lack of PvE shows, and will be more detailed in the next list because they're execution in this new update shows how much it will really be missed.   Toxic community and devs. Developers do not bother trying in new updates that brings people over. Even if they did, the people who play this game make sure you dont want to be here. Granted this is a problem with this game specifically, rather another one to list in a pile of other communities, but the fact that this game is being carried by R34 artists says a lot about how much people actually care about this game.  To be added Now my problems with this update specifically that came out on this platform:  Hero progression means nothing. Why have levels for a character and a progression system when there is nothing to progress to? On top of that, why add a whole new progression system when Overwatch 1 has a level progression system for the whole account? ( WHICH CAN BE FOUND IN OVERWATCH 2 ALREADY TRACKED ) Update 1: I just found out the hero progression is for title cards. Thats it. I would of taken basic voice lines or sprays rather than a name card. Sad.  The new game mode sucks. Maps are too big for team coordination and expands the problem further. Example: you die in a fight and they capture the point. Now there is a whole new spawn location for you and your team, except half of your team is still at the old point, which is over 100m away making fights a 3v5 or less.  Beating a dead horse, the lack of PvE is a major loss for this game, and what they added instead of that is a joke. Granted, the paid missions I have not played yet, but if they are similar to what the free one is that I just played, its just Kings Uprising all over again. Bland AI's move from point a to b with lifeless movement makes me feel like im in the shooting range in practice mode. And the objectives are the same thing that has been around for years. Update 2: The story missions are at least interesting, but not worth the money I was right about the AI being bland and boring. Its just an interactive overwatch animation short except you pay $15 a mission. Just watch someone else play it on YouTube.Which brings back to the main question, why is this called Overwatch 2? (Rhetorical Question, we all know its just for the corporate cash grab lifestyle). When i am alone, ill take any other shooter any day of the week. But because my friends would rather play this than something like Team Fortress 2, or any other game someone may name, my soul dies every other day. The moment this game actually gets this ♥♥♥♥ together is the day im happy. I will edit this review if changes actually happen, weather its Blizzard making those changes or my own thoughts change.
